content: When looking for the best stocks to buy and watch, focus on those with rising relative price strength. One stock that fits that bill is Mosaic (MOS), which had its Relative Strength (RS) Rating upgraded from 78 to 81 Wednesday. X When looking for the best stocks to buy and watch, be sure to pay attention to relative price strength.IBD's unique rating measures market leadership with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The grade shows how a stock's price performance over the last 52 weeks compares to all the other stocks in our database. History shows that the stocks that go on to make the biggest gains typically have an RS Rating of at least 80 in the early stages of their moves.Looking For Winning Stocks? Dividend stocks come in all shapes and sizes. And seasons.The name CF Industries (CF) recently cropped up on IBD's Dividend Leaders list, just as Corn Belt farmers should be rolling into their spring planting season. This year's weather has been uncooperative, however, keeping farmers from their fields by spreading snow, rain and heavy winds from the Gulf Coast through the Midwest.Still, analyst consensus projects the equivalent of a 476% rebound in CF's EPS to 94 cents a share this year, followed by an 85% gain in 2019 to $1.74. CF lost 25 cents a share in 2017. The Deerfield, Ill., company exited nine quarters of earnings declines in the fourth quarter. Its Q1 EPS is forecast to rise 400%.The stock's chart is not pretty. Its price has slipped 9% since the start of the year. Shares are just climbing off support at their 40-week moving average. They could be building a base,Â but have got a ways to go. And the stock's dragging relative strength line is not what you want to see, even from dividend stocks.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseAnd yet CF may be worth putting on your radar. Some analysts project that the entire fertilizer industry is set for a cyclical upturn. Two of the industry's largest names, Potash Saskatchewan and Agrium, combined in January to form Nutrien (NTR). The merger tightened competition and provided the industry added control over manufacturing and supply. Consensus estimates expect Nutrien's earnings to soar 420% this year and 27% in 2019.Susquehanna Financial group trimmed its earnings outlook for CF Industries in late March, as bad weather pointed to delays in purchases of nitrogen fertilizer. Susquehanna also dropped the stock's 12-month price target to 50 from 54. The target is still more than 30% above where the stock traded on Monday.CF currently pays a 30-cent quarterly dividend per share, so the stock yields 3.1% annually. The company paid down $1.1 billion of high-interest debt at the end of 2017. Analysts at Susquehanna Financial Group project the company will pay down an additional $500 million in debt this year.Next to flashy tech and big defense names, fertilizers seem like a sleepy little sideline industry. But the stocks wowed investors with a collective run-up of more than 1,100% from 2002 to 2008. The group crashed along with the market, then ran up an additional 316% from 2008 to 2013.The Potash/Agrium merger left CF, Mosaic (MOS) and Nutrien as the leading publicly traded players in a vast and vitally important industry. Only CF and Nutrien are dividend stocks. But all of the stocks in the group vary according to several factors. One is the price of corn and soybeans. Two of the most widely planted North American crops, they also require the most intensive use of fertilizers.But the trade tiff between the U.S. and China have left corn prices uncertain, to say the least. Prices on Monday were up 8%. That sounds OK, but it is also 11% below corn's high from last July.Another factor: crude oil prices. The use of corn-based ethanol as an extender for U.S. gasoline supplies has kept corn and oil prices fairly closely related. It has also typically made fertilizer stocks an aggressive way to tap oil price gains.Between August 2006 and June 2008, for example, the stocks in IBD's Chemicals-Agricultural industry group staged a massive 453% rally. That corresponded precisely to a 155% run-up in U.S. oil prices during that same period.In addition, other factors amplified the 2008 fertilizer rally. For one, phosphorus rock was in comparatively short supply. Today, the links between fertilizer stocks and oil prices are somewhat weakened.As a group, fertilizer stocks on Monday traded up 24% from a June 2017 low. Crude oil prices climbed 60% during that same period.At the same time, the price of natural gas fell 10%. And nitrogen production capacity is now in relatively tight supply. Analysts project that this combination of tight supply, low raw-material costs and recovering demand is ultimately going to play in strong favor of the big fertilizer names.Susquehanna's March 28 note said the analysts remained "positive on the nitrogen cycle." The analysts continue to expect a multiyear up cycle "due to lagging global capacity growth that should be outpaced by even modest demand growth."CF's five-year dividend growth rate is 31%, although it has not raised its payout since August 2014.RELATED:Why You Want To Pay Attention To These Earnings Reports Oracle Chief Tells Trump Pentagon Cloud Plan Makes 'No Sense' Apple, Intel Lead Five Tech Titans That Just Carved This Bullish PatternÂ Â

Last week, Democrats and many in the mainstream media became highly perturbed by the Trump administration's suggestion that the United States might tie continued foreign aid to support for its agenda abroad.Foreign dictators agreed. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who spent the last year arresting dissidents, announced, "Mr. Trump, you cannot buy Turkey's democratic free will with your dollars, our decision is clear."Herein lies the great irony of the United Nations: While it's the Mos Eisley of international politicsÂ â a hive of scum and villainyÂ â and it votes repeatedly to condemn the United States and Israel, the tyrannies that constitute the body continue to oppress their own peoples.XAmong those who voted last week to condemn the U.S. for recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital and moving its embassy to Jerusalem were North Korea, Iran, Yemen and Venezuela. Why exactly should the United StatesÂ everÂ take advice from those nations seriously?We shouldn't. And we should stop sending cash to an organization that operates as a front for immoral agenda items.The United Nations spends the vast majority of its time condemning Israel: According to UN Watch, the U.N. Human Rights Council issued 135 resolutions from June 2006 to June 2016, 68 of which were against Israel; the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural OrganizationÂ onlyÂ passes resolutions against Israel; and the U.N. General Assembly issued 97 resolutions from 2012 through 2015, 83 of which targeted Israel.Meanwhile, the U.N. has done nearly nothing with regard to Syria. It has instead suggested that Israel turn over the Golan Heights to the Syrian regime. The U.N. can't even successfully prevent the slaughter of the Rohingya in Myanmar. But they certainly have something say about whether the United States ought to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital.No Hidden Agenda: Get News From A Pro-Free Market, Pro-Growth PerspectiveOne of the great lies of the Obama administration was that diplomacy is a foreign policy. We often heard from it that the only two alternatives were diplomacy and war. That was the stated reason for pursuing a one-sided nuclear deal with Iran that left Iran with burgeoning regional power and legitimacy. "What? Do you want a war or something?" it asked.But the moment that the Trump administration uses tools of diplomacy, including financial pressure, to achieve American ends, the left complains. Would it prefer war? Diplomacy is a tool, not a foreign policy, and the use of diplomacy to pressure other nations to follow our lead is not only smart but also necessary.That is why the Trump administration was exactly right to negotiate a $285 million cut to the U.N.'s budget. Now we ought to slash our contributions to the counterproductive organization, since we pay one-fifth of the total bill.The U.N. has always been a foolish fantasy, a League of Nations knockoff that's been about as productive and twice as irritating. It's an outmoded organization that's outlived whatever small usefulness it once had. There's no reason for us to continue cutting checks to prop up regimes that condemn us publicly for exercising the most basic standards of morality.Click here for moreÂ Commentary and OpinionÂ from Investor's Business Daily.Want to make more money in the stock market? Start withÂ IBD University.Â

The major market indexes looked to kick off the new week on a positive note, as the indexes gained upside momentum though early Monday morning trade. The tech-heavy Nasdaq rose 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average held gains of 0.3% each.XÂ Among the Dow industrials, Caterpillar (CAT) set the pace, advancing 1.8%. The heavy machinery firm is well extended from a 99.56 flat-base buy point.Meanwhile,Â financial components Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) gained 0.4% and 1.1%, respectively. JPMorgan is approaching a flat-base's 95.32 buy point.Leading stockÂ Nvidia (NVDA) followed through on Friday's breakout, advancing another 3.5%, and is now extended from a 174.66 flat-base buy point.Among other recent breakouts, Tesla (TSLA) looked to extend a winning streak to four trading sessions, rising 1.5%. The electric automaker is almost extended from its 370.10 buy point, but is still in the 5% buy range.FANG stocks were mixed versus the general market in the stock market today with Netflix (NFLX) leading the advance, rising over 1%.Â Amazon.com (AMZN) followed up with a gain of 0.5%, as it tries to reclaim its 50-day line. In the meantime,Â Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) eked out minor gains.Meanwhile, several big bank stocks are approaching buy points ahead of this week's Federal Reserve meeting. Investment banks Morgan Stanley (MS) and Citigroup (C) moved up 1.2% and 1.6%, respectively, early Monday. Morgan Stanley is approaching a 49 flat-base buy point, while Citigroup is breaking out above a 69.96 entry.Within the S&P 500, fertilizer namesÂ CF Industries (CF) and Mosaic (MOS)Â surged more than 8% and 5%, respectively.Within theÂ IBD 50, only a handful of names were trading in negative territory early Monday.Â Applied Materials (AMAT) was breaking out past a 47.69 cup-with-handle buy point Monday, jumping 2.3%. The chip equipment maker was upgraded from sector perform to outperform at RBC Capital.On the downside, Grubhub (GRUB) slipped 0.6%. The food delivery service is setting up to test its 10-week line for the first time since a breakout above a 47.94 flat-base buy point.RELATED:These 5 Banking Giants Are Near Buys Ahead of Key Fed DecisionDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisFed, Adobe, Fedex, Defense Giants Lead Weekly Investing Action PlanFANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, GoogleBanks And Financial Stocks: Latest News & Analysis

X The stock marketÂ moved modestly higher early Monday as theÂ major indexes and leading stocks continued their recoveries from last week's brutal sell-off.The tech-heavy Nasdaq led the indexes higher with a 0.6% rise, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average followed with gains of 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively. Volume fell on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq vs. the same timeÂ Friday.Among the Dow industrials, Boeing (BA) soared 1.2% after President Trump's busy weekend led to a set of broad-ranging deals with Saudi Arabia.Â  Blue-chip leaders 3M (MMM), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Unitedhealth Group (UNH) all advanced more than 1%.On the downside, Pfizer (PFE) and energy component Chevron (CVX) paced the decliners with falls of 1% and 0.7%, respectively.Among the S&P 500 components, leading stocks in the stock market today were casino operator Wynn Resorts (WYNN)Â and chip stock Qualcomm (QCOM), which rose 3.3% and 2.7%, respectively. At the weak end of the S&P 500, Amgen (AMGN), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Mosaic (MOS) fell more than 2% apiece.Among leading stocks, Nvidia (NVDA) and Amazon (AMZN) traded at new highs, up 1.9% and 0.9%, while Tesla (TSLA) dropped 0.7%. China-based stocks continued their recent spate of gains. Weibo (WB) and Sina (SINA) gainedÂ almost 3% each, NetEase (NTES) moved up 2.9%,Â Alibaba (BABA) rose 1.4%, and JD.com (JD) advanced 0.8%.Â Fiber-optic stocks were favored early Monday after analysts provided bullish commentary on many industry members. Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) was initiated with a buy rating at Needham & Co. and jumped 8.8%. Analyst firm Rosenblatt said Finisar (FNSR)Â may resume shipping products to China network gear maker Huawei, which sparked an 8% rise in shares. Ciena (CIEN) benefited nearly 6% from an upgrade to buyÂ from hold at Stifel Nicolaus.Chip and fiber-optic stocks dominated the top performers of theÂ IBD 50Â in midday trading. Among them, Lumentum (LITE) jumped almost 6%, while Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI) rose 4%. Life sciences software provider Veeva Systems (VEEV) moved up almost 3% to a new high ahead of its Q1 earning release on ThursdayÂ after the close.On the downside, new-issue Floor & Decor (FND) fell 2.1%; it's looking to build an IPO base after its successful IPO on April 27. Mortgage insurer Essent Group (ESNT) lost its fight for support at its 50-day line as it works on a new base. Shares fell 0.4%.RELATED:Applied Optoelectronics, Finisar Rise On Data Centers, ChinaThis Is Tesla's Model 3 Break-Even Price Point â And 5 More Surprises In New StudyWhich Sectors Are Showing The Most Strength As Market Rallies?Dow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks; News And AnalysisApple's Price Target Raised; Qualcomm, Ciena, Finish Line Upgraded

X The stock market shed gains and indexes were near session lows in late afternoon trading.The Nasdaq erased a small gain and was down 0.1%. Facebook (FB), one of its largest components, climbed to a new high. Volume was running about one-third more than normal. Volume also was well above average the previous two days, as institutional investors pile up shares of the social media company ahead of its earnings report Wednesday after the close.The S&P 500 fell 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.1% increase. Gains of more than 1% in Visa (V) and Intel (INTC) helped the industrials in today's trading. Volume was tracking higher compared with the same time yesterday.Hospital, building material, truck manufacturing and various retail industry groups led the market.Â In important stock moves, Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) broke out of a flat base, as shares climbed past the 33.63 buy point. But volume was only moderately above average. The chip foundry is part of a leading industry group that nonetheless has slipped a bit in the ranking of 197 groups. Taiwan Semi remains a group leader, with one of the highest Composite Ratings in the industry.IPG Photonics (IPGP) soared to a new high after the company beat profit estimates. Shares gapped up to a gain of more than 8% in big volume and are now extended from a breakout on April 24. IPG Photonics reported first-quarter earnings of $1.38 a share, up 50%. Sales increased 38% to $285.9 million. It forecast Q2 revenue of $320 million to $340 million and EPS of $1.50 to $1.70, both well above analysts' estimates.The agricultural chemicals industry group came under fire, with a few stocks in that group falling in heavy volume after disappointing earnings reports.Scotts Miracle-Gro (SMG) gapped down to a loss of 5% after the company's Q1 adjusted earnings of $2.78 a share missed Wall Street estimates. Scotts also announced that it agreed to sell its European and Australian consumer operations to Exponent Private Equity in a deal valued at about $250 million. The stock is now dwelling in the lower half of a saucer-type base with a 98.91 buy point.Mosaic (MOS) gapped down and lost nearly 8%, to the lowest level since November. The fertilizer company reported Q1 earnings excluding items of 4 cents a share, down 71% and below expectations. Sales of $1.58 billion were 6% lower than in the year-ago period.That drop extended a streak of year-over-year declines in the top line to seven quarters.Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) plunged more than 8%, sinking to the lows of its current pattern in big volume. The company, which is in IBD's food grains industry group, reported adjusted earnings of 60 cents a share and sales of nearly $15 billion, an increase of 4%.RELATED:Trump Infrastructure Play Soars As Earnings Top On Price HikesWhich Commodities Will Rise This Year? The Case For Gold

The stock market remained higher Monday afternoon, although stocks fell off session highs on news Russia's ambassador to Turkey was shot dead in Ankara.The Nasdaq composite led the way, rising 0.6%, helped by strength in several large-cap technology names.Apple (AAPL) rose 0.9% to 117.05. It's showing some signs of accumulation as it works on a base with a 118.79 buy point.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 added 0.3%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking well below Friday's levels in what's expected to be a quiet week of trading ahead of Christmas.Top technology gainers in the Nasdaq 100 included Lam Research (LRCX), up 3%, and Adobe Systems (ADBE) and Microsoft (MSFT), up 2% each.Inside the Dow, Walt Disney (DIS) gapped up and rose nearly 2% on a strong debut for "Rogue One" over the weekend. Don't chase it though, because it's extended from a 100.39 cup-with-handle buy point.In the stock market today, shares of Mosaic (MOS) slumped 5.4% to 27.96Â on news it's buying Vale's (VALE) fertilizer business for $2.5 billion in cash and stock. Mosiac is just below a 29.22 cup-with-handle buy point after erasing an 8% gain.On the earnings front, homebuilder Lennar (LEN) gained 1.2% to 43.94 after reporting double-digit earnings and sales growth before the open. However, when it comes to leaders and laggards in the group, Lennar is definitely the latter. Resistance has been strong lately around the 45 price level.IBD'S TAKE: For a look at some leading small-cap names in the homebuilding group, consult an IBD Stock Checkup.Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP) was a top gainer in the IBD 50, up 8% to 17.05. It's a highly profitable biotech but also on the speculative side with a market capitalization of less than $1 billion. Its lead drug is Amitiza, used to treat constipation, and Rescula, an eye drug to treat open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension.Sucampo is closing in quickly on its Nov. 30 intraday high of 17.54. A heavy-volume above that price level would be bullish.RELATED:Russian Ambassador To Turkey Assassinated In Syria RetaliationFANG Stock Pullback A Buying Opportunity: Canaccord GenuityApplied Materials Downgraded; 3 Other Chip Gear Makers Rated BuyDisney's Studio Cash Cow Continues To Moo, Even As ESPN Woes SimmerLennar Tops Q4 Earnings Views; Optimistic About Trump, Cautious On Margins

Tuesday's weak-volume session did little to influence the market's status, although the Nasdaq did edge to a fresh high and the Dow snugged nearer to the 20,000 mark.The Nasdaq swung up nearly 0.5% for the day, notching a new closing high after briefly topping 5500 in morning trade. The S&P 500 clocked a 0.2% advance, while the Dow industrials added 0.1%. Small caps and tech issues were largely in sync, with the Russell 200 also finishing 0.5% higher.Better-than-forecast October home price data and a gain of almost 2% in oil prices gave Tuesday's session a positive nudge across an array of industries, but energy and steel were leading beneficiaries.Canadian Solar (CSIQ) beamed up 6% in above-average trade, crossing back above its 50-day moving average in the process.Olympic Steel (ZEUS) popped more than 5%, although trading volume was weak. Coal minerÂ Alliance Holdings (AHGP) surged 5%, CNX Coal Resources (CNXC) swung up more than 8%, rising further above its rising 50-day line.CNX Coal was spun off by Consol Energy and debuted on July 1 at 15 a share.Apple (AAPL) outpaced its Dow peers, rising 0.8% in soft action. Shares ended a shade more than 1% below a 118.42 cup base buy point.On the downside, Nike (NKE) slipped 1.2%, still unable to gain any altitude above its 50-day moving average.Rising oil prices lifted energy stocks to many of the S&P 500's best gains. But IBD 50 stock Nvidia (NVDA) topped the S&P 500 with a 6% gain in better-than double its average volume. The move put the chipmaker 98% above the stock's 200-day moving average, and violated an upper channel line in the stock's advance. Both are technical sell signals.Among other IBD 50 stocks, LogMeIn (LOGM) popped 3% in light trade, rising to test the underside of its 50-day moving average. The stock is beginning the fifth week of a flattish consolidation.Two of the S&P 500's top advances on Tuesday came from fertilizer makers. CF Industries (CF) climbed 4%. Mosaic (MOS) gained 3%. Both advances occurred in weak trade.Watch for CF and Mosaic to potentially break out of bottoming base patterns following their long declines. CF has fallen more than 70% below a 70.32 high marked in July 2015.No significant earnings releases are due out Wednesday, and the only major release on the economic calendar is pending home sales news for November from the National Association of Realtors.RELATED:Ross, Burlington Offer Retail Havens: Investing Action PlanStock Market Today: Why Nvidia Is Surging, And Why A Correction May Be DueInvesting In Big-Cap Techs: When Did Apple First Break Out This Year?

Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) and Agrium (AGU), Canada's largest fertilizer producers, agreed to an all-share merger to create the world's largest crop-nutrient supplier with a market value of about $27 billion.The deal will give Potash Corp. shareholders 52% of the new producer, which has yet to be named, while Agrium investors will hold the rest, the companies said Monday in a joint statement. Agrium Chief Executive Officer Chuck Magro will be CEO of the combined group while Potash Corp. leader Jochen Tilk will become executive chairman. The new company will be based in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, the current location of Potash Corp.'s headquarters.It's the latest in a string of mega deals in the agricultural chemicals market announced in the past year as producers of fertilizers, pesticides and seeds struggle with low commodity prices and weak demand.Negotiations between Bayer and Monsanto (MON), the world's largest seed company, are advancing after the German company's $56 billion takeover bid. China National Chemical Corp. agreed in February to acquire Swiss pesticide maker Syngenta (SYT) for about $43 billion, while DuPont (DD) and Dow Chemical (DOW) plan to merge and then carve out a new crop-science unit.IBD'S TAKE: Bayer last week sweetened its offer for Monsanto, which has rejected earlier bids. But a deal would vault Bayer to the top of crop products overnight.Putting together Agrium and Potash Corp. will create a company that not only produces commodity fertilizer but also sells it directly to farmers through a North American network of retail stores. Potash Corp. is largely a mining company, extracting potash in underground mines, while Agrium got 77% of its revenue last year from its retail arm.In Monday's deal, described by both sides as a merger of equals, Potash Corp. investors will get 0.4 of a share in the new company for each share they own now while Agrium shareholders will get 2.23 shares. Potash Corp. gained 2.8% to $17.45 at 7:54 a.m. in premarket trading in New York while Agrium had yet to trade after closing last week at $95.21.The companies expect to generate cost savings of $500 million a year through the merger. They said they're committed to marketing group Canpotex Ltd, their joint venture with U.S. fertilizer company Mosaic (MOS) that handles all three companies' potash exports outside of North America."This is a transformational merger that creates benefits and growth opportunities that neither company could achieve alone," Agrium's Magro said. "Combining our complementary assets will enable us to serve our customers more efficiently, deliver significant operating synergies and improve our cash flows to provide capital returns and invest in growth."The deal will be implemented by a plan of arrangement under the Canada Business Corporations Act and is expected to close in mid-2017. The merged company will employ about 20,000 people and have investments in 18 countries.

Sales growth is an important gauge. But growing sales don't tell you whether a company is truly a top-shelf or bottom-rung player. And it doesn't tell you if a company might be slashing prices to move its inventory.Profit margins can add several important dimensions to your research.Sales provide capital to fuel a company's operations. Profits reveal how effectively the company achieves those sales. They also show how much muscle an outfit builds to reinvest in operations, to develop and market new products, and to offer employees incentives to innovate and excel.To gauge a company's profits, take a look at pretax margins.Pretax margins can be sliced and diced a number of ways, but they aim to show earnings, before taxes, as a percentage of overall revenue. (EBITDA, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, is a similar measure, showing a company's profitability minus the effects of accounting and financing strategies.)Margins can vary widely from industry to industry. But the ratio provides a good gauge of peer strength in any particular industry group.Among fertilizer makers, for example, CF Industries (CF) generated a 45% pretax margin in 2011. That is well above Mosaic's (MOS) 26% margin and the 13% margin for Agrium (AGU). But it lagged Terra Nitrogen (TNH), a master limited partnership thatÂ sported a 64% pretax ratio.Part of that difference is due to the companies' differing focus on nitrogen-based fertilizers. Nitrogen products have commanded somewhat higher prices this year, while the basic raw material -- natural gas -- has been unusually cheap.Agrium is more diversified, with just over a third of its pretax earnings coming from nitrogen last year. Nitrogen was more than 90% of CF Industries' pretax take, while Mosaic, on the other hand, is focused on phosphate and potassium-based fertilizers.After-tax margins help dig a little deeper. In IBD's market columns, writers frequently point out a company's margin changes on a year-over-year basis.CF's after-tax margin was 26.4% in the first quarter of 2012. That was only slightly below the fourth-quarter peak of 27.3%. Measured on year over year, CF has increased its after-tax margins in four consecutive quarters.Agrium has increased after-tax margins in eight straight quarters. Its Q1 after-tax margin was 5.7%, down sharply from 11.9% in Q4 and well below the 21.6% high notched in Q4 2008. Again, CF is on better footing.IBD's combined Sales Growth, Profit Margins and Return on Equity grade, called the SMR Rating, also incorporates margin strength. CF Industries, Agrium and Terra Nitrogen carry SMR Ratings of A. Mosaic's SMR Rating is a B.(Editor's Note: This column originally published in the July 16, 2012, edition of IBD. CF's pretax margin was 31.6% in 2015 -- by itself, a high number, yet thatÂ margin has fallen for four years in a row. In 2011, CF's pretax margin was 45.1%. Check a company's SMR Rating by going to IBD Stock Checkup, accessible under the "Research" tab at Investors.com.)

The majority of ETFs in the IBD ETF Sector Rotation index at the time of the Brexit sell-off escaped without major damage -- in particular the ones with more metals exposure.Specifically, any ETF with exposure to gold prices came out better for the wear. Gold became more attractive as a store of wealth as the surprise Brexit vote sent global bond yields plunging.Global X Silver Miners (SIL) made a new high the past week. The price of silver closely tracks that of gold, and the fund's main holdings had a good week. Shares of metals miner Fresnillo, one of Global X's major holdings, surged about 30% on the London Stock Exchange followingÂ the Brexit vote. Silver Wheaton (SLW) broke out of an ascending base to a new high. Pan American Silver (PAAS) cleared a 16.59 buy point Friday.SPDR S&P Metals & Mining (XME), one of the most gold-heavy ETFs, broke out past the 25.66 buy point of a cup-with-handle pattern.The iShares MSCI All Peru (EPU) ETF has made up all its post-Brexit losses, which were minor to begin with. The ETF, profiled in this space last week, continues to work on a new base with a 31.52 buy point. Major mining holdings in the fund, Buenaventura (BVN) and the Canadian-traded shares of Fortuna Silver Mines (FSM), are near 52-week highs.First Trust Materials (FXZ) has recouped nearly all of a 6.7% two-day plunge.Â  First Trust Materials is largely a cyclical-stock play. Other major holdings includeÂ Steel Dynamics (STLD) and fertilizer giant Mosaic (MOS). One-third of the ETF is in chemical stocks, and about 16% is in mining.PowerShares High Yield Equity Dividend Achievers Portfolio (PEY) has only minor holdings in materials, yet the ETF weathered the Brexit slide quite well. Shares dipped just below the 50-day moving average, where they started to rebound and are now close to a new high.VanEck Vectors Morningstar Wide Moat (MOAT) tumbled 7% Monday and Tuesday. The ETF -- which targets companies that Morningstar considers undervalued and which have a competitive advantage -- was hurt mainly by financials with European exposure, such as CBRE Group (CBG), Visa (V), American Express (AXP) and State Street (STT).But many of its holdings (40 companies that are pretty evenly divided in weighting) have already recuperated from the two-day slide.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. The universe from which the ETFs are selected includes the funds listed below.

Although one-third of First Trust Materials AlphaDEX ETF (FXZ) is in chemical companies, its most interesting stocks are smaller holdings in the building trades.It's in that batch that investors will find Masco (MAS), Watsco (WSO), Martin Marietta (MLM), Vulcan Materials (VMC) and other building-supply companies that have become among the best performing in the market today.Masco broke out past a 30.71 buy point in March and is near new highs after finding support at the 50-day moving average. The cabinetry maker's earnings growth ramped up 26%, 61% and 78% the past three quarters. Sales gains have been in single digits, however.Martin Marietta, a provider of asphalt, concrete and other aggregates, has surged more than 75% from its Feb. 9 low. Vulcan, another supplier to the heavy-construction industry, is at multiyear highs after an impressive climb since January. The two are growing thanks to the rise in home construction (April new home sales were at an eight-year high) and new funding for roads and bridges.Watsco has pulled back from its April high, but is holding on to most of its 2016 advance. Valspar (VAL) is another top holding, although the paint maker is being acquired by rival Sherwin-Williams. The stock soared to record highs in March on news of the deal and has been flat since then.Fastenal (FAST), a construction supply retailer, is 3.1% of the total fund. Shares are consolidating but trading below the 50-day moving average.At its core, First Trust Materials is a cyclical-stock play. Its major holdings include Dow Chemical (DOW), Steel Dynamics (STLD), fertilizer giant Mosaic (MOS) and paper producer Domtar (UFS). Although some major holdings are well off 52-week highs, it's not that they're all dogs. Dow and Steel Dynamics made big strides earlier in the year.One-third of the ETF is in chemical stocks, about 16% in mining and 15% in packaging. Building and construction companies make up a combined 18%, according to the fund's website.First Trust Materials tracks an enhanced index developed by NYSE Group that selects stocks from the Russell 1000 based on growth factors including three-, six- and 12-month price performance. Sales to price and one year sales growth are other selection factors, as well as certain valuation gauges.The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. The universe from which the ETFs are selected includes the funds listed below.

Travis Mills will sometimes begin a motivational speech by asking people to âsnap your fingers and wiggle your toes.â When they do, he tells them, âYour life isnât that bad.âThe audience knows what he means. Mills, a retired Army staff sergeant, is a rare soldier to survive a quadruple amputation.In sharing his story to inspired crowds, he isnât after sympathy. âI really say that as a joke, to show them my funny side,â he told IBD.Still, his message -- subliminal or not -- is clear: You can overcome everything. In 2012, on his third deployment to Afghanistan and leading an 82nd Airborne squad searching for weapons, he put down his rucksack in an area that supposedly was cleared of mines. It wasnât. An  improvised explosive device went off, effectively severing all his limbs and nearly killing him.Mills writes about this and much more in his newly published memoir, âTough as They Come.âMills, 29, had an all-American, Norman Rockwell, small-town upbringing in Vassar, Mich. He was big -- 6 feet 3 inches, 250 pounds when he enlisted -- and athletic, having been a three-sport starter in high school.He attended local colleges but discovered that the course he really needed wasnât offered: How Do You Pay Off Your College Debt 101. So, in early 2006, he enlisted, and though he had a choice of MOS (military occupational specialty), he decided on airborne.After extensive training, he made the cut and, along with the rest of the 82nd, deployed in January 2007 to Afghanistan's Forward Operating Base Salerno, named for the Alliesâ World War II landing in Italy in 1943.Mills had a relatively cushy 15 months, during which he never fired his rifle.He returned home in April 2008. He married his sweetheart, Kelsey Buck, in June, and the pair settled in at Fort Bragg, N.C., for a year before Travis deployed again.It happened in August 2009, when his unit was sent to Camp Stone near the Afghan city of Herat. It was dusty, dirty duty. In his year there, he took only four showers. He called home to discover that his grandmother and a beloved uncle had died, so it was a time of great pain.It also provided learning experiences, including the realization that with rank -- he was a sergeant -- comes responsibility. Though one of his men had good intentions, he disobeyed an order. The soldier had been told to stay by the squadâs truck to monitor the radio. But when a wounded Taliban fighter was being carried out of a house the unit had just attacked, he rushed to help his comrades. Leaving the radio unattended was wrong.The offender had to be disciplined, but thatâs easier said than done when the soldier is a friend and bunkmate. âYou have to take friendship out of the equation when you are in the military,â Mills said. âWe were close friends. We went through training together, but I just happened to be promoted above him. He had to be punished, either lose rank and pay, or I had to come up with something for him to do.âMills chose the lesser of the two evils and assigned the soldier to a month of -- how to put this delicately? -- burning the platoonâs poop. At first, the guilty party ranted and didnât want to listen. But Mills couldnât back down: âI needed to be able to rely on my junior NCOs. We had a few heated words, but I realized I had to step up and be the leader the situation called for.âAnother example of a lesson learned occurred when Millsâ truck broke a tire rod, leaving him and his squad stuck overnight in the middle of nowhere because no assistanceÂ was available. They had to hunker down out in the open for the night.âThe only thing I could control in that situation was my attitude,â he said. âGetting mad wasnât going to be helpful. I could either laugh or cry. I chose to laugh. We could be getting shot at. It could be snowing. We could be cold and wet. We could be locked away in a Taliban prison somewhere.âWith that new perspective, I started to laugh right there on the side of the road. Laughing became my default because I knew things could always be worse.â Indeed, help came the next day.Millsâ deployment provided him with a new perspective, a sense of accomplishment, something that he noticed particularly when he rotated home and visited Vassar. Numerous friends were still living at home with their parents. Even many of those who had graduated from school were looking for work or an internship.âIâd had adventures and stories,â he said. âIâd been in charge of a $1.5 million piece of equipment (a Humvee), and I was in charge of two people who I told when to shoot and when not to shoot. And I was 21 years old. My friends were finishing off college and werenât sure what they were going to do. I was grateful for the opportunity the Army gave me.âIn February 2012, his unit was set to return to the front. Now the father of daughter Chloe and with two deployments behind him, Travis could have opted out. But heâd selected, trained and bonded with the men for a year.âAs an NCO (noncommissioned officer), your job is to lead, protect and inspire your guys,â he said. âIf they were going overseas, there was no way Iâd let them go alone.âZachary Lewis left a cushy financial planning job to enlist. After 18 months of training to be an officer and Ranger, he joined the 82nd as a second lieutenant and Millsâ platoon leader.âI think my main thoughts leading up to and certainly during deployment was constantly thinking about the guys, wondering if youâve done everything to make sure theyâre safe,â Lewis told IBD.In that regard, said Lewis, one of his best aides was Mills, whose âbiggest asset was that he was singularly focused on getting his squad ready for combat. Nothing else mattered to him. He didnât cut any corners. He wanted all training to be realistic.âHis squad loved him, and not because he was easy on them. He was tough but never asked them to do what he wouldnât.âLewis loved Mills too: âHow you do or do not get along with your NCOs is going to dictate your successâ as a young officer.And the two hit it off. âHeâs a big jokester,â said Lewis. âI weighed 170 pounds, and heâd come in and pick me up and bear-hug me and kind of throw me around. He helped me assimilate into the platoon.âThat third deployment had Mills stationed at an outback post near Kandahar. One day, just two months after he arrived, he placed his rucksack down and ...Medics worked to stabilize him in the field, and he was evacuated to medical facilities in Afghanistan, then Germany and finally the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Washington, D.C.It was while in the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Germany that he became aware of the extent of his injuries. His initial reaction was anger. He wanted to quit and didnât want to speak to anyone, including his wife.âWhen my wife came in (to my room at Walter Reed), I didnât want to talk to her,â Mills said. âI didnât want to be a burden, for her to have to carry me. And I was afraid my little girl was going to scream when she saw me.âThat didnât happen. âShe (Kelsey) assured me we were going to get through this together,â he said.Mills soon started experiencing phantom pain from his limbs. It became so bad that he was placed in a coma via ketamine, a horse tranquilizer.When he came out of it, a number of revelations arose. For one, the pain was gone. For another, he came to realize that the disaster had a plus side. His limbs had been blown off cleanly, with no burns. He didnât require skin grafts. All he had to do was heal.Finally, he was visited by Marine Cpl. Todd Nicely, another rare quadruple amputee to survive his injuries. Nicely told Mills that his life would get better, even normal. It inspired the wounded soldier ... to get into a fight with his doctor.Mills wanted to start rehab immediately. The doctor said that it was too soon, that he had to be patient. Mills was patient -- for half an hour. Then he paged the doctor again. He paged him every half-hour for four hours until the doctor relented and let him start the arduous process.Amazingly, on June 7, 2012, less than two months after his injuries, Mills took his first steps on prostheses. By August, he was allowed to leave the hospital for several days at a time to travel home to North Carolina. The next month he participated in a five-kilometer race.In November 2013, he was so improved, his therapy ended. By then, he had decided to pay it forward. In the same way that Nicely inspired him to go on, Mills made it his mission to do the same for other wounded soldiers.âThey called me the mayor of the warrior transition building at Walter Reed,â he said.Doctors asked him to see troubled patients. He understood what they were growing through and reassured them there is a future.He noted: âYou ask yourself, 'Am I a bad person? Does God hate me? How am I going to go on with my life?â I tell them, 'Youâre not bad. You will get through this.â âMills' mission continues. He and Kelsey have formed a nonprofit, via TravisMills.org, that runs a campground near their home in Maine for wounded vets and their families, who can come and enjoy the outdoors, go fishing, have a lobster bake and even take advantage of on-site counseling.A surviving quadruple amputee.Overcame: Desire to quit.Lesson: Itâs possible to overcome the worst personal tragedies with grit.âOnce I realized it could be done and I realized there was a future for me, I wouldnât let anything or anyone stop me.â
Stocks mapped out a mixed early session in heavy volume Friday morning.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6%. The Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. The S&P 500 edged up 0.2%.
Volume powered higher on the stock market today, up 38% on the Nasdaq and 18% higher on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Thursday.

No progress is being reported in Europe, leaving eurozone markets under pressure ahead of Greece's $1.8 billion debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund. China-based stocks were under some pressure on U.S. markets in early trade after China's mainland exchanges bored steeply into a sell-off, leaving the Shanghai Composite 18.8% off its June 12 high.

Investors received positive news from the University of Michigan, which reported that its Consumer Sentiment Index rose to 96.1 in its final estimate for June. That was a nice bump up from the prior estimate of 94.6 and well above May's 90.7 tally.

In stocks, Micron Technology (MU) dived 17%, the worst loss on both the Nasdaq 100 and the S&P 500, after reporting late Thursday that its fiscal third quarter sales and earnings slipped more than expected. Management said chip prices were weak and expected to fall further, and guided Q4 revenue below consensus views. The loss drove shares to their lowest mark since November 2013.

Nike (NKE) jumped 4.5% to lead the Dow and the S&P 500. The shoe and athletic gear maker blew past fiscal fourth quarter consensus earnings and revenue forecasts. Analysts attributed a strong portion of the earnings beat to tight cost controls. The gain lifted shares to a new high, and out of buying range above a 103.89 buy point.

Agriculture equipment maker Deere (DE) rose more than 2%, and fertilizer producers led by CF Industries (CF) and Mosaic (MOS) were showing early strength as corn and wheat prices jumped on concerns that ongoing rain in the Midwest could hurt crop yields.

Hospital and managed care providers including Tenet Healthcare (THC), HCA Holdings (HCA), Humana (HUM) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) punched out early advances, apparently still figuring in value related to Thursday's Supreme Court vote on the Affordable Care Act.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Ambarella (AMBA) led the list, paring gains but still up nearly 2% as it continued to claw back ground lost in Monday's 21% sell-off. The chip developer remains down almost 10% for the week, but still extended above its last rebound from 10-week support.

On the injured list, Noah Holdings (NOAH) tumbled almost 7% in heavy trade. The Shanghai-based asset manager is now trading 24% below its mid-May high, after slipping below its 10-week line in moderate trade a week ago.Stocks mapped out a mixed early session in heavy volume Friday morning.The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6%. Natural gas futures fell by the most in 11 months in New York on speculation that moderating U.S. weather will limit demand for the heating fuel. Prices slid 9.5%, the biggest decline since Feb. 24. Temperatures from the Great Plains through Florida will be above normal over the next five days, with seasonal or higher readings through Jan. 29, saidâ¦

Stocks for a number of fertilizer makers, led by Calgary, Alberta-based Agrium (AGU) are climbing as companies raise dividends and see analysts ratchet up earnings projections for 2015.Agrium announced Jan. 22 it had raised its dividend payout ratio to 40% to 50% of free cash flow. That was up from its prior target of 25% to 35%. Saskatoon, Saskatchewan-based Potash Corp. (POT) cranked up its dividend to 38 cents per share from 35.The fertilizer industry is easy to underestimate. In reality, the trade has a bewildering number of moving parts. They start with operations to mine inputs including phosphate rock and potash, and others to refine ammonium nitrate. The supply/demand scenario of each of those strongly affects profit. So do fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.Weather, and the balance of plantings between corn, soybeans, wheat and other crops â both in the U.S. and overseas â drive demand on an annual basis. And massive supply contracts, such as the one inked Jan. 22 by Canpotex â a consortium owned by Potash Corp., Mosaic (MOS) and Agrium â provide significant visibility into exports to China and India's massive fertilizer markets.Fertilizer stocks have been reeling since a potash price crash in 2013. A Jan. 15 Goldman Sachs note maintained "a bearish view on potash pricing" for 2015, partly due to oncoming Canadian production capacity and to the end of sanctions vs. potash-rich Belarus in December. U.S. nitrogen margins "remain resilient," the note said, supported by ongoing weak natural gas prices.But the note upgraded Deerfield, Ill.-based CF Industries (CF) to buy from hold, noting prospects for a doubling of its dividend (currently $1.50 quarterly) within two years. The stock has been trading tightly and notching new highs after clearing a three-month consolidation in January.Agrium cleared an eight-week cup base on Jan. 22 with a 5% spike in heavy trade. The stock is ticking off new highs, trading 4% above the 104.03 buy point on Tuesday as it works to climb out of a two-year hole. Agrium reports its Q4 results Feb. 24.Mosaic has been climbing from an October low, decisively retaking 10- and 40-week support in the past four weeks. The stock cleared a 48.83 handle buy point Jan. 30. It remains just below an alternative buy point of 51.35. Mosaic reports its fourth-quarter results Feb. 11.
Stock futures veered unevenly lower on a heavy slate of earnings reports ahead of Wednesday's open.
Dow futures were down 30.3 points below fair market value, but had pared early losses. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 62.4 points and sliding. S&P 500 futures were also ticking lower, down 7.2 points.

This week's economic calendar finally kicks into gear at 9 a.m. ET, with the Federal Housing Finance Agency's May Housing Price Index. June existing-home sales numbers from the National Association of Realtors are due out at 10 a.m., with weekly crude oil inventories from the Energy Information Administration to follow at 10:30.

Big names were moving ahead of the open in the stock market today, with Boeing (BA) (up 1%), Microsoft (MSFT) (down 4%), Coca-Cola (KO) (up 1%) and Whirlpool (WHR) (up 2%) responding to their quarterly reports.

Apple (AAPL) grabbed the early headlines. The stock slid more than 6% in premarket trade, despite its late-Tuesday report of a better-than-forecast 44% earnings gain, a 33% surge in sales and expanded profit margins in its fiscal third quarter.

Fourth-quarter revenue guidance didn't quite measure up, however, and the company separately didn't break out sales of the new Apple Watch. Apple shares ended Tuesday just above their 50-day moving average in a shallow, two-month consolidation.
Apple suppliers were also taking an early beating, with Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) down more than 5%.

Vasco Data Security (VDSI) collapsed 9% after the company admitted in a regulatory filing released Tuesday that some of its products may have been sold into Iran via its European subsidiary and a third-party distributor.

The sale potentially violated federal rules prohibiting transactions with "proliferators of weapons of mass destruction and their supporters." Vasco shares had pulled back sharply from a late June high to test support at their 40-week moving average.
Illumina (ILMN) dimmed 9%, falling hard after reporting late Tuesday its Q2 earnings topped; revenue missed analyst consensus expectations for the first time in six years.

The maker of large-scale genetic screening equipment also raised its Q3 earnings guidance in line with projections. The stock finished Tuesday just below Monday's high and 6% above a 223.18 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Blackhawk Network (HAWK) climbed 4%. The distributor of prepaid gift cards reported late Tuesday its sales and earnings cleared analyst estimates. The IBD 50 and Leaderboard stock ended Tuesday at the top of its buying range, 4.8% above a 40.67 buy point in a cup base.

Overseas, Europe's markets were under pressure near midday. A vote in Greece was expected to pass further fiscal measures required by its recent bailout agreement with eurozone creditors, but could show declining support for Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. London's FTSE 100 showed the deepest loss among benchmark indexes, down 1%.
In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1%, while the Shanghai Composite added 0.2%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan fell 1.2% as the yen rose against the dollar.

The dollar rose up vs. the euro. Oil and gold were both down about 1%.Stock futures veered unevenly lower on a heavy slate of earnings reports ahead of Wednesday's open.Dow futures were down 30.3 points below fair market value, but had pared early losses. Norway's Yara International confirmed the talks, but said there is no guarantee that a merger will happen with Deerfield, Ill.-based CF Industries. Copper futures posted the biggest two-session drop in 28 months on signs of faltering economic growth from France to China, the world's biggest consumer of industrial metals.

On the Comex in New York, copper dropped below $3 a pound for the first time since June. French industrial production production unexpectedly dropped in January for the second straight month, and business confidence declined, separate reports showed Monday. In China, exports slid in February by the most since 2009, government data showed on March 8.

This year, copper has slumped 11%, the most among 34 commodities tracked by Bloomberg. Global consumption of the metal will trail production by 81,000 metric tons in 2014 after a deficit of 175,000 tons last year, Barclays said on Feb. 12. Shares of Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, the largest biggest publicly traded producer, have tumbled 8.2% in three sessions.

"When you have a series of data, especially covering two major economic zones as China and the European Union do, that would suggest weaker demand," Tim Evans, chief market strategist at Long Leaf Trading Group in Chicago, said.

Copper futures for May delivery dropped 1.7% to settle at $3.0315 at 1:28 p.m. ET. Earlier, the metal touched $2.9955, the lowest for a most-active contract since June 25. In two sessions, the price tumbled 5.8%, the most since Oct. 20, 2011.

Trading was 63% higher than the 100-day average, data compiled by Bloomberg show.Copper futures posted the biggest two-session drop in 28 months on signs of faltering economic growth from France to China, the world's biggest consumer of industrial metals.On the Comex in New York, copper dropped below $3 a pound for the first time since June. In two sessions, the price tumbled 5.8%, the most since Oct. 20, 2011.Trading was 63% higher than the 100-day average, data compiled by Bloomberg show.
West Texas intermediate crude dropped the most in two months and Brent oil decreased after a government report showed that U.S. inventories advanced for a seventh week.

Futures fell 1.8% in New York after the Energy Information Administration said supplies rose by 1.43 million barrels to 363.8 million last week. Refineries operated at 87.4% of capacity, down 0.6 percentage point from the prior week. Refiners are performing maintenance as they transition to summer from winter fuels. Oil also slipped on speculation that Ukraine's crisis won't disrupt shipments.WTI for April delivery dropped $1.88 to $101.45 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It was the lowest settlement since Feb. 14. Prices dropped the most since Jan. 2. The volume of all futures traded was 24% higher than the 100-day average at 3:45 p.m.Brent for April settlement declined $1.54, or 1.4%, to end the session at $107.76 a barrel on the London-based ICE Futures Europe exchange. Trading was 25% above the 100- day average.The European benchmark closed at a $6.31 premium to WTI. The spread has narrowed from a 2014 high of $14.88 on Jan. 13.Crude supplies were projected to climb 1.3 million barrels in the seven days ended Feb. 28, according to the median of nine analyst estimates in a Bloomberg survey.U.S. crude production advanced to 8.08 million barrels a day, according to the EIA, the Energy Department's statistical arm.
Stock futures edged narrowly lower ahead of Tuesday's open, despite an on-target reading for the March U.S. trade balance.
Dow futures slipped 35.5 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 9 points and S&P 500 futures unwound 5 points.

The stock market today gets started with the Nasdaq snug up against the bottom side of its 50-day moving average. A move above this level, which has capped the index's attempted uptrend for the past two weeks, would be a positive. The S&P 500 has held its 50-day line, sandwiched between that level of support and its April 4 high.

The day's brief economic calendar showed the U.S. trade deficit narrowed to $40.4 billion in March. The Commerce Department also revised February's deficit lower, to $41.9 billion from $42.3 billion. The March number was in line with analyst expectations for $40.5 billion.

The rumble of massive, international medical deals continued, with New Jersey-based Merck (MRK) announcing it would sell its consumer care business to Germany's Bayer (BAYRY) for $14.2 billion. The unit, which includes allergy medicine Claritin and decongestant Afrin, saw 70% of its sales last year in North America. A statement from Bayer said the deal would make it the largest provider of over-the-counter drugs in North America. The companies expect the deal to close late this year.
Merck shares rose a fraction in premarket trade. Bayer was flat.

Action related to earnings reports was generally mild before Tuesday's open, with Discovery Communications (DISCA), Mosaic (MOS) and Wellcare Health Group (WCG) holding relatively steady after reporting first-quarter results.

Tableau Software (DATA) popped 8% ahead of the open. The maker of business intelligence products reported a 1-cent loss, 10 cents better than analyst expectations. An 87% leap in revenue soared past estimates. The stock is 43% below its February high and 87% above its year-ago IPO price.

Avago Technologies (AVGO) added 3% after Standard & Poor's announced late Monday the Singapore-based chip designer would be listed on the S&P 500 index beginning Thursday. The stock has been in a shallow consolidation below a March 21 high.
Overseas, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index slumped 1.3% after a weak reading on April manufacturing. The Shanghai Composite ended a fraction higher. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ticked 0.2% lower.
In Europe and the U.K., major indexes carried mild losses into midday trade.

The euro rose to a seven-week high vs. the dollar ahead of Janet Yellen's testimony scheduled before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress tomorrow, and a policy decision from the European Central Bank on Thursday.

Gold nosed higher for a third day, trading just above $1,311 an ounce - up 2% since Thursday's settle. Oil continued to bob between $99 and $100 a barrel. Investors should always strive to buy leading stocks at proper buy points when the market is rising.The proper buy point is when a stock takes out the left-side high or when it clears a handle by at least 10 cents. But for more aggressive traders, sometimes it's prudent to use a lower entry.One of the easiest ways to find a lower entry point is to simply draw a trend line across the highs of a base or in a handle. The idea is to buy once the stock breaks above the trend line, which represents an area of resistance.Sometimes, using this method can get you in several points lower than the traditional left-side high buy point. It can even get you in lower than that of a handle's buy point. In this case, the difference can be small.It takes time to stalk and draw a proper trend line. But another benefit of buying stocks using the trend line is that it may prevent you from being stopped out if a shakeout occurs once the stock takes out the traditional entry.Remember, this method is more art than science. Unlike standard buy points, where you add 10 cents to a high, the precise buy point using trend lines can be hard to pinpoint.Another thing: Just because a stock breaks above a trend line does not mean that everything is good from here. You can still be prone to whipsaw action.You should generally draw trend lines on a daily chart. The downward trend line should connect at least three highs. The more points connected, the better.If the base spans many months, then investors can plot trend lines on weekly charts.Thanks to the robust demand of corn-based ethanol, fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS) went on a tear around August of 2006.In December 2006, the stock started forming what would become a nine-week consolidation. 1 The pattern was too deep for a flat base and wasn't exactly a cup with handle either.The standard buy point was 23.64. 2 Investors could have drawn a trend line from the Dec. 11 peak for an aggressive entry.Mosaic broke above the trend line Feb. 12, 2007, clearing a buy point of about 22.08 3 in nearly triple average volume. The stock rose 89% by July, then went into a highly choppy correction for two months before heading to new highs.

They wanted to make memory chips, and started with three very different technologies. One was too easy for rivals to copy. Another added too much complexity. "And the third one, using a different kind of transistor, called a MOS transistor,â¦

The long-depressed fertilizer sector got a lift Wednesday after CF Industries (CF) said it's considering a master-limited partnership, which would shield earnings from corporate taxes, and RBC Capital Markets initiated coverage on a slew of companies in the group.Deerfield, Ill.-based CF Industries said Wednesday in a filing that it's in talks with financial advisers about options, including an MLP or "MLP-like structures along with other financial options."The maker of nitrogen and phosphate fertilizers saw shares jump 10% in Wednesday afternoon trading on the stock market today.The company had been criticized by activist investor Dan Loeb, head of Third Point LLC hedge fund, for what he considered low dividend payments.In a report to investors earlier this year, Third Point said CF was trading at an "unwarranted discount" to peers, which include Potash (POT), Agrium (AGU) and Mosaic (MOS).Meanwhile, RBC Capital Markets analyst Chris Nocella initiated coverage on five fertilizer companies, including CF."CF is considered a North American nitrogen pure play with leading leverage to the U.S. agriculture market, particularly corn, and a significant nitrogen capacity expansion underway," Nocella said in a client note.He started CF, Potash and Intrepid Potash (IPI) with a sector perform (neutral) rating, and price targets of 235, 35 and 16, respectively. He also started Agrium and Mosaic at outperform (buy), with target prices of 115 and 57, respectively.Combined stock prices in IBD's Chemicals-Agricultural group have retreated this year amid a fertilizer glut and weaker demand. The group lost 24% of its value from January to Nov. 29, and mostly traded sideways until the group surged 5.4% in Wednesday afternoon trading.Follow James DeTar at Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Fertilizer provider Mosaic (MOS) broke out of a first-stage base on Oct. 8.
The buy point in the cup-with-handle pattern was 64.04. The stock has been dipping in and out of a standard 5% buying range recently.
Mosaic is benefiting from new industry conditions. Tight crop supplies have boosted prices, increasing the demand for fertilizer.

The company is well-positioned to meet that demand. In July, Mosaic invested $385 million in a phosphate rock mine in Peru. At the earnings call on Oct. 5, CEO James Prokopanko said shipments from the Peru mine had begun.

Recent quarters reflect these new conditions. After four quarters of falling revenue on a year-ago basis, sales leapt 26%, 17% and 50% the past three quarters. Earnings grew 178%, then were 89 cents a share vs. a year-earlier loss, then grew 191%.
Analysts expect earnings to grow 87% this fiscal year.
The stock's fundamentals are strong. Pretax margin was 18% in fiscal 2010 ended in May. Operating cash flow per share was 55% greater than EPS, an excellent ratio.
The Composite Rating is 98, which is unsurpassed in Mosaic's industry group. The Composite Rating combines all five IBD ratings into one number.

One risk is litigation that has halted mining at Mosaic's South Fort Meade mine in Florida. Environmental groups filed a June lawsuit that the court has yet to decide. Mosaic is seeking a partial stay to allow mining in a portion of the property until the case is decided.

James Despain of investor relations told IBD that while the court case could drag on for a couple of years, the company hopes to get a ruling on the stay by May or earlier.Fertilizer provider Mosaic (MOS) broke out of a first-stage base on Oct. 8.The buy point in the cup-with-handle pattern was 64.04. In a bid to gain an edge in the struggling fertilizer industry, Mosaic (MOS) said it will buy the Florida phosphate business of rival CF Industries (CF) for about $1.4 billion.
Mosaic will pay $1.2 billion cash and put $200 million into a fund CF Industries has set up to meet environmental requirements.
No. 2 U.S. fertilizer maker Mosaic said its acquisition of a mine and other assets from CF will enable it to boost output of the crop nutrient in Florida.
Mosaic will acquire the 22,000-acre South Pasture mine, a factory in nearby Plant City and an ammonia terminal and finished-product warehouse in Tampa.
The South Pasture plant produces about 1.8 million tons of phosphate fertilizer a year vs. Mosaic's current 8.2 million-ton total yearly phosphate output.
Additionally, CF Industries agreed to supply Mosaic with up to 1 million tons a year of key fertilizer ingredient ammonia.

Mosaic CEO James Prokopanko said combining the two units creates opportunity "for enhanced operating efficiencies and sustainability efforts, lower production costs and reduced capital investment â creating value for our shareholders, customers and employees."
Mosaic's stock was up more than 1% in Monday afternoon trading on the stock market today. CF Industries gapped up about 5% Monday afternoon.
Elsewhere in the group, Agrium (AGU), the largest fertilizer maker by revenue, Switzerland's Syngenta (SYT) and Potash (POT) were all trading higher.
The Chemicals-Agricultural group is ranked a dismal 186 on IBD's list of 197 industries amid a glut of fertilizers that has hurt prices.

Russia's Uralkali Group, the world's largest fertilizer producer, set potash stocks reeling Tuesday by pulling out of a cartel and vowing to ramp up production, a move that threatens to crash the $20 billion-a-year market.

The top six fertilizer makers control about 80% of potash production in two consortiums, analysts estimate. Uralkali, Plymouth, Minn.-based Mosaic (MOS), Canada's Agrium (AGU) and Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) have played off each other to stabilize prices for potash, one of the most commonly used ingredients for fertilizers.
Mosaic shares, which had been sinking in recent months, fell 18% Tuesday. Agrium lost 5%, Potash 16.5% and Intrepid Potash (IPI) 29%.
Stirring The Potash
Uralkali said it's ending its joint venture with Belarusian Potash Co.

Uralkali and Belarusian parent Belaruskali set up the BPC venture in 2005 to boost their market position. The Russian fertilizer giant blamed the Belarus government's decision to cancel BPC's exclusive right to export the country's potash.
Uralkali says it expects to boost its potash output to 13 million tons in 2014 from 10.5 million this year. Prices should fall significantly, CEO Vladislav Baumgertner said.
That's bad news for rival fertilizer makers, who will likely see sales and earnings fall.
It's seen as good news for farmers, who will pay lower prices for fertilizer if Belarus doesn't take action to woo Uralkali back into a partnership.

Shawn Hackett, author of the Hackett Money Flow Commodity Report, says the short-term boost could be a long-term drag for farmers. Lower fertilizer costs could encourage more plantings and boost harvest, hitting already-falling crop prices.
"Although fertilizer cost would fall, that's just one component," Hackett told IBD. "Insecticide, seeds and land rental costs won't fall much, if at all."
As a result, he said, "every farmer could have substantially lower revenue next year."
Hackett said Belarus may try to lure Uralkali back to the negotiating table: "Whenever you have governments and money, no one wants to see the pie shrink too much. Everyone wants to make money."
Anna Kolonchina, a Uralkali director, says in a statement on Uralkali's website that the board fully backs the decision.
"We view the fundamentals of the potash industry as strong and have confidence in the growth potential of this market," she said.
Meanwhile, CF Industries (CF), with less potash exposure than many peers, fell 2.5%. Swiss-based Syngenta (SYT) edged lower.

The major indexes opened nearly flat Thursday, as investors took in higher than expected readings on pending home sales and the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index.The Dow rose 0.1%, while the Nasdaq, S&P 500 and NYSE composite were all trading virtually flat. Volume fell 1% on the NYSE and rose 8% on the Nasdaq vs. the same period Wednesday.Endo Pharmaceuticals (ENDP) rose 3% on five times its normal trade. The Food and Drug Administration approved Endo's testosterone gel, used to treat men with low levels of the hormone. Endo last year licensed Fortesta from Scotland's ProStrakan Group. Endo's stock gapped above its 50-day moving average on the news.Mosaic (MOS) rose 2% on nearly four times its usual turnover. The fertilizer maker's stock broke out of a seven-week base on Wednesday, clearing a 74.35 buy point. The stock is still within range, sitting about 3% above that buy point. IBD Exclusive SeriesHope, Fear And Greed:Psychological Barriers To Successful Investing
If you have a thing against ingesting raw fish, you'll never get to savor the delicacy that is sushi.
Likewise, if you refuse to eat frog legs, you'll never find out if they really taste like chicken.
On a more serious note, investors should avoid holding deeply personal biases against certain industry groups. Doing so can lead you to miss out on what could be some monster profit opportunities.

Yes, some industries are traditionally associated with higher growth. Techs and Internets fit the bill. Such stocks do tend to be faster growing and more exciting than industries that make containers or mobile homes.
But Internet and techs are not always the groups in play; you should look for setups and strength across all industry groups.
In fact, tech highfliers were out of favor for years after the dot-com bubble popped in 2000. Chipmakers tumbled 85% from their March 2000 peak to the October 2002 low; optical gear makers lost 99%.
In recent months, chip and chip-equipment makers have returned to the front burner, thanks to demand for mobile smart devices.
On the other hand, farm equipment makers, discount retailers and steel makers aren't generally known to be market leaders. In fact, they've all held the pole position in recent years.
Changes in technology, demand for supplementary or complementary products and services, regulatory changes, price increases and material shortages can all affect an industry group's performance.
Thanks to solid global demand for steel, especially from China, producers of the metal were red-hot from 2003 to 2008.
Don't keep your focus too narrow. Opportunities can come from a wide array of industry groups.
Use the industry group table to find the best ones and those up-and-comers.
Also, read the daily IBD Industry Themes piece as well as the Industry Snapshot published each Monday.

Investors who dismissed the Chemical-Agricultural group as a pile of junk would have missed some of the best stocks in the past decade. As the chart shows, fertilizer makers started huge moves in 2004.

Potash (POT) broke out in June of that year and soared more than 1,500% in a little over four years. In August 2006, the group picked up steam again on rising demand for ethanol as an alternative fuel.

Another big winner in our study of market leaders, Mosaic (MOS), broke out in the week ended Feb. 16, 2007. The stock climbed 620% in 70 weeks. Fertilizer firms have returned to the spotlight on rocketing grain prices.

Fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS) will report second-quarter results Friday after watching its share price spike this week on a major deal.
Shares of Mosaic, Potash Corp. (POT) and Agrium (AGU) all rose sharply Monday after they jointly unveiled a deal to sell potash fertilizer to China's Sinofert Holdings.
Mosaic climbed 2.6% Monday and rose another 1.6% to 57.51 Wednesday. Potash was up about 1% in Wednesday afternoon trading and Agrium 2.6%.

Although the trio of North American fertilizer companies agreed to sell their fertilizer at a deep discount, the pact is expected to ease a potash glut and provide support to fertilizer prices after a long slide.
More deals with companies in India and China, the two biggest fertilizer buyers, are expected by summer. That could further prop up prices.
Still, 13 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Mosaic to report a 31% drop in earnings, to 97 cents a share when it reports fiscal Q2 results before the market opens Friday.
Mosaic has missed Wall Street views in three of the last five quarters.
Sales are expected to fall 15% from the same quarter last year, to $2.56 billion.

When the company reported fiscal Q1 earnings on Oct. 4, CEO James Prokopanko said results were impacted by annual maintenance shutdowns of plants that cut production, and challenges posed by hurricanes and shipping problems.
Results for the most recent period could also be hurt by Superstorm Sandy, which shut down much of the East Coast at the end of October and early November.

On Nov. 13, Mosaic cut its forecast for phosphate and potash sales, citing uncertain contracts with India and China. The lowered forecast drove its shares down 3.3% the following day to 49 a share, the lowest point since the end of June.
Its share price has since risen about 17%.
Standpoint Research said in a report Wednesday that it lowered its rating on Mosaic to hold from buy.

Sales growth is an important gauge. But growing sales don't tell you whether a company is truly a top-shelf or bottom-rung player. And it doesn't tell you if a company might be slashing prices to move its inventory.Profit margins can add several important dimensions to your research.Sales provide capital to fuel a company's operations. Profits reveal how effectively the company achieves those sales. They also show how much muscle an outfit builds to reinvest in operations, to develop and market new products, and to offer employees incentives to innovate and excel.To gauge a company's profits, take a look at pretax margins.Pretax margins can be sliced and diced a number of ways, but aim to show earnings, before taxes, as a percentage of overall revenue. (EBITDA, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, is a similar measure, showing a company's profitability minus the effects of accounting and financing strategies.)Margins can vary widely from industry to industry. But the ratio provides a good gauge of peer strength in any particular industry group.Among fertilizer makers, for example, CF Industries (CF) generated a 45% pretax margin last year. That is well above Mosaic's (MOS) 26% margin and the 13% margin for Agrium (AGU). But it lagged Terra Nitrogen (TNH), a master limited partnership which sports a 64% pretax ratio.Part of that difference is due to the companies' differing focus on nitrogen-based fertilizers. Nitrogen products have commanded somewhat higher prices this year, while the basic raw material, natural gas, has been unusually cheap.Agrium is more diversified, with just over a third of its pretax earnings coming from nitrogen last year. Nitrogen was more than 90% of CF Industries' pretax take. Mosaic, on the other hand, is focused on phosphate and potassium-based fertilizers.After-tax margins help dig a little deeper. In IBD's market columns, writers frequently point out a company's margin changes on a year-over-year basis.CF's after-tax margin was 26.4% in the first quarter. That was only slightly below the fourth-quarter peak of 27.3%. Measured on a year-over-year basis, CF has increased its after-tax margins in four consecutive quarters.Agrium has increased after-tax margins in eight straight quarters. Its Q1 after tax margin was 5.7%, down sharply from 11.9% in Q4 and well below the 21.6% high notched in Q4 2008. Again, CF is on better footing.IBD's combined Sales Growth, Profit Margins and Return on Equity grade, called the SMR Rating, also incorporates margin strength. CF Industries, Agrium and Terra Nitrogen carry SMR Ratings of A. Mosaic's SMR Rating is a B.

The past two days have been tough.
If you look at the 20 stocks in Thursday's Stocks In The News, all lost ground in the past two sessions. The median loss was 5%, which is about twice the Nasdaq's retreat.
Some of the losses were stunning.

F5 Networks (FFIV) is now 25% off its high after a quarterly revenue miss and a disappointing outlook. The network traffic gear provider shaped a square-box base recently. But it never found much volume as it tried to clear and hold above the 143.85 potential buy point.

Mosaic (MOS) jumped out of a base in 38% greater volume on Dec. 29. The breakout occurred in volume 38% above average, slightly below the 40% minimum in most valid breakouts. The fertilizer maker rose about 15% in the next three weeks.
But a news development late Tuesday blindsided Mosaic. Majority shareholder Cargill announced it was going to sell 286 million shares.
The stock dropped sharply and is now 15% off its high. It has found support at its 50-day moving average, though.
Cliffs Natural Resources (CLF) dropped 7% in the past two sessions. Volume was above average both days. Cliffs' metal ores group is top-notch in six-month price performance.
But the group recently fell under its 10-week moving average.
Trouble like this should give investors pause. You could argue that Mosaic's drop was a special situation. But the nasty reaction to F5 Networks' miss was a bad sign for the market's leadership.

Despite upbeat factory data, stocks pared gains of 1% or more to end mixed on the fourth quarter's first day. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6% and the S&P 500 climbed 0.3%. They were up as much as 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq turned a 1% gain into a 0.1% loss. A few computer-related groups fell hardâ¦
The major indexes closed with solid gains and near session highs, as turnover increased from Tuesday's levels on both the NYSE and Nasdaq.

The NYSE composite rose 0.9%. The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 pushed 0.7% higher. The Nasdaq finished above its 50-day moving average for the second day in a row, while the NYSE and S&P 500 have ended above that level for five straight sessions. Most of IBD's 197 industry groups advanced.

After the bell, Mosaic (MOS) reported earnings for its fiscal Q3 that topped analysts' forecasts. Revenue missed estimates. The fertilizer giant will host a conference call to discuss its results Thursday morning. In a news release, Mosaic said: "Record demand combined with supply uncertainties are serving to support crop nutrient markets." The stock was little changed in extended trading, after initially rising after the bell. Mosaic has regained its 10-week moving average as it etches a choppy consolidation. It has a respectable IBD Composite Rating of 88.

During the regular session, Rackspace Hosting (RAX) jumped 8% in strong volume, clearing a 40.72 buy point from a cup base. The stock finished 6% past that level, meaning it's no longer in a proper buying range. Rackspace, which has a 96 Composite Rating, provides dedicated server hosting and other services.

Tal International (TAL) tacked on 6% in huge trade. The provider of freight containers broke out past a 37.33 buy point from a square-box base last Thursday, but it ended the day below that level and pulled back through Tuesday. On Wednesday, Tal moved back above 37.33. It has a 97 Composite Rating.

Among the companies expected to report earnings Thursday are Lawson Software (LWSN), Robbins & Myers (RBN) and CarMax (KMX). The day's economic news will include the March reading for the Chicago purchasing managers index, as well as February data for factory orders.
