Stocks frittered their early gains Friday amid fresh earnings reports by corporate giants GE (GE) and Bank of America (BAC).
GE gapped up 5% after beating Wall Street's expectations. It's now less than 1% below its 52-week high of 19.70.

The Nasdaq, up as much as 0.7% after 30 minutes of trading, faded to a gain of less than 0.1%. The Nasdaq lost 2.2% over the prior two sessions. The NYSE and the S&P 500 continued to outperform, up 0.5% and 0.4% respectively. But they too pulled back from early-morning highs. Volume was running lower on the Nasdaq despite the expiration of January options and futures.

Polycom (PLCM) jumped 17% in soaring volume. The videoconferencing gear maker busted out of a seven-month consolidation in October and has rallied 32% past a 34.24 buy point. An investor might have been able to find an earlier entry point by drawing a trend line across the highs from the base's left side.

Polycom posted a 48% increase in fourth-quarter earnings late Thursday. This marked a third straight quarter of EPS growth acceleration (from 7% in the March 2010 quarter to 17% and 23%). Sales picked up 27%, a fourth straight quarter of 23% or faster sales growth.

Mosaic (MOS) recouped some of its two-day 15% slide with a 3% rebound, with volume tracking nearly four times its usual level. The phosphate fertilizer firm is back near a 74.35 buy point in a six-week base that sits atop a longer, deeper cup pattern. Mosaic has a 97 Composite Rating and a B- for Accumulation/Distribution.

BofA bounced off early-morning lows but continued to spin its wheels as it fought to hold above its downtrending 200-day moving average. The banking giant, which merged with troubled brokerage Merrill Lynch in 2008, reported a loss of 16 cents a share, missing the consensus forecast for an 18-cents-per-share profit. Revenue fell 11% to $22.4 billion. The stock has a poor 43 Relative Price Strength Rating, meaning it's outperformed only 43% of all stocks in IBD's database in the past 12 months. In the 23-member Banks-Money Center industry group, no stock has an RS Rating of 80 or higher.

In the broader market, computer networking, fertilizers and fiber-optics rebounded after Thursday's pounding. All three industry groups were ranked within the top 20 of 197 groups in IBD's six-month performance rankings as of Friday's IBD. Stock futures signaled a lower open Wednesday following the prior session's rebound.
Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq futures were all down ahead of the bell.
On Tuesday Wall Street recorded its biggest one-day gain since May 2010 in a volatile day of trading, despite ongoing fears about the economy.
A Reuters poll said economists figure there's a one-in-three chance the U.S will have another recession, which means the Fed might launch another round of monetary easing.
Elsewhere, gold prices remained near a record high $1,778 an ounce.
On the corporate front, Macy's (M) logged second-quarter earnings 55 cents a share, up from 35 cents the prior year and a nickel above views.
Disney (DIS) also beat earnings and sales estimates, thanks in part to strong results from ESPN and its theme-park division.

Overseas, Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 1.05% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed 2.34%. The major indexes held steady Monday with big opening-day gains after a lunchtime pullback.The Nasdaq rose 1.5%; it was up as much as 1.9% at around 11:40 a.m. ET. The S&P 500 rallied 1.3% and the NYSE composite gained 1.1% as volume continued at a stronger pace than Friday's light session.Mosaic (MOS) eased sharply from its intraday highs but still gained 0.1%. The Plymouth, Minn.-based phosphate and potash fertilizer supplier cleared a seven-week flat base with a 74.35 buy point. Stocks in the Chemicals-Agriculture industry group got a boost following a Reuters report that floods in Australia hampered grain shipments, which could further restrict the global supply. Group mate Potash(POT) jumped 3% to a 52-week high in low volume.Tech stocks that led in 2010 got off to a great start. ARM Holdings (ARMH), whose chip designs go into smartphones and portable computing devices such as the iPad, added 2% in above-average trade and notched a new high. It gained 3% Friday and is now 9% extended past a 19.38 buy point in a 12-week cup with handle.Cloud computing and server virtualization firm VMware (VMW) ramped up 6% to a new high. The stock surpassed a 92.05 cup-with-high handle buy point. It had trouble getting past 90 in the past three weeks. VMware has a 98 Composite Rating and is part of the No. 37 Computer Software-Specialty Enterprise industry group as of Monday's IBD. Its most recent base is a later stage base after staging breakouts in late August 2009 and February 2010.

Stocks stumbled to new session lows as the dollar gained steam in afternoon trading Tuesday.The NYSE composite lost 0.7% and the S&P 500 0.6%. The Dow and Nasdaq fell 0.5% each. Volume continued to track sharply higher across the board. Decliners beat advancers by 2-to-1 on both exchanges.HHGregg (HGG) tumbled 10% in huge volume, slicing its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Before the open, the consumer electronics retailer reported lower fiscal Q2 earnings that missed views. Sales grew 45%, but also missed analysts' estimates. And the company cut its full-year profit outlook to a range of $1.30 to $1.45 a share vs. views of $1.43.China New Borun (BORN) reversed opening gains and dived 10% in heavy trading. The reversal erased nearly all of Monday's work. The stock is still trading above its 10-week moving average. The alcohol producer announced that two of its board members resigned. China New Borun reports earnings Nov. 16. Analysts see profit rising 17% to 35 cents a share. It had previously delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit growth.On the upside, agriculture-related stocks gained after a government report cut crop estimates. Corn, cotton and soybean prices jumped.Lindsay Manufacturing (LNN)rallied 6% to a two-year high. That puts it 48% past a 44.81 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The company makes irrigation systems. It recently trounced views with a 182% surge in Q3 earnings.Fertilizer producer Mosaic (MOS) climbed 4% in fast trade. It's now 15% past a 64.04 buy point from a deep cup-with-handle base.Elsewhere, gold ended about $14 off its fresh record high. The December contract gained $7.10 to $1,410.30 an ounce.

Stocks remained near session highs Tuesday afternoon after dismissing S&P's downgrade of Italy and mixed housing data. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 rose 1.2% each, while the Nasdaq climbed 0.8%. Turnover was tracking lower across the board. Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) bolted 5% in fast trade to a new high. It's now 6% past a 68.74 buy pointâ¦

Stocks were again off session lows, but remained stuck in the red in late trading Monday.The Nasdaq fell 1.2%, NYSE composite 1.1%, S&P 500 1% and Dow 0.9%. Turnover was again tracking lower across the board.Cyberonics (CYBX) tumbled 7% in fast trade. The stock passed a 25.08 buy point from a double-bottom base Sept. 24 on weak volume. Monday's downturn has erased the bulk of its recent gains.VMware (VMW) dropped 4% in heavy trading. That puts the stock 6% below an 87.26 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern cleared Sept. 20. But the stock appeared to have found support at its 50-day moving average.Lexmark International (LXK) lost 4% on a downgrade. Citing valuation, Barclay's Capital cut the printer maker to equal weight from overweight. Despite the hit, the stock still sits 9% past a 39.48 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Mosaic (MOS) fell 2% ahead of its fiscal Q1 results after the close. Analysts see the fertilizer producer's earnings surging 213% to 72 cents a share. Sales area slated to jump 35% to $1.973 billion.

Stocks rallied off late-morning lows Thursday and resumed their upward trend.The Nasdaq gained 0.6% and traded near session highs. The S&P 500 edged up 0.2%, still off its high, and the NYSE composite rose 0.1%. Volume continued to track mildly lower on both main exchanges.Riverbed Technology (RVBD) rebounded for a second straight session, rising 2% and briefly reclaiming its 50-day moving average. Volume was running at 57% faster than its usual pace. After a fantastic run-up in 2010, Riverbed is clearly wrestling with its first authentic correction since last summer. The specialist in optimizing the speed of wide-area computer networks reports Q4 earnings after the close. Analysts see profit up 64% at 18 cents a share on a 41% jump in sales to $158.6 million.Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) retracted from its high of 178.71 earlier today but was still up 3% in heavy volume. The phosphate fertilizer giant has gained 13% since clearing a 153.39 buy point in a long, flat-base-like consolidation. Its Chemicals-Agricultural industry group ranked a solid 25th among 197 IBD industry groups as of Thursday's IBD.Mosaic (MOS) surrendered all of its early gains but remained nearly 6% above a recent 74.35 buy point. The stock's recent action has been highly volatile, however, as indicated by its 1.12 beta reading. (Beta readings can be found on the weekly chart of MarketSmith, an IBD-affiliated research tool.)Greenhill (GHL), a relatively new investment bank that went public in May 2004, gapped below its 50- and 200-day moving averages in soaring volume. It fell 11% and dived beneath recent lows near 74. The stock had been forming a long cup base since May of last year, though it's been a laggard the past few years.New York-based Greenhill reported a Q4 profit of 6 cents a share, down from 57 cents a year ago and way below Thomson Reuters' 52-cent consensus estimate. Expenses jumped 39% despite a 7% decline in revenue. Greenhill's revenue record has indeed been spotty, rising from year-ago levels just twice in the past five quarters.
Stocks headed mostly lower in light trading Wednesday as investors digested mixed economic data and a wave of fourth-quarter earnings reports.

The Nasdaq slipped 0.4%. The NYSE composite and the S&P 500 each dipped 0.2%. The Dow held on to a 0.2% gain. Volume was 11% lower on the Nasdaq and down 30% on the NYSE compared with the same time Tuesday.
Goldman Sachs  (GS) slipped 3% in early trade, after reporting fourth-quarter earnings down 53%, to $3.79 a share. That topped analysts' consensus of $3.76. Revenue missed expectations.

Shares of fertilizer producer Mosaic (MOS) tumbled 6%. Privately held agriculture giant Cargill said late Tuesday that it would divest its 286 million shares, about 64% ownership, in the company. Mosaic was created in a 2004 merger between Cargill's crop nutrition division and IMC Global.

Adtran (ADTN) gapped up to a 5% gain in powerful trading. The optical networking equipment maker late Tuesday topped fourth-quarter expectations. The stock hit a new high, 14% above a 36.95 buy point following the Jan. 6 breakout from a two-month cup base. MKM Partners initiated coverage of the stock on Tuesday with a buy rating.

Chip equipment maker Cree (CREE) plummeted 13% in massive trade. The company reported fiscal Q2 earnings of 55 cents a share, below views of 58 cents. Revenue rose 29% to $257 million, below estimates of $276.6 million.Â Distribution had picked up sharply the past several days as the stock built a handle on the possible base. One thing to look for in a market correction is the stock that resets its base count.

A stock does this when the low in its base undercuts the low of the previous base. This is important because a reset results in a first-stage base. First- and second-stage bases have a better record for successful breakouts.
A handful of stocks that appeared recently in the Stocks In The News screen have wiped clean the base count.

Priceline (PCLN) is extended, but the base it formed from April to August undercut the previous low and reset the count. The online travel services provider broke out in August and then formed and cleared a short-stroke pattern.
If Priceline were to form a new base, it would only be a stage two.

The low Mosaic (MOS) hit in July while shaping a base also reset the base count. The fertilizer maker broke out of the first-stage base on Oct. 8, and is now finding support at its 10-week moving average.
BHP Billiton (BBL) began work on a long base in April and undercut the previous base's low. The Australian mining company cleared the first-stage base and is becoming extended from its buy point.
Coal producer Walter Energy (WLT) undercut the low of its previous base after beginning a new base in April. The potential buy point is 99.55, unless it carves a handle.

Keep two things in mind, however. First, with the market in correction it's best not to be buying any stocks, no matter how good the chart looks. Second, review the fundamentals before putting a stock on your watch list. The major indexes opened narrowly mixed Friday, as a disappointing jobs report refueled expectations that the Federal Reserve would step in to assist the sluggish economy.The NYSE composite rose 0.3%, the S&P 500 and Dow gained 0.2% each. On the downside, the Nasdaq shed 0.1%. Volume fell 13% on the NYSE and rose 21% on the Nasdaq vs. the same period Thursday.Mosaic (MOS) and Agrium (AGU) both gapped up 6% in fast trade. The fertilizer makers soared after the Agriculture Department cut its estimate of the nation's corn production by 3.8%.On the downside, F5 Networks (FFIV) tumbled 6% in heavy volume. A Goldman Sachs analyst cut her rating on the network technology firm to sell from neutral and hacked her price target on the stock. F5 slashed through its 50-day moving average and has plunged 17% from its Tuesday high.Adobe Systems (ADBE) also skidded 6% in rapid turnover. The publishing software maker is giving back some of the 12% gain it seized Thursday following a report that Microsoft might try to buy the company.

Stock futures pointed sharply higher ahead of Thursday's open, as the dollar fell and overseas markets showed firm gains. Dow futures were up 122 points, slightly below their earlier highs. S&P 500 futures held a 16-point gain and Nasdaq 100 futures were 26.25 points ahead. A large portion of action on the stock market today will be in response toâ¦

Fertilizer stocks should have benefited from an Agriculture Department report that said supplies of corn and soybeans will likely remain tight for the foreseeable future. The higher prices seen for corn and beans should encourage expanded acreage here and, especially, abroad. More acres planted means more demand for fertilizer. Things don't always play out as you think they should. Thursday'sâ¦
IBD Exclusive SeriesHope, Fear And Greed:Psychological Barriers To Successful Investing
Whether you're a limo driver or a soccer mom (or dad), you don't think about touching the brakes when you approach a stop sign. You're trained to do it. So you do.
Why, then, do we sometimes have trouble pressing the accelerator pedal in our portfolio when the market says "Go"?
Our thinking often gets in the way of what we should be doing. Thinking is good, but it ultimately doesn't bring big gains to your portfolio. Taking action at the right time is key.

If a major stock average posts a follow-through after a sharp decline, it signals a new uptrend is under way. A true change in market character is critical, since three of four growth stocks track the market's general direction.
That's not all. IBD's research has found that the most powerful winners tend to break out to new highs just days or weeks after a solid follow-through takes place.
Of course, it can feel scary to begin buying at this point. You might have gotten burned by your last few trades. You might think, well, the news has been so grim, it's not going to get better soon.
Yet that's the wicked genius of the market: It moves counter to most people's expectations.

William O'Neil confirmed this fact at a recent IBD Meetup gathering in Los Angeles. The IBD founder and chairman asked how many people had read in IBD's Big Picture that the Nasdaq and other indexes posted a follow-through on Sept. 1. Scores of hands shot up.
O'Neil then asked how many readers immediately bought stocks.
Virtually no one did.
Certainly, not every follow-through works. But every major market bottom since 1900 had one. If you wait too long after this key signal, the opportunity costs grow.

After moving like a bucking bronco for months, the Nasdaq gained 1.7% on Aug. 27 last year â a nice way to begin a new advance 1. Three days later, a follow-through came as the Nasdaq rose 3% in higher volume 2. A new bull run was born, and winning stocks began to move.

On Sept. 2, EZchip Semiconductor (EZCH) surged 6% to new highs. It had pulled back near a breakout point. IBD's Stocks On The Move table highlighted it on Sept. 3. Fertilizer producer Mosaic (MOS) hopped out of a deep cup with handle Oct. 8. It's gained 34%, vs. a 12% advance by the NYSE composite over the same period.

Other leaders supplied new entry points. Priceline.com (PCLN) dipped near its 10-week moving average for the first time since its August breakout, then ended the week higher. It sailed ahead 30% in three months and is up 94% from a 234.55 cup-with-handle buy point.

Of course, it can feel scary to begin buying at this point. You might have gotten burned by your last few trades. You might think, well, the news has been so grim, it's not going to get better soon.
Yet that's the wicked genius of the market: It moves counter to most people's expectations.

William O'Neil confirmed this fact at a recent IBD Meetup gathering in Los Angeles. The IBD founder and chairman asked how many people had read in IBD's Big Picture that the Nasdaq and other indexes posted a follow-through on Sept. 1. Scores of hands shot up.
O'Neil then asked how many readers immediately bought stocks.
Virtually no one did.
Certainly, not every follow-through works. But every major market bottom since 1900 had one. If you wait too long after this key signal, the opportunity costs grow.

After moving like a bucking bronco for months, the Nasdaq gained 1.7% on Aug. 27 last year â a nice way to begin a new advance 1. Three days later, a follow-through came as the Nasdaq rose 3% in higher volume 2. A new bull run was born, and winning stocks began to move.

On Sept. 2, EZchip Semiconductor (EZCH) surged 6% to new highs. It had pulled back near a breakout point. IBD's Stocks On The Move table highlighted it on Sept. 3. Fertilizer producer Mosaic (MOS) hopped out of a deep cup with handle Oct. 8. It's gained 34%, vs. a 12% advance by the NYSE composite over the same period.

Other leaders supplied new entry points. Priceline.com (PCLN) dipped near its 10-week moving average for the first time since its August breakout, then ended the week higher. It sailed ahead 30% in three months and is up 94% from a 234.55 cup-with-handle buy point.Whether you're a limo driver or a soccer mom (or dad), you don't think about touching the brakes when you approach a stop sign. You're trained to do it. So you do.Why, then, do we sometimes have trouble pressing the accelerator pedal in our portfolio when the market says "Go"?Our thinking often gets in the way of what we should be doing. Thinking is good, but it ultimately doesn't bring big gains to your portfolio. Taking action at the right time is key.If a major stock average posts a follow-through after a sharp decline, it signals a new uptrend is under way. A true change in market character is critical, since three of four growth stocks track the market's general direction.That's not all. IBD's research has found that the most powerful winners tend to break out to new highs just days or weeks after a solid follow-through takes place.Of course, it can feel scary to begin buying at this point. You might have gotten burned by your last few trades. Techs led and indexes turned higher by lunchtime Wednesday after absorbing light morning losses.

The market opened mildly lower despite ADP's strong December private employment sector report (297,000 jobs added) and a better-than-expected December service sector reading (57.1 vs. 55 in November) by the Institute for Supply Management.

The Nasdaq, down 0.3% early, rallied 0.6% by late-morning trading. The S&P 500, bolstered by strength in its software, chip and some financial components, edged ahead 0.3%. The NYSE composite was marginally higher. Volume was pacing higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE.

ARM Holdings (ARMH) surged 5% to new highs, and was on track to post its fourth-straight gain. Volume was running near five times its average levels. The designer of chips for smart phones, tablet PCs and other mobile electronic devices is now up 13% from a 19.38 cup-with-handle buy point. The U.K.-based firm broke out on Dec. 21.

Mosaic (MOS), a leading maker of potash and phosphate fertilizers, rallied nearly 2% in rapid turnover. It erased Tuesday's losses and was trading 3% above a 74.35 buy point in a six-week consolidation. Late Tuesday, the Plymouth, Minn.-based firm reported a 216% jump in November fiscal second-quarter earnings to $1.01 a share, smashing views. Sales grew 56%, notching a second straight quarter of accelerating growth.

Software stocks continued to post a strong new year's start. Autodesk (ADSK) ran ahead 6% to a multiyear high in heavy trading. The industrial design software tool expert broke out of a six-month cup with handle at 33.70 in mid-October and has gained 19%. The stock tested its 10-week line in November. Its double-digit profit and revenue growth in the past three quarters (after five straight periods of deflating results) symbolize the stock's turnaround.

On the downside, Family Dollar Stores (FDO) gapped down 8% as more than 5 million shares already traded hands. Its daily average is 1.67 million shares. The Matthews, N.C.-based deep-discount retailer missed expectations with its November fiscal first-quarter profit of 58 cents a share. Higher freight costs hurt gross margin. Family Dollar, which prices most of its items below $10, also forecast February Q2 profit at $0.92-$0.97 a share, vs. the Thomson Reuters estimate of $1.00 a share.Techs led and indexes turned higher by lunchtime Wednesday after absorbing light morning losses.The market opened mildly lower despite ADP's strong December private employment sector report (297,000 jobs added) and a better-than-expected December service sector reading (57.1 vs. 55 in November) by the Institute for Supply Management.The Nasdaq, down 0.3% early, rallied 0.6% by late-morning trading. The major indexes remained positive but pulled back from session highs in midafternoon action, with the Chemicals-Agricultural industry group performing the best out of IBD's 197 groups.The NYSE composite added 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Dow both tacked on 0.3%. The Nasdaq composite rose 0.2%. Volume continued to track lower across the board.Agrium (AGU), Mosaic (MOS) and Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) were among the top-rated ag-chemicals stocks that were up in above-average turnover.Agrium gained 5% in big trade. The Canadian fertilizer maker cleared an 89.79 buy point from a cup base. The stock found support at its 10-week moving average as it etched its eight-week base.Mosaic advanced 5%. The Minnesota-based fertilizer producer moved past a 74.35 buy point in above-average volume. Like Agrium, the stock found support at its 10-week line as it formed its base.Potash rose 6% as it broke out also. The Canadian fertilizer maker climbed above a 153.39 buy point from a flat base that dates to August.The fertilizer rally came after bullish comments by Alberto Weisser, CEO of agribusiness giant Bunge  (BG). He told the Financial Times that grain prices could remain high well into 2011.

Fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS)Â beat analysts' fiscal second-quarter earnings estimates.Â  But international distributors delayed purchases, and it said it expects lower profit margins this quarter. But shares rose nearly 3% in intraday trading Friday. The company's gain was in sync with the recent upward movement for the Chemicals-Agricultural group, and came in the wake of a deal Mosaic, Potash Corp. (POT)â¦

A handful of foreign fertilizer stocks are shaping bases amid expectations that farmers will boost production due to a weaker-than-expected corn harvest this year.The Agriculture Department said Wednesday that this year's corn harvest will fall 12% below June's forecast for a record crop. It also slashed its outlook for inventories next year by 37% amid a drought in the Midwest.It's not clear just how much production will rise, given that the department also cut its outlook for demand due to a 40% jump in corn prices this year.Fertilizer stocks have been rising with the price of corn, which is the biggest U.S. crop and usually requires the most fertilizer to grow.Canada-based Agrium (AGU) may be forming a handle after it broke out above a 90 buy point July 3 in light volume. The stock has since slipped back below the buy point.Agrium's 94 Composite Rating is by far the highest among non-U.S. fertilizer makers in the Chemicals-Agricultural industry group.Weak fundamentals are a reason the group's ranking stood at just 93 out of the 197 groups as of Wednesday's IBD.Agrium's base has shown tight action , and it shows signs of accumulation.Like its competitors, Agrium's Accumulation-Distribution Rating has risen sharply in the past month, a sign that fund managers are starting to take an interest in these stocks despite weak sales and profit growth rates. Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) and Mosaic (MOS), two other Canadian fertilizer makers, are working on cup-type bases, though each has formed mostly below key support lines.Potash is shaping its base within a much larger consolidation and is about 30% from its 52-week high.Mosaic also is forming a pattern inside a long consolidation.Like Agrium, the Accumulation-Distribution Ratings of Potash and Mosaic are pointing to healthy investor demand. However, Potash and Mosaic have low Composite Ratings of 56 and 28, reflecting weak fundamentals.Switzerland's Syngenta (SYT) is forming a tightly shaped base. In this case, the pattern is developing much closer to new highs. Its earnings rose 11% and 52% in the past two six-month periods.Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile's (SQM) earnings gains ranged from 25% to 50% the past four quarters. The stock is basing.

Stocks were modestly lower near midday Tuesday after lifting off new session lows. Still equities came under pressure as Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke's testimony before Capitol Hill gave no hints of additional stimulus, which offset a round of better-than-expected economic data and earnings reports. The Nasdaq pared a 0.9% loss to 0.4%. It found support at its 50-day line. Theâ¦

Farmers tend to be plain-spoken and often understated people. But the farm business lately has become one of superlatives. Farm incomes spiked to record highs in the past two years, despite the nation being mired in a molasses economy. This year, market conditions coaxed U.S. farmers to plant an estimated 96 million acres of corn, shattering a World War II-eraâ¦

Dow Chemical (DOW) raised its quarterly dividend 28% to 32 cents per share from 25 cents. The dividend hike comes on the heels of an April 2 announcement that it would cut jobs and close plants to save money.

"Looking ahead, we are confident in our ability to continue to achieve higher and more sustainable earnings, and today's announcement demonstrates our commitment to increasingly reward shareholders as we grow," said CEO Andrew Liveris.

The largest chemical producer in the U.S. estimates it will save $250 million annually with its proposed cost-cutting plans. Dow will cut 900 jobs as it closes four plants in Portugal, Hungary, Brazil and Charleston, Ill. It will idle a fifth factory in the Netherlands due to the weakened European economy.
Dow has historically been hit hard by poor economic conditions. During the 2008 economic crisis, Dow cut over 10,000 jobs. It now has 52,000 employees on its payroll worldwide.
Dow shares rose 1.8% to 33.25 in early-afternoon trade, bucking a market sell-off.
Companies paying higher dividends have been a recent trend.
Three-fourths of S&P 500 dividend-paying companies have increased their dividend this year vs. 2011, according to the AP.

Colgate-Palmolive (CL) raised its dividend 7% to 62 cents per share vs. 58. TJX Cos. (TJX) upped its dividend 21% to 11.5 cents per share and Mosaic (MOS) increased its dividend 150% to 12.5 cents per share.
Companies are issuing new dividends as well.

Apple (AAPL) announced last month that it would issue its first dividend in more than 10 years.Dow Chemical (DOW) raised its quarterly dividend 28% to 32 cents per share from 25 cents. (TJX) upped its dividend 21% to 11.5 cents per share and Mosaic (MOS) increased its dividend 150% to 12.5 cents per share.Companies are issuing new dividends as well.Apple (AAPL) announced last month that it would issue its first dividend in more than 10 years.
Monsanto (MON) hopes the Agriculture Department's summer weather forecast is on the mark.

On June 19, the agency said it expects hot and dry weather will trim corn and soybean output. That could raise prices, giving a boost to agriculture-related businesses like Monsanto. Corn futures shot up 7% on Monday on those concerns.
The world's largest seed company will report fiscal third-quarter results before the market opens Wednesday.

Monsanto shares fell 0.7% on Monday. Meanwhile, fertilizer makers rallied as an analyst upgraded CF Industries (CF), Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) and others on the possible upside from dry weather. CF climbed 1.7% and POT 2.4. Terra Nitrogen (TNH) shares sprouted 3.2% and Mosaic (MOS) 1%.

"We continue to see strong long-term growth potential for our business," Chief Financial Officer Pierre Courduroux said earlier this month, after the company announced a new share buyback plan and a 30-cent-per-share dividend.
Favorable weather conditions in the U.S. and Brazil â which recently raised its production estimate for the 2011-12 year to a record 69 million metric tons of corn â could help.

A House committee last week voted to let farmers continue to use genetically modified crops as part of the next big agricultural spending bill. Environmental lawsuits and a 2009 San Francisco judge's court ruling have delayed or invalidated the USDA's GM crop approvals.
Monsanto is a leading seller of genetically modified seed. It also sells Roundup and other herbicides.

Wall Street expects Q3 EPS to rise 27% vs. the same quarter last year, to $1.60. Revenue is projected to climb 11.3% to $3.996 billion. Monsanto has beaten analyst estimates in five of the last six quarters.

Some of the upside may already be built into Monsanto's numbers, though. On May 30, the firm raised its profit guidance. It guided Q3 profit at $1.57-$1.62 per share, well ahead of the Street's view at the time of $1.29.
For the full year, it hiked its 2012 EPS outlook to $3.65 to $3.70 from $3.49-$3.54. Analysts expected $3.56, a view that has since been lifted to $3.70.

Last Thursday, Monsanto completed the purchase of planting technology developer Precision Planting for up to $250 million, a $210 million upfront payment, plus a possible performance-based payment of up to $40 million.

Also during the quarter, the company announced a three-year, $1 billion share repurchase plan, effective July 1. The program kicks in when the previous $1 billion buyback is completed.Monsanto (MON) hopes the Agriculture Department's summer weather forecast is on the mark.On June 19, the agency said it expects hot and dry weather will trim corn and soybean output. Big Blue, which climbed past a base on base on July 1, was one of a few companies that were up after the bell on earnings news.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose moderately after the company reported a profit of $1.60 a share, above expectations. The casino company cleared a pattern on July 7 and hit a new high Monday despite light volume on the breakout. Mosaic (MOS) traded erratically, but was still up after its profit report. The stock remains deep in a correction.

That was a bit of bright news after the market sold off Monday. The NYSE fell 1.1%, the Nasdaq 0.9% and the S&P 500 0.8%. The Nasdaq closed in the upper half of its trading range. Small caps were weaker: the Russell 2000 slid 1.4%.
Volume was quiet, according to unconfirmed data.
On Tuesday, earnings reports are expected from headliners such as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Polaris (PII), Apple (AAPL), VMware (VMW) and Riverbed (RVBD).
The latest report on existing home sales highlights the economic calendar Tuesday. It will be out before the opening bell.

The alarming global shortage of grains has sent corn, bean and wheat prices flying. Farmers are scrambling to put more acres under production. And what do you need to grow more crops? Fertilizer. Santiago, Chile-based Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile (SQM) seems poised to tap into the global push for more food output. The company supplies fertilizers and specialtyâ¦

The people of the Middle East have held the world riveted recently as they take to the streets demanding freedom and democracy. Not all that unrest has revolved around exalted ideals. Empty stomachs have also had a say. Rising food prices helped incite protests that rolled through Tunisia, beginning in December, and more recently rocked Algeria and Jordan. Food priceâ¦

Stocks climbed in midday trade Monday, but volume remained quiet.The Nasdaq was up 0.8%, the NYSE composite 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.5%. Volume was well below Friday's pace, suggesting that institutional investors were on the sidelines.The technology sector continued its recent struggles. Coal, steel and agriculture did well.Fertilizer provider Mosaic (MOS) bounced 4% in double its usual trade. Funds have raised their stake in the past two quarters. Mosaic is 11% off its high after plunging last week, but it has found support at its 50-day moving average.Apple (AAPL) added 2% in twice its routine volume. The computer and communication device maker has found support just above its 50-day line. The stock is 3% past a 321.40 buy point resulting from a pullback to the 50-day line.On the downside, technology leaders Aruba Networks (ARUN) and F5 Networks (FFIV) slid further below their 50-day lines. Each has suffered some pretty significant chart damage recently, undoing positive-looking patterns. Aruba is now 15% below the 24.38 buy point from a cup without handle. F5 is showing no sign of a rebound from Thursday's 21% plunge.Among widely held blue chips, IBM (IBM) continued to show strength. Big Blue rose 1.5% in fast trade. The stock is 7% past a 147.63 buy point after clearing a flat base this month. IBM has a Composite Rating of 89, putting it above all but 11% of the market. The Composite Rating combines all five IBD Ratings into one number.

Stocks retreated in early trading Monday as European debt worries rekindled. Portugal is facing rising pressure to accept a bailout while yields on Spanish, Italian and Greek debt climbed.The NYSE composite dropped 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.6% and the Nasdaq 0.5%. Volume was tracking marginally higher on both exchanges.Endo Pharmaceuticals (ENDP) gapped down and dropped nearly 6% to a three-month low. Late Friday, the Food and Drug Administration rejected the drugmaker's formula for a painkiller. The stock had been trading in a flat base.Radiant Systems (RADS) fell further below its 50-day moving average, which was breached Friday. Shares gapped down and lost 4% in fast trade. The company is a maker of point-of-sales systems. Its earnings grew 21% to 61% in the past four quarters, but analysts see profit falling 7% in the current quarter.Agrium (AGU) lost 2% on a downgrade. TD Newcrest cut shares of the fertilizer maker to hold from buy, but raised its price target to 100 from 95. The stock dipped under an 89.79 buy point from a cup base cleared Dec. 29.Group mate Mosaic (MOS) fell 1% in fast trade. It cleared a 74.35 buy point from a flat base Dec. 29 and still hovered above that price level.On the upside, LDK Solar (LDK) gapped up and rocketed 17% after raising guidance. The Chinese maker of solar wafers boosted its Q4 2010 sales outlook to a range of $870 to $910 million, up from a prior estimate of $710 to $750 million. Currently, analyst views call for $741.9 million. It also guided full-year 2011 revenue above views. The stock remains 18% off its high.Group mate Jinko Solar (JKS) jumped 6% and Trina Solar Limited (TSL) rose 3%.
While the indexes showed little movement Tuesday, top-rated stocks fared much better.

The Nasdaq rose 0.3%, while the NYSE composite slipped 0.2%. The S&P 500 and the Dow were up fractionally. Volume was up on the Nasdaq and down on the NYSE. Decliners led advancers by a 5-4 ratio on the NYSE and were roughly even on the Nasdaq.

Some top-rated stocks found new highs in strong volume, including China-based Internet content provider Baidu (BIDU), online film provider Netflix (NFLX), fast-casual restaurant Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS).
Several stocks broke out, including high-end handbag and accessories maker Coach (COH), Ugg boot maker Deckers Outdoor (DECK) and IT outsourcing services provider iGate (IGTE).
Among industry groups, apparel makers and cruise operators did well. For-profit schools and steel producers fell hard.

The major indexes traded slightly lower in pre-market action Monday, as investors looked ahead to the start of third-quarter earnings season later this week.Nasdaq 100, S&P 500 and Dow futures all edged lower ahead of the opening bell.Aluminum supplier Alcoa (AA) is scheduled to kick off third-quarter earnings season on Thursday.A handful of other companies operating on a different fiscal schedule will be out with results before then. Fertilizer maker  Mosaic (MOS) is slated to release its quarterly results after today's close. The company owns a 91 IBD Composite Rating.Shares of Sara Lee (SLC) rocketed 17% in pre-market action. The producer of meats, baked goods and other foods perked up on a report that it rejected a $12 billion unsolicited takeover offer from KKR.French drugmaker Sanofi-Aventis (SNY) launched a hostile bid of $69 a share for Genzyme (GENZ) after the biotech's management refused to accept an earlier $18.5 billion buyout bid.On the economic front, data on August factory orders new home sales are both due at 10 a.m. EDT.
Stocks pared gains and turned narrowly mixed near Tuesday's halftime. In a reversal from Monday, blue chips fared the worst while techs sported slim gains.

The Nasdaq rose 0.3%, but that's down from a gain of 0.6%. The S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%. Turnover was tracking lower across the board compared to the same time Monday.

Chuy's Holdings (CHUY) ramped up for the sixth straight session. The July IPO added nearly 3% to a fresh record high. Chuy's operates a chain of about 37 Tex-Mex restaurants, mostly in Southern states. Analysts see earnings surging 150% to 55 cents a share this year.

Panera Bread (PNRA) pulled back after hitting a new high, but was still up nearly 1%. The stock cleared a 164.10 buy point from a cup-with-handle base Sept. 12 in almost triple its average trade. Panera is 5% above that buy point.

Lumber Liquidators (LL) was off its session low, but still down 5% in big volume. The stock was off by nearly 8%, but trimmed losses after nearing its 50-day line. Lumber Liquidators has on been on fire since clearing a cup-with-handle base in early March.

Mosaic (MOS) gapped down and dropped 4% after reporting lackluster fiscal Q1 results. Hurt by weak phosphate sales, Mosaic's profit fell to $1.03 a share, excluding items, from $1.21 a share in the year-ago period. Revenue dropped 19% to just over $2.5 billion. Views were for $1.15 a share on sales of about $2.68 billion.

Rivals Potash Corp. Of Saskatchewan (POT) and CF Industries (CF) lost 3% and 2%, respectively. Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF) shed 3%, but was still well past a 28.91 handle trigger cleared in July.Stocks pared gains and turned narrowly mixed near Tuesday's halftime. Leading stocks rebounded Wednesday as the market recouped much of the prior session's sharp losses. Netflix (NFLX), a leader in the No. 2 Leisure sector, rose 3.82 to 153.15 during the regular session, then jumped in after-hours trade. The stock remained well above its double-bottom buy point of 124.10 and above its 50-day moving average. The online video rental firmâ¦

Stocks remained lower in late-morning trade on Wednesday as chip, chip gear, fertilizer and banking stocks paced the decline.The Nasdaq fell 0.9%, slightly above its lows of the morning. The S&P 500 slid nearly 0.7%, and the NYSE composite was down 0.6%. Volume was tracking slightly higher on the Nasdaq and sharply lower on the NYSE.Chipmaking and chip equipment stocks helped drag the tech-heavy Nasdaq lower as Cree (CREE) plunged 14% following a quarterly profit miss.ASML Holding (ASML) slid 6% despite posting strong Q4 results. The stock is still up 15% past a 33.34 double-bottom buy point. It's found support along its 10-week moving average since its late-October breakout.The Dutch maker of lithography systems that map out electronic circuits posted Q4 sales of 1.52 billion euros, or $2.03 billion, up 145%, according to Reuters. Net income was 407 million euros ($544.8 million), a quarterly record, and earnings per share vaulted to $1.24 vs. $0.17 a year ago.CEO Eric Meurice told a news conference that the current up cycle for the chip sector should extend into 2012. ASML has a market cap of $16.5 billion, second only to Applied Materials (AMAT) in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Equipment industry group.Veeco Instruments (VECO) shed its gains over the prior two sessions, losing 6%. The maker of systems used to make LEDs and other products has been trading in a wide-and-loose pattern since hitting a high of 54.50 in late April.Fertilizer makers also weighed on the market. Late Tuesday, Cargill said it would divest its 64% stake in Mosaic (MOS), the Plymouth, Minn.-based phosphate and potash giant. Cargill will sell its 286 million shares to its own shareholders and owners of Cargill debt. Mosaic dropped 6%, wiping away three days' worth of gains.CF Industries (CF), which makes both phosphate and nitrogen-based fertilizers, sank 4% in heavy trade but still held well above a 130.10 buy point following its Dec. 23 breakout from a six-week flat base.On the upside, Dow component IBM (IBM) gapped up at the open and gained 3% to a new high. In late September, the stock cleared an eight-month saucer pattern and has rallied 17% past its 132.59 buy point. The computer and IT services giant notched 16% earnings growth in Q4, its fourth quarter of double-digit gains. Revenue climbed 7%, the biggest increase since the second quarter of 2008.IBM's gains helped the Dow industrials trade slightly higher.

Wall Street's answer to that old riddle is a question: But what was the tree's volume like? In typical year-end fashion, the marketâ¦

Stocks notched small gains Wednesday as below-average volume persisted for a seventh straight session. Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video! The Nasdaq added 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow inched up 0.1% each. The NYSE composite popped 0.4%. Big gains among the NYSE-listed fertilizer stocks helpedâ¦
The major averages finished higher in unison Wednesday, the first time this week.
The major averages finished higher in unison Wednesday, the first time this week.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!

At the close, the NYSE composite rose 0.4% and the Nasdaq 0.2%. The Dow and S&P 500 edged up 0.1% each. All but the Nasdaq hit a fresh two-year high. Turnover slipped on both major exchanges and was well below average again.
Fertilizer producers sprouted gains after Bunge (BG) Chief Executive Alberto Weisser told Financial Times that grain supplies would remain tight and prices high through next year.

Mosaic (MOS) jumped 5% in heavy trading to its highest close in more than two years. It cleared a 74.35 buy point from a seven-week cup base. Mosaic is a maker of phosphate and potash fertilizers. It has delivered triple-digit profit growth in two of the past three quarters. Sales grew between 17% and 50% in the past three quarters.
Group mate Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) rose 5% and notched a two-year high in brisk volume. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B- from D+ last month.
Sociedad Quimica y Minera (SQM) rose 3% in fast trade, also good for a two-year high. The stock recently found support at its 10-week moving average. It cleared a cup-with-handle base Aug. 17.

Elsewhere, Rovi (ROVI) added 3% to its best levels in more than nine years. The stock is extended after breaking out from a base-on-base pattern in September. Rovi provides an array of digital entertainment technologies. On Tuesday, Sears Holdings (SHLD) said it was launching a movie-download service using technology from Sonic Solutions (SNIC). Rovi is in the process of buying Sonic.
Initial jobless claims, Chicago PMI and pending home sales will be out Thursday.

Stocks continued to recover after staging a big downside reversal on this last day of the month and quarter.The Nasdaq, NYSE composite and S&P 500 fell 0.2% each. The Dow lost 0.3%. All major indexes were down between 0.7% and 0.9% at session lows. Volume continued to track vastly higher across the board.Agricultural stocks stumbled as grain prices fell sharply. Farming equipment firms CNH Global (CNH) and Deere (DE) dropped 4% and 3%, respectively. Fertilizer makers Agrium (AGU) and Mosaic (MOS) lost 3% each.Elsewhere, Tenneco (TEN) erased earlier gains and dropped 4% in fast trade. The stock fell below a 29.84 buy point from a base-on-base pattern cleared Wednesday. Shares were up as much as 3% earlier.Netflix (NFLX) reversed from a new record high and lost 4% in heavy trading. The stock wiped out most of Wednesday's move.On the upside, Trimble Navigation (TRMB) rose 2% in fast trade. The stock cleared a 33.67 buy point from a cup base Sept. 20 and has gained 4%. Trimble makes GPS devices for the engineering and construction markets. Its earnings dropped 32% last year, but analysts see a 38% jump this year.Trimble's Composite Rating is 88, a bit below leadership quality. The 88 rating means about one-eighth of the market is rated higher. The Composite Rating combines all five IBD ratings into one number.Elsewhere, gold cut most of its losses to settle at $1,309.10 an ounce, down $1.20.

Stocks were modestly higher early Thursday after shaking off earlier weakness.The Nasdaq rose 0.3% while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 edged up 0.1% each. The latter two indexes touched two-year highs. Volume was tracking lower across the board.In economic news, pending home sales surprisingly rose 2% in December. That marked the fifth straight monthly gain. Economists expected a 0.5% drop.China MediaExpress (CCME) gapped up and bolted 10% to a record high. The stock gapped past a 21.50 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. China MediaExpress, a provider of digital advertising in buses in China, has already traded more than half its average daily volume.Potash Corp. (POT) gapped up and gained 4% to a two-year high after beating views. Before the open, the fertilizer maker said its Q4 earnings surged 121% to $1.77 a share. Boosted by high demand stemming from rising food prices, sales jumped 65% to $1.81 billion, easily above views. It guided Q1 and full-year profit mostly in line with expectations. The stock cleared a flat base in late December.Late Wednesday, the company raised its quarterly cash dividend to 12 cents a share from a dime a share. It also announced a 3-for-1 stock split.Two other fertilizer stocks, Agrium (AGU) and Mosaic (MOS), rose 2% each.Under Armour (UA) gapped above its 50-day moving average and gained 6% after besting expectations. The stock is forming a new base. Before the open, the athletic clothing maker reported Q4 earnings of 44 cents a share, up 47% and 7 cents over views. Sales, which also beat views, grew 36% to $301.2 million. Under Armour pegged full-year revenue at $1.33 billion to $1.35 billion vs. estimates of $1.28 billion.On the downside, Starbucks (SBUX) gapped down and fell 3%, yet it continued to find support at its 50-day moving average. Late Wednesday, the coffee giant delivered fiscal Q1 results, but warned that rising coffee prices would hurt its bottom line more than it previously expected.

Top-ranked stocks rebounded Thursday. Aruba Networks (ARUN) gapped up at the open and gained 1.66 to 22.98 in heavy volume. In the prior two sessions, the stock lost ground in strong trade, but investors supported the stock near its 50-day moving average, a positive sign. The wireless networking firm announced solid October Q1 results late Wednesday. Its Internet-Networking industry groupâ¦
Stock futures held steady, healthy gains ahead of Monday's open as the market looked toward a short week of preholiday trade. Dow futures were level, trading 92.5 points above fair market value.
Nasdaq 100 futures and S&P 500 futures were also steady, up 33.4 and 11.4 points, respectively.

The stock market today has its work cut out for it, although Christmas week trade generally tends to be light. The young uptrend ran into heavy distribution Friday, raising questions as to how long it will last.

Economic news isn't likely to have much impact. The Chicago Federal Reserve's National Activity Index, the most prominent piece of economic news prior to the open, showed a 0.3% slip in November. That accelerated October's 0.17% contraction and was not what economist consensus had expected â a 0.15% increase.

International markets also appeared to have negligible effect. Stocks in Europe traded modestly higher at midday. China's markets rose, including a 1.8% jump from the Shanghai Composite, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan slipped 0.4%.

The dollar rose. Bonds edged up. Oil prices slipped, with West Texas Intermediate down 1%, bobbing between $34 and $35 a barrel, and Brent crude down 2% to just above $36. Most metals traded higher, but with no big gains.

There could be a "Star Wars" effect on early trade, with Walt Disney (DIS) being one of three stocks leading the Dow with a better-than 1% gain in premarket trade. Goldman Sachs (GS) and Apple (AAPL) also gained more than 1%.

Disney's "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" grossed an estimated $238 million in the U.S. and Canada over the weekend. That was above expectations, beating out prior record holders "Jurassic World," which grossed $208.8 million when it premiered in June, and "The Avengers," which pulled $207.4 million in its 2012 premier.
Disney shares briefly cleared a 117.678 buy point in a cup-with-handle base in November, then dropped and undercut the buy point by more than 8%, triggering a sell rule.

Huge-screen, 3D-savvy Imax (IMAX) jumped 3%. The new "Star Wars" film reportedly premiered on 667 Imax screens over the weekend, pulling in $48 million â setting an Imax record and topping the $44.1 million opening weekend take of "Jurassic World," according to box office figures from Deadline Hollywood. Imax, an IBD 50 stock, ended Friday about 2% below a 39.97 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Also on the IBD 50 list, ARM (ARMH) perked up 3% ahead of the open. Shares of the Cambridge, England-based chip designer tumbled 6% last week, ending below the stock's converged 10- and 40-week lines of support.Stock futures held steady, healthy gains ahead of Monday's open as the market looked toward a short week of preholiday trade. Stocks weakened, but remained off the worst levels of Thursday's session.
The Nasdaq dropped 1%, hurt by chips and networking issues. The Dow and S&P 500 lost 0.7% each, while the NYSE composite fell 0.5%. Volume was mixed, with the Nasdaq higher and the NYSE lower.

NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) was off its session low, but still down 7% in heavy trading. The stock had been down more than 13%. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has crumpled to E from B+ in late July.

JinkoSolar Holdings (JKS) lost 2% as it pulled back for a second straight session. The May IPO snapped a seven-session win streak Wednesday. JinkoSolar reports earnings Aug. 16. Analysts are expecting 58 cents a share, up from 3 cents a share in the year-ago period.

On the upside, China Agritech (CAGC) surged 21% and regained its 200-day moving average. Before the open, the Chinese fertilizer producer reported a smaller-than-expected decline in its Q2 profit. The company reaffirmed its full-year profit revenue outlook of $114 million vs. views of $112.3 million. China Agritech is recovering from a 70% correction from its March peak.
Other fertilizer producers rallied in sympathy. Mosaic (MOS) and Intrepid Potash (IPI) gained 5% each, while Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) rose 4%.

Elsewhere, Kraton Performance Polymers (KRA) staged a big comeback. It turned an earlier 3% loss into a 3% gain. Kraton came public in December and has doubled since then. The company makes materials used in adhesives, coating, sealants and personal care products. Kraton lost a penny a share last year, but analysts see it earning $3.22 a share this year.Stocks weakened, but remained off the worst levels of Thursday's session.The Nasdaq dropped 1%, hurt by chips and networking issues. Fertilizer shares sprouted Monday after an analyst upgraded CF Industries (CF), Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) and others on an emerging "win-win" scenario. Dahlman Rose analyst Charles Neivert said the large corn crop expected this year is already priced in to the fertilizers' stock prices. If that large yield occurs, the shares have limited downside, he noted, and should climbâ¦

Woozy global economies and cautious distributors could deliver the first quarterly decline in per-share profits for fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS) in more than two years. The company reports fiscal third-quarter earnings after the close Wednesday. Analysts expect 74 cents per share, down from $1.21 a year earlier. They expect revenue of $2.13 billion, down slightly from last year's $2.2 billion.â¦
Stock futures on Tuesday advanced toward the open for a second straight day, but showed a bit more strength than in Monday's premarket session.

Dow futures were ahead 91.1 points, well above Monday's premarket levels, and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 23.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a healthy 10.2-point gain. Small caps also looked in good shape, with Russell 2000 futures up 4.8 points.

The stock market today rolls into December with automakers releasing November sales numbers throughout the session. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported a 3% gain in sales to its best level for November in 15 years. Jeep sales drove the results, rising 20%, vs. a 12% decline for Chrysler products, an 8% slip for Dodge and a 3% fall for Fiat autos.
Auto researcher Edmunds forecasts a total of 1.33 million light vehicles sold during the month, up 2.5% from a year ago. If accurate, it would make this the best November for automakers since 2001.
At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management releases its November ISM Index and the Commerce Department reports October construction spending.

Retailers with a strong online presence may get a bump from data released by Adobe Systems (ADBE) showing shoppers spent a total of $2.98 billion during "Cyber Monday" â the Monday following the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season, which is designated as a day of technology and online shopping specials. The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.
About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.
Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.

Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.

Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain â in line with consensus views.

China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.

Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.

Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Most of the group remained flat. Among the few gains and losses, all held to less than 1%. The same was true for stocks on IBD's Your Weekly Review list.
Overseas, markets across Asia gained as PMI gauges tracking China's manufacturing and services sectors showed further divergence during the month. European markets were narrowly mixed near midday.

Follow Alan Elliott on Twitter @IBD_AElliott.Stock futures on Tuesday advanced toward the open for a second straight day, but showed a bit more strength than in Monday's premarket session.Dow futures were ahead 91.1 points, well above Monday's premarket levels, and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 23.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a healthy 10.2-point gain. Small caps also looked in good shape, with Russell 2000 futures up 4.8 points.The stock market today rolls into December with automakers releasing November sales numbers throughout the session. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported a 3% gain in sales to its best level for November in 15 years. Jeep sales drove the results, rising 20%, vs. a 12% decline for Chrysler products, an 8% slip for Dodge and a 3% fall for Fiat autos.Auto researcher Edmunds forecasts a total of 1.33 million light vehicles sold during the month, up 2.5% from a year ago. If accurate, it would make this the best November for automakers since 2001.At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management releases its November ISM Index and the Commerce Department reports October construction spending.Retailers with a strong online presence may get a bump from data released by Adobe Systems (ADBE) showing shoppers spent a total of $2.98 billion during "Cyber Monday" â the Monday following the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season, which is designated as a day of technology and online shopping specials. The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain â in line with consensus views.China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Stocks ceded early gains and turned south before the lunch hour, with automakers and solar stocks leading the declines.
The S&P 500 dipped 0.3%. The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.2% each.
Volume climbed 16% on the Nasdaq and was 13% higher on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday.

The stock market today sorted through contradictory influences. Rising consumer price data suggested inflation is on pace with the Fed's goal. Some Federal Reserve members have worried that inflation is too low.

A healthy reading on builder confidence from the National Association of Home Builder's July Housing Market Index and a slight improvement in factory activity hinted that the recovery remained on pace.

The pullback in late morning trade occurred after Federal Reserve official Esther George asserted the central bank should begin trimming back its bond purchases. This was not new for George. In the past four meetings, she has voted against the Fed's stance to maintain quantitative easing.

On the earnings calendar, Goldman Sachs (GS) slipped, Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) rose a fraction after positive quarterly reports. Fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS) dropped 2%, after reporting sales and earnings declined less than expected.
Tenet Healthcare (THC) led the S&P 500 with a 3% gain. But the hospital operator pared its early gains after meeting resistance at its 50-day moving average.

Bally Technologies (BYI) rose 6% to top the S&P Midcap 40. Bally announced it would buy smaller rival SHFL Entertainment (SHFL) for $1.3 billion in cash. SHFL soared 22%. Both companies are headquartered in Las Vegas.
In commodities, oil backtracked, slipping a fraction to below $105 a barrel. Gold edged up to above $1.291 an ounce.

Stocks shaved more losses near midday Friday after sliding at the open. The S&P 500 lost 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.3%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq dropped 0.5%. All three were down between 1.4% and 1.8% at session lows. Volume was tracking mixed with NYSE higher and Nasdaq lower. CF Industries Holdings (CF) gapped down and slumped 7%â¦
Stocks rallied Friday as larger-than-expected job losses raised hopes for more Fed action to boost the economy.
Stocks rallied Friday as larger-than-expected job losses raised hopes for more Fed action to boost the economy.

The U.S. economy lost 95,000 jobs in September vs. expectations for no change in payrolls.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.8%. The Dow and NYSE hit fresh five-month highs. They gained 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 climbed 0.6%. Turnover rose on both exchanges as indexes closed near session highs.
For the week, the Dow and S&P 500 gained 1.6% each, while the Nasdaq climbed 1.3%. The NYSE composite ran up 1.9%, its sixth straight weekly gain.
Agriculture-related stocks were some of the session's best performers after the U.S. Department of Agriculture cut its corn crop estimate.

Lindsay (LNN) bolted 11% in more than twice its average trade. The stock cleared a 44.81 buy point from a handle in a nine-month pattern and hit its best levels in nearly two years. Lindsay makes irrigation systems. Analysts see its earnings rising 47% this year.
Two other ag-related stocks, CNH Global (CNH) and Deere (DE), rallied 8% and 5%, respectively.

Mosaic (MOS) gapped up and gained 7% in more than double its average volume. The stock cleared a 64.04 buy point in a long, deep handle. Fellow fertilizer maker Agrium (AGU) gapped up and climbed nearly 8%.

Elsewhere, Lululemon Athletica (LULU) climbed 5% to its best levels in more than two years. Volume swelled to more than double its average. Lululemon cleared a 43.47 buy point in a double-bottom base Sept. 14 and has gained 9%.

On the downside, F5 Networks (FFIV) fell 4% in triple its average volume. Citing cyclical risks, Goldman Sachs downgraded the network technology firm to sell from neutral. F5 finished well off session lows and above its 50-day moving average.
No economic reports are scheduled for Monday.

Stocks worsened and stumbled to fresh session lows at midday Wednesday.The NYSE composite dropped 1.4%, the S&P 500 1.2% and the Nasdaq 1.1%. Volume was tracking mixed, with NYSE trading a touch higher and the Nasdaq's lower. Not many leaders came under after heavy selling Wednesday, though.Late Tuesday lawn care products maker Scotts Miracle-Gro (SMG) slashed its full-year profit outlook to $3.10 to $3.20 a share vs. consensus estimates for $3.65. The news pressured fertilizer makers. Mosaic (MOS) dropped 3%, while CF Industries (CF) and Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) fell 2% each. Scotts gapped down and slumped 5%.J.C. Penney (JCP) fell 3% in fast trade as it gave back a small piece of Tuesday's 17% surge. On Tuesday, the department store retailer said it named a former Apple (AAPL) executive as its new chief executive officer.SolarWinds (SWI) turned slightly lower after retreating from a record high. On Tuesday, the stock cleared a 24.88 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The management software maker's earnings growth picked up in recent quarters, but sales growth decelerated over the same period.On the upside, Travelzoo (TZOO) erased earlier losses and climbed 4% in fast trade. There's no specific company news. In the first hour of trading, the stock had already traded half of its average daily volume. Travelzoo is trying to recover after falling 47% from its April 25 peak. The company is an online publisher of travel deals. It has delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit profit growth.JinkoSolar (JKS) bucked weakness among solar issues. The stock erased an earlier loss, rose 3% and regained its 50-day moving average. Despite recent volatility, JinkoSolar rose the past four sessions.Elsewhere, oil rose 31 cents to $99.68 following a bigger-than-expected drop in inventories. The Energy Information Administration reported a draw of 3.4 million barrels last week vs. estimates for a decline of 1.9 million.Gold turned higher despite a stronger dollar. The August contract climbed $6.80 to $1,531.20 an ounce.

Stocks improved in late trading Friday and were on pace to cap the week with gains.The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, climbing back above the 2400 mark Â a level it hasn't closed above in nearly five months. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite climbed 0.7%. The Dow and S&P 500 gained 0.6% each. Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE.Agriculture-related stocks continued to be among the session's best performers.CNH Global (CNH) ramped up 9% to a two-year high. It found support at its 40-week line in late August. The Dutch maker of agricultural and construction equipment is scheduled to report Q3 earnings Oct. 21. Analysts are expecting 30 cents a share vs. a year-ago loss of 9 cents a share.Fertilizer producer Agrium (AGU) gapped up and gained 8% to a 52-week high. Mosaic (MOS), another agricultural chemicals stock, rose 7% to a nine-month high.Elsewhere, Casino operators gained after the Nevada Gaming Control Board said gaming revenue on the Las Vegas Strip jumped 21% on a year-over-year basis in August.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) climbed 4% each. Penn National Gaming (PENN) rose 3% to a five-month high.

The latest USDA report showed drought damage to Midwest corn and soybean crops continued this past week, but the agency reported corn conditions were unchanged and soybean conditions improved slightly for the week.

That's scant comfort for farmers who are in their third year of a devastating drought that's calculated to be the worst in 50 years. Fertilizer stocks as a group slid 2.66%, the second day in a row the group has fallen.
CF Industries (CF), the largest fertilizer maker by sales and highest-rated company in the group, fell nearly 2% to 211.40.
Among other large fertilizer makers, Potash (POT) dropped 2.4%, Mosaic (MOS) was off 0.8% and Agrium (AGU) slid 2.4%.
Other top-rated companies in the group weren't immune either. American Vanguard (AVD) fell 2.5% to 29.03 and Syngenta (SYT) was off 0.5% at 69.19.
Sociedad Quimica (SQM) was down 0.4% and Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF) faded 2.7%.
RBC Capital Markets noted in a report that, based on the weekly USDA figures, only 3% of corn crops are rated as in excellent condition vs. 25% rated poor and 26% very poor.
"When we weight conditions in the most important corn-producing states according to production, 2012 conditions have declined significantly compared to the past three years," RBC said.

Once the corn crop matures, the bank noted, focus will shift to what yields are and how impaired they are from the drought.The latest USDA report showed drought damage to Midwest corn and soybean crops continued this past week, but the agency reported corn conditions were unchanged and soybean conditions improved slightly for the week.That's scant comfort for farmers who are in their third year of a devastating drought that's calculated to be the worst in 50 years. Market leaders of the year seldom come back for a repeat performance year after year. And losers eventually turn around due to the "regression to the mean" theory in which extreme moves up or down even out over the long run. Here is an overview of five ETFs in alphabetical order that our panel of investment strategists is making contrarianâ¦

As forecasts called for 100-degree weekend temperatures and scant rain over much of the Midwest, the drought-raked region braced for a federal crop condition report Monday that's expected to show the toll is climbing.
Week by week since June, updates have pared what once promised to be a record harvest. Corn and soybean prices have spiked for five straight weeks, tearing through record highs Thursday and Friday.
Concerns are rising across the agricultural sector, a $400 billion powerhouse that has boomed as much of the U.S. economy shuffled through an ersatz recovery.
Grain growers and crop insurers face a difficult season, but generally not financial disaster. Livestock ranchers and ethanol producers may be the biggest losers.
Grain

Grain farmers entered 2012 on strong footing, says Chris Hurt, agricultural economist at Purdue University. Years of high prices had boosted farm incomes to record levels. Rising land values drove the sector's debt-to-asset ratios to their lowest since 1960.

But drought damage led the Agriculture Department on July 16 to expand its lowest-tier assessment of "poor to very poor" corn acreage to 38% vs. 30% the prior week. Nearly a third of the soybean crop got the same sad grade. Wheat has been less affected, but prices have also spiked to record highs.

Many experts expect Monday's report from the National Agricul tural Statistics Service to confirm even more damage. Further reductions could pit livestock farmers vs. grain processors and ethanol producers in a struggle for dwindling supplies.

Yet most grain farmers are looking at very survivable scenarios, Hurt says. Indiana, the hardest hit of the big corn states, faced an overall 28% crop loss as of last week. But prices have shot up 50% since the start of June. A farmer could lose half of his crop and still have a good year.
"It could be that revenues, on average, will not be as heavily affected as what the general thought is," Hurt said.

Farmers who hedged portions of their crop at lower prices are more at risk. A farmer who hedged a third of his crop at $5.50 a bushel and lost another third to drought faces a tough year. Those who sold forward 50% or more of their crop may take significant losses.

Several farm suppliers have done well. Equipment maker Deere & Co. (DE) rose 16% from June 1 and mid-July, then eased to 6% above its June 1 price. Irrigation equipment maker Lindsay (LNN) has bolted 31% since June 1. Seed producer Monsanto (MON) is up 15%.
Insurance
U.S. farmers paid the highest cost ever to put this year's crop in the ground, Hurt says.

Many farmers risk their entire net worth each year. Crop insurance offers a vast safety net against disaster. It isn't cheap and doesn't cover all losses. But it generally keeps farms from failing and lets them invest in the next season's crop.

Multiperil crop insurance represents only 1% of the property/casualty industry's net annual written premiums. The insurers tend to be top-rated, large, globally diversified operators with solid balance sheets, a July 18 report from Fitch said. They include Switzerland's Ace Ltd. (ACE), Cincinnati's American Financial Group (AFG) and Germany's Allianz (AZSEY) . Shares of all three have dipped since the start of May.
Endurance Specialty (ENH) is most exposed, with crop insurance 25% of its net premiums written, Fitch says. Its stock is off 16% since May 1.
Livestock
In east Texas, ranching conditions actually improved this year, while west Texas stayed parched.
Last year, "in Texas, it was our driest year on record," said David Anderson, a livestock economist with Texas A&M's AgriLife Extension Service.
Dairy farmers and beef ranchers had been reducing herds since grain and feed costs upshifted in 2006. Last year's drought accelerated the culling to record levels.

This year's expanded drought is propelling feed costs and withering grassland in the Great Plains and Corn Belt regions. Those pastures had provided a market for Texas and Oklahoma ranchers selling beef and dairy cattle, Anderson says.
Now ranchers are liquidating herds in more states. Prices for calves sold into feedlots, to be fattened for sale as beef, have sunk.

Unlike crop farmers, no insurance backstops livestock producers. The likely outcome is an increasing number of failures, Anderson says, and an accelerated downsizing of the U.S. beef and dairy trades.
"We've got the fewest cattle in the U.S. in 60 years," he said.
Fertilizers

U.S. fertilizer buying is done for this year, says Roger Elmore, an extension corn specialist at Iowa State University. Most drought-damaged crops will be mowed and turned back into the soil. That generally means more nutrients left in the ground, pointing to less fertilizer demand in the 2013 growing season.

But the southern hemisphere is in its fertilizer buying season. The U.S. is the world's leading corn exporter, so the drought and soaring prices are rippling across the globe, says Oliver Hatfield, director of fertilizers with Integer Research in London. That could boost fertilizer sales. But several production facilities are set to come on line in Saudi Arabia and North Africa.
"There is a risk that there will be oversupply," Hatfield said.
But fertilizer stocks have continued to track corn prices, with stocks like Mosaic (MOS) up 25% and CF Industries (CF) up 26% since June 1.
Ethanol
"Ethanol producers came into 2012 on a high," said Brian Jennings, executive vice president with the American Coalition for Ethanol.
Oil and gasoline prices were high. Record-setting corn plantings led to forecasts for low input costs.
But oil prices fell abruptly in May, forcing some ethanol plant shutdowns. The corn price spike, begun in June, tightened the vise.
Valero (VLO) in June idled two facilities in Nebraska and Indiana with annual capacity of 110 million gallons each.

The drought may shake out some weaker players. But, in general, Jennings said, "Ethanol producers are on better footing than they were (during the price spikes) in 2008."As forecasts called for 100-degree weekend temperatures and scant rain over much of the Midwest, the drought-raked region braced for a federal crop condition report Monday that's expected to show the toll is climbing.Week by week since June, updates have pared what once promised to be a record harvest.
