The wet winter across much of the U.S. heartland and in Europe continues to take its toll. Chemical maker DuPont (DD) warned that its earnings will be lower than expected as a result of lower sales because of weak agriculture chemical sales.
The harsh winter that hurt spring planting this year followed a drought that devastated much of the Midwest corn crop last year.
DuPont now expects first-half operating profit to be 10% below last year, vs. its April forecast for a 7% to 9% drop.
The company also expects full-year operating earnings to fall below its previous $3.85 to $4.05 per share estimate. Wall Street expected $3.90 a share.
DuPont sells nutrition supplements for pig and chicken feed, along with animal disease prevention and control products.
Chief Financial Officer Nicholas Fanandakis said at a conference that "March to May 2013 has been the wettest spring in nearly 120 years across the farm belt states of Iowa, Illinois and Indiana."
DuPont shares were down 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today.

The chemicals giant, with annual sales north of $35 billion, saw earnings per share growth fall 54%, 69% and 3% over the last three quarters. Analyst consensus prior to Thursday's announcement was for an 8% drop this quarter.
Still, its stock hit a two-year high 56.38 May 21 in sync with a market upturn, before it turned down.
Large companies in the Agricultural Operations industry group, ranked a weak 134 on IBD's list of 197 industries, are also feeling the effects of the rough weather.

Grain and seed processor and fertilizer maker Bunge 's (BG) shares, down 14% from a Feb. 5 high, rose 1.3%. Seed maker Monsanto (MON), which has been struggling with a global backlash since unapproved genetically engineered wheat was found growing on an Oregon farm last month, rose 0.5%.
In the Chemicals-Agriculture group, ranked a near-worst No. 193 on the industries list, fertilizer makers Mosaic (MOS) advanced 0.7%, Potash (POT) dipped 0.5% and Syngenta AG (SYT) slid 0.2%.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture in a report Wednesday offers some hope to agriculture companies. It forecast that U.S. farmers will bring in 14 billion bushels of corn this year, 135 million bushels lower than it forecast last month, but well above the 13.1-billion-bushel record set in 2009.
Last year, farmers only harvested roughly 11 billion bushels because of the drought.

The USDA noted that farmers got a short break from rain in late May and corn planting jumped from 28% to 71% complete in that period.The wet winter across much of the U.S. heartland and in Europe continues to take its toll. Chemical maker DuPont (DD) warned that its earnings will be lower than expected as a result of lower sales because of weak agriculture chemical sales.The harsh winter that hurt spring planting this year followed a drought that devastated much of the Midwest corn crop last year.DuPont now expects first-half operating profit to be 10% below last year, vs. its April forecast for a 7% to 9% drop.The company also expects full-year operating earnings to fall below its previous $3.85 to $4.05 per share estimate. Wall Street expected $3.90 a share.DuPont sells nutrition supplements for pig and chicken feed, along with animal disease prevention and control products.Chief Financial Officer Nicholas Fanandakis said at a conference that "March to May 2013 has been the wettest spring in nearly 120 years across the farm belt states of Iowa, Illinois and Indiana."DuPont shares were down 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today.The chemicals giant, with annual sales north of $35 billion, saw earnings per share growth fall 54%, 69% and 3% over the last three quarters. It forecast that U.S. farmers will bring in 14 billion bushels of corn this year, 135 million bushels lower than it forecast last month, but well above the 13.1-billion-bushel record set in 2009.Last year, farmers only harvested roughly 11 billion bushels because of the drought.The USDA noted that farmers got a short break from rain in late May and corn planting jumped from 28% to 71% complete in that period.

Stocks drove lower at Monday's open, hurt by overseas uncertainty and a rising dollar. The Nasdaq dropped 1.5%, the S&P 500 1.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.1%. Volume was up 2% on the Nasdaq and 7% higher on the NYSE compared with the same time Friday. New-home sales jumped more than 7% in May to an annualized rateâ¦

Heavy-volume selling in the market eased enough Thursday afternoon to allow the indexes to erase some losses.The Nasdaq pared a 1.4% loss to 0.5%. The S&P 500, once off as much as 0.8%, stood 0.1% above Wednesday's close. The NYSE composite was down 0.2%. Volume was still tracking higher across the board.Still, tech stocks and materials companies were wallowing in deep-loss territory. F5 Networks (FFIV) was off 21%, not much improved from its worst price of the day. Rackspace (RAX) was off 8% â but it had sunk as much as 12% earlier in the day. Volume remained strong for both of these recent market leaders.Blue Coat Systems (BCSI), a computer networking company, gapped down and shed 6%. It had been recovering from a deep correction. Coal producer Alliance Resources (ARLP) fell 4% in frantic trade. The stock was finding some support at its 50-day moving average, its first pullback since a Dec. 1 breakout.Walter Energy (WLT), another coal producer, had sunk as much as 4%, tested its 10-week moving average â then reversed higher.Among materials makers, Mosaic (MOS) fell 2% in heavy trade, after plunging 10% Wednesday.The market's bright spot appeared in the Retail-Department Store group, thanks to Dillard's (DDS), which shot up 15% in furious trade. Also, JC Penney (JCP) rose 4% in fast trade.After the close, watch for earnings reports from search engine  Google (GOOG), pawnshop and payday loan center operator EZCorp (EZPW) and chipmaker Skyworks (SWKS).
Stocks improved and were near fresh intraday highs midday Wednesday. They were modestly lower earlier, despite better-than-expected economic data.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 climbed 0.6% and 0.5% respectively and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. Turnover was tracking slightly lower across the board.
Economic data showed the services sector expanding more than expected and an ADP private sector gauge reported more hiring than estimated.

Nationstar Mortgage (NSM) reversed its early loss and ramped up nearly 6% to a new high in fast trade. The stock was off by 4% after being cut to neutral from buy at Sterne Agee. Nationstar is well-extended from a rebound off its 10-week line. The stock cleared resistance at the 35 level, which it has yet to close above.

Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) climbed 2% in active trading and neared resistance at its 50-day line. The high flier has pulled back from its September peak, but has found support near the 100 level. Mellanox may also be forming a new base. The Israeli maker of high-speed interconnect products will unveil its Q3 results after the market's close Oct. 17. Analysts see earnings surging 265% to $1.13 a share, which would mark the third straight quarter of triple-digit growth.

On the downside, MetroPCS Communications (PCS) tumbled 8% after confirming a merger with Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY). On Monday, MetroPCS bolted 18% on reports of a deal between the two companies. Sprint Nextel (S), which had been in talks with MetroPCS, bounced back from early losses and rose a fraction. See related story

Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF) was off its session low, but still down 5% in heavy trading. The stock trimmed its loss after sliding to around the 35 level, which was previously resistance. Rentech's weakness may be attributed to Lazard Capital's downgrade of Mosaic (MOS) and Potash Corp. Of SaskatchewanPOTStocks improved and were near fresh intraday highs midday Wednesday. Dow Chemical (DOW) unveiled a new soybean resistant to herbicides that it sees challenging Monsanto's (MON) dominance in the seed market. Dow, the chemical and agricultural products giant, submitted the genetically modified soybean to the Agriculture Department for approval. It was developed with privately held M.S. Technologies. Shares fell more than 1% as of 1:00 p.m. ET, while the overallâ¦
The major indexes achieved solid gains and closed near session highs on Tuesday, after shaking off early losses.
The major indexes achieved solid gains and closed near session highs on Tuesday, after shaking off early losses.

The Nasdaq composite tacked on 1%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the NYSE composite 0.6%. Volume increased on the NYSE, but dipped slightly on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.

After hours, Tibco Software (TIBX) fell even as it reported Q1 EPS and sales that beat views. The stock has been rebounding off its 10-week moving average since clearing a base on Feb. 1. The software maker boasts a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99.
During the regular session, a number of leading stocks behaved well.

Lululemon Athletica (LULU) gained 5% in big trade. The seller of high-end workout clothing broke out past an 85.38 buy point on Monday, but then dipped and finished below that level. On Tuesday, the stock finished the job and closed 4% beyond 85.38. Lululemon is No. 5 in this week's IBD 50.

Halliburton (HAL) rose 2% and cleared a 48.94 buy point from a base-on-base pattern. Volume was about 36% above average, just below the 40% or more level that you prefer to see. The oilfield services provider ended just barely over 48.94. The stock has a 99 Composite Rating.

Much of Tuesday's economic news was discouraging. Stocks started lower after a report showed that home prices fell in 19 of the 20 large U.S. cities tracked by the S&P/Case-Shiller index. Meanwhile, the Conference Board said its confidence index fell more than expected to 63.4 in February.

Wednesday's economic news will include a monthly jobs reports from ADP, as well as Challenger's monthly report on job cuts. Among the companies expected to report earnings are Signet Jewelers (SIG), Family Dollar (FDO) and Mosaic (MOS).

Stocks were modestly higher in early afternoon trading Monday, with techs leading the pack.The Nasdaq gained 0.4% and was on the verge of hitting a five-month high. Chips were strong as the Philadelphia semiconductor index climbed 1.6%. Gains in Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOG) also helped.Meanwhile, the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. The Dow and NYSE composite edged up 0.1% each.Volume was tracking sharply lower on the Nasdaq and higher on the NYSE.Agriculture-related issues again rallied as grain prices continued higher. Corn hit a two-year high, while soybeans touched a 16-month high. On Friday, the U.S. Department of Agriculture cut its corn corp estimate.CNH Global (CNH) added 3% to a new two-year high in fast trade. The Dutch farming gear maker reports Q3 earnings Oct. 21. Analysts are expecting $1.35 a share. CNH lost 48 cents a share in fiscal 2009.Lindsay Manufacturing (LNN) rose 2% to a near two-year high, following through on Friday's breakout. Last year, the irrigation systems maker's earnings tumbled 65%. But the company is expected to deliver a 47% increase this year. Fertilizer makers CF Industries (CF) and  Mosaic (MOS) rose 2% and 1%, respectively. Both cleared bases Friday.Elsewhere, Gymboree (GYMB) gapped up and bolted 22%. The children's apparel retailer agreed to be taken private by Bain Capital in a $1.8 billion deal. Rival  Children's Place (PLCE) gapped up and gained 5% in sympathy.On the downside, not all techs fared well. Citrix Systems (CTXS) fell 4% in heavy trading. It slumped to its lowest level since late August. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has dropped to D from A last month.Salesforce.com (CRM) and  VMware (VMW) lost 4% and 2%, respectively.

Leading stocks were active early Thursday as a bullish crop report boosted agriculture issues.The NYSE composite and S&P 500 climbed 0.7% each. The Nasdaq struggled ahead 0.3%, weighed down by Vertex Pharmaceuticals' (VRTX) 12% slide. Volume was 7% lower on the NYSE and down 18% on the Nasdaq.The Agriculture Department projected tight U.S. feed grain supplies and reduced corn acreage for 2011-12. The report reduced the area for intended corn plantings by 1.5 million acres, primarily due to weather-related planting delays. The department also reduced its forecast for harvested area by 1.9 million acres, to 83.2 million. It projected production of 13.2 billion bushels, 305 million below last month's estimate.The news sent fertilizer makers higher. CF Industries Holdings (CF) shoveled up a 4% advance in heavy trade. The IBD 50 stock cleared a cup-with-handle base May 23.Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT), Agrium (AGU) and Mosaic (MOS) climbed 3% each.In other stocks, accessories retail/wholesaler Fossil (FOSL) pared early gains, but held a 2% advance in strong trade. The IBD 50 stock is in the fourth week of a possible square-box base, or could be rebounding off its 10-week moving average. Its relative strength and accumulation performance is still top notch.On the downside, Polypore International (PPO) crumbled 5% in heavy selling. The maker of filters used in industrial, pharmaceutical and research settings had pulled back in quiet volume the past three weeks to test support at its 10-week moving average. Thursday's move cut that line in heavy volume, sending the stock back below its 60.60 buy point from an April breakout.

As stocks staggered lower in afternoon trade Wednesday, the Nasdaq sliced below its 50-day moving average for the first time since September.The Nasdaq was down 1.5%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.8% and the NYSE composite 0.6%. The S&P 500 and the NYSE remain above their 50-day line, but the margin above the line is only 1% to 2%. Volume was tracking higher across the board.Top-rated stocks weren't dodging the market's blows. Only four stocks in the IBD 50 were up. Two were energy-related â Concho Resources (CXO) and Northern Oil & Gas (NOG) â and one was a precious metal stock, Silver Wheaton (SLW). The fourth gainer was Apple (AAPL), which bounced off its 50-day line in strong volume.Other stocks were not so fortunate.Priceline.com (PCLN), which will report quarterly results after the close, dropped 3% in fast trade. The online travel booker pierced its 50-day line, trading under the key level for the first time since July.Mosaic (MOS) also violated its 50-day line. The fertilizer maker had bounced off its 50-day line in January, but that decline also came in heavy volume.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) plunged 5% in double its usual volume. The restaurant stock broke out of a base on Feb. 11, clearing a 262.87 buy point. But Chipotle is now more than 8% below the buy point. That would represent a sell rule for investors who bought the stock at that price or above it. A stock should be sold when it drops 7% or 8% below the price at which you buy it. The rule is designed to prevent deep losses that would be difficult to recover.Crude oil was up 4% as unrest continued in Libya. Gadhafi reportedly ordered the country's oil fields sabotaged. Gold tacked on a 1% gain.

Stocks made modest progress in trimming losses in afternoon trade Thursday.The NYSE composite was down 1.6%, after being off as much as 2.1% earlier. The Nasdaq fell 1.3% and the S&P 500 1.2%. Volume was up on both major exchanges but slowing from its early aggressive pace.Finding the day's winners was a difficult task. On the NYSE, there were five declining issues for every advancer. On the Nasdaq, the ratio was about 6-to-1. The IBD 50, a proxy for leading stocks, had more than four stocks down for every stock that was up.The ratios confirmed the reality that in a correction, three of every four stocks will go down. Opening new positions in such an atmosphere is hazardous.Two winners had a special story to back up their move. Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) and  Starbucks (SBUX) were up 36% and 9%, respectively, on a deal to sell Starbucks coffee and tea in Green Mountain's single-serve packs.Cloud-computing company F5 Networks (FFIV) rose 2% in brisk trade. But the move was a bounce off the 200-day moving average, not the place a top-rated stock should be living.Rental movie provider Netflix (NFLX) popped 3% in heavy volume, but the stock remains under its 50-day line.On the dominant downside, China-based Jinko Solar (JKS) shed 5% as it dropped under its 200-day line. The stock lost its 50-day line on March 4. Trina Solar (TSL) also fell 5%. It closed below its 50-day line on March 7, but appeared to be finding support at the 200-day line.Three fertilizer stocks Mosaic (MOS), Agrium (AGU) and Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) fell further under their 50-day line.Some top-rated stocks were holding above their 50-day line. They included Apple (AAPL),  Priceline.com (PCLN), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), Riverbed Technology (RVBD) and OpenTable (OPEN).

Stocks rallied in midday trade Wednesday, but volume was mixed.The NYSE composite led with a 1.2% gain. The S&P 500 added 0.9%, while the Nasdaq tacked on 0.7%.Volume was down on the Nasdaq and up slightly on the NYSE.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, strong performers included fertilizers, RVs and some retail stocks. The day's laggards included toys, gold miners and discount retailers.While yoga-apparel retailer Lululemon Athletica (LULU) boosted the retail apparel group with a 6% pop, there were other stocks in that niche that also were rallying. Ann Taylor Stores (ANN) was up 6%; Men's Wearhouse (MW) bobbed up 5%, recouping some of its big losses due to a Dec. 8 gap-down; and Jos. A. Bank Clothiers (JOSB) added 2% as it continued to ride along its 200-day moving average.Apparel makers also rose. Deckers Outdoor (DECK), the maker of Ugg boots, advanced 3% in heavy volume. The stock is extended after clearing a base in late October. However, it has found support on its first trip to the 10-week moving average. That puts it in a secondary buy zone.Fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS) gained 2% in strong volume. It is 5% past a 74.35 buy point after breaking out on Dec. 29. A buy zone only extends 5% past the ideal buy point.On the downside, Interactive Intelligence (ININ), a maker of call-center software, dropped 3% in fast trade. But this came after a 24% gap-up gain Tuesday in far greater volume.The Federal Reserve's beige book report, a collection of anecdotal economic information from each Federal Reserve district, is due to be released at 2 p.m. EST.Crude oil rallied about 1%, but gold was off about 0.4%.
Stocks fell Monday as a higher dollar and mixed economic data offset buyout news. But the major indexes avoided a distribution day.
Stocks fell Monday as a higher dollar and mixed economic data offset buyout news. But the major indexes avoided a distribution day.

The Nasdaq dropped 1.1%. It fared the worst due to Goldman Sach's downgrade of Microsoft (MSFT). The NYSE composite lost 0.9%, the S&P 500 0.8% and the Dow 0.7%. All major indexes bucked a distribution day as volume fell on both major exchanges.
Some leaders fell in heavy trading.

MercadoLibre (MELI) dropped 6% in more than double its average trade and sliced its 50-day moving average. Monday marked the biggest volume for a down day in nearly eight months. Intraday, the stock fell more than 8% from a 74.88 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern cleared Sept. 27.
Trina Solar (TSL) dropped 5% amid overall weakness in solar issues. Rival Jinko Solar (JKS) shed 8%.
VMware (VMW) lost 4% in heavy trading. But the stock found support at its 50-day moving average.

VMware closed 6% below an 87.26 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern cleared Sept. 20. The maker of virtualization software will report earnings Oct. 18. Analysts see profit rising 46% to 35 cents a share.

On the upside, Isilon Systems (ISLN) gapped up and surged 9% in more than three times average trade. Shares were up more than 14% at the session's peak on a report that it's exploring a sale of the company.
Netflix (NFLX) reversed higher to close up 1% in brisk trade.
After the close, Mosaic (MOS) reported fiscal Q1 earnings that were a nickel below views, but sales beat estimates. Shares fell about 2% in extended trading.
The ISM services index and earnings from Yum Brands (YUM) will be out Tuesday.

The Nasdaq pared gains in weakening trade while NYSE stocks edged higher on merger and earnings news.The NYSE was up 0.5% and the Dow 0.4%. The S&P 500 held its 0.3% advance while the Nasdaq eased to a 0.1% gain after being up as much as 0.7%.Trading slipped on both major exchanges.The dollar pressed higher vs. both the euro and yen.Heavy equipment makers were the leading industry, responding to news that Caterpillar  (CAT) would acquire mining equipment maker Bucyrus International (BUCY) for $8.6 billion.Caterpillar, a member of the Dow Jones industrials, throttled up 2% in heavy trading. It has an 89 Composite Rating. CNH Global (CNH) surged 6% in big trade, but it remained in buying range on a pullback to its 10-week moving average.Lowe's (LOW) advanced 2% in heavy trade after reporting Q3 EPS of 31 cents, a penny above analyst expectations. Revenue of $11.59 billion missed views for $11.75 billion. The home improvement retailer offered Q4 guidance in line with current views. The stock has been locked in a base since late April. Its RS Rating is 27. Home Depot (HD) rose 1% in strong trade.Fertilizer producer Mosaic (MOS) pared losses and was down 2% after diving 4% in early trade â a response to BHP Billiton  (BHP)calling off its hostile takeover attempt of Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT). Potash edged 1% lower in heavy trade and hit its lowest levels since Aug. 17, when the stock gapped up 31% on BHP's offer to buy the Canadian company for $40 billion.

Managers of top-performing stock funds have been stocking up on natural resources and industrial stocks in their latest reporting periods. That helps December live up to its gift-giving reputation, with stocks delivering 6% plus gains on the Nasdaq and S&P 500. Chemical firms have been performing well, including Polypore International (PPO), Innospec (IOSP) and Solutia (SOA) . Big agriculture names,â¦

Stocks vacillated and closed higher Friday after a round of mostly better-than-expected economic data. Personal income, personal spending, consumer sentiment and construction spending all beat expectations. But the ISM index was a tad below estimates.

The NYSE composite climbed 0.8%, while the Dow and S&P 500 gained 0.4% each. The Nasdaq lagged with a 0.1% gain.
All the major indexes stayed within Thursday's range. Volume fell across the board.
Equities ended little changed for the week. The NYSE composite rose 0.5% for its fifth straight weekly gain. The Nasdaq slipped 0.4%, the Dow dipped 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged off 0.2%.

Mesabi Trust (MSB) climbed 5% in fast trade Friday and regained most of Thursday's loss. It has gained 47% since clearing a 25.87 buy point from a cup-with-handle base on August 30, although that was its second try.
Mesabi is a royalty trust that holds interest in iron ore properties. It has delivered triple- to quadruple-digit earnings and sales growth in recent quarters.

Riverbed Technology (RVBD) rallied 4% in heavy trading to its best levels in nearly three years. The stock has been in a strong uptrend since rebounding off its 10-week line in August. Riverbed now sits just 10% below its Oct. 17, 2007, record high. The network application firm has delivered accelerating earnings and sales in recent quarters.

On the downside, VeriFone Systems (PAY) reversed opening gains and dropped 8% in more than twice its average volume. The stock erased Thursday's move and then some. On Thursday, Hypercom (HYC) rejected the payment processor's $290 million buyout offer. VeriFone remains 19% past a 23.84 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) dropped 5% in six times its average trade. But shares were down as much as 12% at session lows. Late Tuesday, the coffee distributor disclosed that it was being investigated for its revenue recognition practices and a vendor relationship. Jim Cramer called the stock a sell on Thursday night's "Mad Money."
Elsewhere, Amazon.com (AMZN), Baidu (BIDU) and Netflix (NFLX) fell in heavy trading.
Pending home sales and factory orders will be out Monday, along with earnings from fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS).

Stocks vacillated and closed higher Friday after a round of mostly better-than-expected economic data. Personal income, personal spending, consumer sentiment and construction spending all beat expectations. But the ISM index was a tad below estimates.

Stocks vacillated and closed higher Friday after a round of mostly better-than-expected economic data. Personal income, personal spending, consumer sentiment and construction spending all beat expectations. But the ISM index was a tad below estimates.

If it walks like a bull, but the Fed talks like a bear, what kind of market is it? On Wednesday, investors eventually decided it was a bull . The indexes stumbled midsession on the Federal Reserve's dismal minutes from the March meeting, but then recovered nicely. The Nasdaq tacked on 1.9% while the S&P 500 added 1.2%. The NYSEâ¦

Leading stocks finished mixed Friday in a holiday-shortened session. Netflix (NFLX), which soared 9% on Monday after announcing a rate hike in its online streaming and DVD-by-mail rental plans, added 3.13, or 2%, to a new high of 191.90. The stock has rallied 30% since rebounding off its 10-week moving average in late October. Netflix on Monday also launched inâ¦
5:15 p.m. Update: It was a complicated day. Weak jobs and factory order data overshadowed the Senate's passing of a reworked financial rescue package.
A weak earnings report from Mosaic (MOS) sent agriculture stocks sprawling, and a commodities sell-off added to the misery.
The NYSE composite cut deepest, ending 4.8% in the hole. The Nasdaq composite scrapped 4.5%. The S&P 500 gave up 4% and the Dow toppled 3.2%.
Midcaps hurtled further than most, with the S&P 400 plummeting 5.6%.
Energy stocks pulled down hardest on the NYSE, its energy index collapsing 6.8%.
Preliminary data showed volume up 10% on the NYSE and 14% higher on the Nasdaq.
All but three of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD lost ground.
Mortgage, diversified drug makers and diversified companies edged up.
Fertilizer makers, and gold and silver miners, fell furthest.
Decliners led advancers by about 5-to-1 on the NYSE and by about 9-to-2 on the Nasdaq.
Commodities toppled nearly across the board as the dollar continued its recent sprint. Oil, gold, natural gas and Â well, you name it Â closed lower.

Minnesota-based Mosaic's (MOS) fiscal Q1 results fell far short of analyst views late Wednesday. Mosaic tumbled 27.86 to 39.65. Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) tripped 34.53 to 93.51. CF Holdings (CF) dropped 30.64 to 58. The youngster of the group, Intrepid Potash (IPI), dove 6.32 to 23.33.
Other agriculture-related issues were also dragged lower.
Seed and grain processor Bunge (BG) tumbled 12.84 to 50.16. Its shares are mired in a nine-month correction that has now erased all the stock's gains since July '07.
Monsanto (MON) withered 15.83 to 82.01. That put the genetic-seed strain developer down 25% so far this week, its biggest weekly loss since at least 2002.
Titan Machinery (TITN) fell 3.52 to 16.27 Â its lowest mark since March. The farm equipment dealer chain's shares were 91% above their December initial offering price, and 52% below their June high.
3:15 p.m. Update: Nasdaq Undercuts As Stocks Extend Losses
By VINCENT MAO
Stocks took a turn for the worse in late trading Thursday. The Nasdaq breached its Sept. 29 low, while the NYSE was close to doing the same.
At 2:46 p.m. EDT, the NYSE composite swooned 4.6%, Nasdaq 4.2%, S&P 500 3.8% and Dow 3.2%. Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges.
Commodities suffered broad-based selling. Crude oil fell $4.56 to $93.97 a barrel. Gold tumbled $43, or 5%, to settle at $844.30 an ounce.
Agricultural and transportation stocks were some of the worst decliners, but losing issues were everywhere.
Hartford Financial Services Group (HIG) dived 7.83, or 21%, to an eight-year low of 30.28. The insurer tumbled on bankruptcy fears.
Group mate Metlife (MET) slid 17%.
Immucor (BLUD) shed 1.32 to 30.75 in heavy trading. The maker of blood-testing gear was up 5% on the heels of its fiscal Q1 reports, but investors registered a big change of heart.
DXP Enterprises (DXPE) dumped 3.24, or 12%, to 22.76 in active trading. That puts the industrial equipment maker 33% off its Sept.
22 all-time high.
Urban Outfitters (URBN) dropped 2.03, or 6%, to 29.58 and sliced its 200-day moving average. The youth-oriented clothing retailer has been down each day this week.
About 95 of the IBD 100 components traded lower.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Stuck In Deep Red
By VINCENT MAO
Stocks were near their worst levels of the session midday Thursday, as rebound efforts appeared to have waned.
At 12:43 p.m. EDT, the NYSE composite dumped 3.5%, Nasdaq 3.1%, S&P 500 2.9% and Dow 2.4%.
Turnover was again tracking higher across the board.
Crude oil tumbled $3.40 to $95.13 a barrel. Even gold lost its luster. The December contract swooned $44.60 to $842.70 an ounce.

General Electric (GE) gapped down and slumped 2.05, or 8%, to 22.45 in heavy trading. The conglomerate priced an offering of 547.8 million shares at 22.25 each Â a discount from Wednesday's close of 24.50. GE has been hammered in recent weeks because of its financial exposure. The firm's finance arm accounts for about half of its annual sales. It was the biggest percentage loser in the Dow.
Trucking issues tanked after Con-Way (CNW) cut its full-year profit outlook. Demand fears also hurt truckers.
Old Dominion Freight Lines (ODFL) tumbled 3.83, or 13%, to a near nine-month low of 24.40.
Arkansas Best (ABFS) gapped below its 200-day, sliding 3.44, or 10%, to 30.56.
Heavy-volume gainers were nearly nonexistent.
Abbott Laboratories (ABT) climbed 0.97 to 59.26 in fast trade. The health care products firm reports earnings Oct. 15. Views are for 77 cents a share, up 15%.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Dig In With A Big Shovel
By ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Weak factory orders and a seven-year high in jobless claims seized the day, as indexes drove lower in increasing volume in late morning trade.
The NYSE composite continued to play point, down 3.3% at 11:00 a.m.

EDT. The Nasdaq composite crumpled 2.7% while the S&P 500 and the Dow shed 2.4% and 2.1% apiece. Dow components Caterpillar (CAT), IBM (IBM) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) all took heavy hits. Ebay (EBAY), Apple (AAPL) and Amazon.com (AMZN) weighed heavy on the Nasdaq.
Volume pressed higher on both side of the aisle, up 14% on the NYSE and 10% higher on the Nasdaq. Mid-caps also saw heavy selling, with the S&P 400 down 3.5%.
Commodities moved lower. Oil skidded $3.84 to below $95 a barrel.
Natural gas, grains, metals and gold all drove to lower ground. The dollar launched into its fourth straight day of gains vs. other major currencies.

Fertilizer makers continued taking the largest hits on the boards after a weak earnings report late Wednesday from group leader Mosaic, which tumbled 20.85 to 40.66. Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) tripped 29.65 to 98.39. CF Holdings (CF) dropped 22.82 to 65.82.
Other agriculture-related issues were also dragged lower.
Seed and grain processor Bunge (BG) scythed off a 12.09 loss to 50.91. Its shares are mired in a nine-month correction that has now erased all the stock's gains since July '07.
Monsanto (MON) withered 15.62 to 82.22. That put the genetic seed strain developer down 23% so far this week, it's biggest weekly loss since at least 2002.
Overseas, markets were mixed across Asia, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index jumping 1.1% and the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo crumbling 1.9%.
Shanghai's market remained closed on holiday.

Stocks moved generally lower in Europe and the U.K. as a weak read on U.S. factory orders overpowered enthusiasm for the senate's approval of a federal financial system rescue. Frankfurt's DAX slipped 1.3%.
The CAC-40 in Paris shed 0.5% and London's FTSE 100 whittled off a 0.6% loss.
10:15 a.m. Update: Jobless Claims, Uncertainty Pressure Stocks In Early Trade
By VINCENT MAO
Stocks opened lower and headed further south Thursday following an unexpected jump in jobless claims and uncertainty ahead of Friday's second House vote.
At 9:55 a.m. EDT, the NYSE composite was down 2.3%, the S&P 500 1.7%, the Dow 1.6% and the Nasdaq 1.4%.
Volume was tracking lower on both exchanges.
Agriculture-related issues got slammed following Mosaic's (MOS) worse-than-expected earnings.
Monsanto (MON) gapped down and sank 18.79, or 19%, to 79.08 on a downgrade. Merrill Lynch cut the stock to neutral from buy.
Group mates Bunge (BG) and Syngenta (SYT) fell 11% and 9%, respectively.

Elsewhere, Con-Way (CNW) gapped down and dived 6.12, or 14%, to 36.82 on a lowered outlook. Citing a "challenging" business environment, the freight transport firm pegged full-year earnings from continuing operations of $2.60 to $2.80 a share, down from a prior range of $3 to $3.40. Views are for $3.22 a share. Stifel Nicolaus cut shares to hold from buy.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Weak Start
By VINCENT MAO
Stock futures pointed to a lower open Thursday, despite the Senate's passage of the financial rescue plan. A spike in jobless claims didn't help.
Nasdaq futures dropped 16 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures lost 11 points and Dow futures shed 73 points.

Late Wednesday, the Senate passed a sweetened $700 billion bailout package by 74-25. The revised bill includes tax breaks for businesses and the middle class. It also raised the federal deposit insurance cap to $250,000 from $100,000. The House, which rejected the bill earlier this week, is expected to vote again on Friday.

In economic news, initial jobless claims rose by 1,000 to 497,000 Â a seven-year high. Economists expected a drop to 475,000. The Labor Department's jobs report will be out Friday. A loss of 105,000 job is expected.

UBS (UBS) rose 2% in the pre-market after it said it would be profitable this quarter. In a press release, the Swiss bank said "despite recent extremely volatile market conditions, UBS currently expects to report a small profit for the third quarter, based on preliminary estimates. The bank also substantially reduced its U.S.
commercial and residential mortgage-related positions, mainly through disposals."
Analysts expect UBS to post Q3 earnings of 43 cents a share. It lost money the prior four quarters. Deutsche Bank upgraded UBS shares to buy from hold.
American International Group (AIG) reportedly is preparing for an asset sale. Shares of the troubled insurer rose 7% in the pre-open.

Meanwhile, Mosaic (MOS) plunged 20% after it missed views. After Wednesday's close, the fertilizer maker reported Q1 earnings of $2.65 a share, up from 68 cents the prior year but 29 cents below analyst expectations. Goldman Sachs cut Mosaic shares to neutral from buy, while Merrill Lynch downgraded the stock to underperform from buy.

Merrill gave the same downgrade to Mosaic group mates Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) and Agrium (AGU) the same downgrade.5:15 p.m. Update: It was a complicated day. Earnings growth is the trait that separates true market winners from the rest of the pack. In fact, this factor is so vital that it makes up the first two letters of CAN SLIM.
Companies are in business to provide certain goods and services, but their real aim is making money for shareholders.
If a firm isn't delivering on the bottom line and growing its business, there's just no reason for share prices to move up.
After all, the price of a stock is a function of the company's future earnings potential.
With that said, what should you look for in profit growth? And how much growth should you look for?
First, you want to find companies that grew earnings per share by a minimum of 25% in the latest quarter or past two quarters. Larger percentage increases are even better.
Just make sure you compare the current quarter's results with the same period a year earlier.
The 25% increase is just a floor. Often the best-performing companies will deliver quarterly profit growth well above that.
Research into the most successful stocks from 1952 to 2001 found that they averaged more than a 70% surge in the latest quarter before they began their major advances.
Case in point, fertilizer and animal feed producer Mosaic (MOS) reported a 1,940% explosion in fiscal third-quarter income back in early April. The stock has gained about 23% since then.
Other companies such as Continental Resources (CLR), CF Industries Holdings (CF) and Arch Coal (ACI) posted triple-digit earnings growth in their latest reported periods.
All of these names have been among the best-performing stocks after breaking out of bases.
Besides the percentage increase, look at the actual earnings figure.
If the firm posted a 400% surge in per-share profit by earning a nickel, up from a penny a year ago, you might take that with a grain of salt.
Also, you should deduct one-time items from results to get a good apples-to-apples comparison.

If growth is good, acceleration is even better. That's when the rate of increase improves over consecutive quarters. For example, EPS gains will be 40% one quarter, 45% the next and then 50% in the following period. Accelerating growth tells you there's an important trend under way.
IBD's research found that in most of the the biggest stock market winners, earnings growth accelerated sometime in the 10 quarters before starting their major moves.

On the flip side, watch out for deceleration or slowing growth. Every company can have a bad quarter now and then. But beware if you see two straight quarters of a substantial slowdown. Generally, that means a two-thirds deterioration in EPS growth.
In addition to strong quarterly growth, you want to see evidence that the company has delivered increases on a longer-term basis.
Annual profit growth should be up at least 25% for at least three years in a row.
There are many resources in IBD and Investors.com that can help investors find companies with stellar profit growth.
Stocks In The News, the IBD 100, Your Weekly Review and other features are focused on companies with superior earnings growth.
IBD's EPS Rating calculates long-term and recent quarterly results and ranks those results for every stock on a scale of 1 to 99, with 99 being best.

The G-forces increased on agricultural commodities Wednesday as wheat, corn and cotton steepened already sheer climbs after another cutback in the USDA's monthly crop outlook. Agricultural stocks remained unusually mum, however, with only a small group of stocks lifted specifically by bullish earnings releases. Agricultural chemicals makers Syngenta (SYT) and Agrium (AGU) rose 4% and 3%, respectively, after solid Q4â¦

Stocks plummeted Thursday, as concerns over the fate of the government's rescue plan combined with a spate of weak economic data to roil the market. The Nasdaq dived 4.5%. The Dow industrials plunged 3.2%, the S&P 400 4%, the NYSE composite 4.8%. Small caps fared worst, as the S&P 600 tumbled 5.1%. Volume jumped 15% on both the Nasdaq andâ¦

The stock market went back to its losing ways Wednesday, as the major indexes erased all of the prior day's solid gains. The Nasdaq led the way with a 2.6% plunge. The S&P 500 caved in 2.3%, while the Dow tumbled 2.1% and the NYSE composite 1.7%. All closed at intraday lows after surrendering modest morning gains. It was dishearteningâ¦
5:15 p.m. Update:Â A mixed round of earnings reports sent stocks scrambling for direction Wednesday. Only the Nasdaq finished with gains, while other indexes stepped back.
The Nasdaq rallied 0.5%, helped by Apple (AAPL) and Starbucks (SBUX). That marked the index's 11th straight gain. Its last 11-session win streak was in September 1996.
Meanwhile, the Dow fell 0.4%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 were essentially flat.
Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) erased early losses and ran 7% in heavy trading. The Chinese online gamer is forming a cup base
NetEase.com (NTES) extended its win streak to 10 sessions. It gained 5% to a new all-time high. That puts shares 12% past a 38.84 buy point from a second pullback to its 10-week moving average.
Changyou.com (CYOU) added nearly 2% in fast trade. But it pulled back after touching a new record high. Shares were up as much as 10%.

On the downside, Aaron's (AAN) gapped below its 50-day moving average and tumbled 14% in more than four-times average trade. The furniture and appliance rental firm reported Q2 sales below views and cut its full-year revenue forecast.
Allegiant Travel (ALGT) gapped down and shed 9% after missing earnings views by a penny. The stock has potential support from its 50-day and 200-day lines a few ticks below.
P.F. Chang's China Bistro (PFCB) reversed from a near 52-week high and dropped 7% despite delivering Q2 earnings above views and raising guidance.

Thursday brings a wave of earnings reports from 3M (MMM), Amazon.com (AMZN), American Express (AXP), AT&T (T), BJ's Restaurants (BJRI), Bristol-Myer Squibb (BMY), CME Group (CME), Diamond Offshore (DO), EMC (EMC), McDonald's (MCD), Netflix (NFLX), Newmont Mining (NEM), Northrop Grumman (NOC) and Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT).
4:15 p.m. Update: Nasdaq Rises While Others Slip
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes closed mixed after a seesaw session Wednesday.
The Nasdaq was the lone gainer, rising 0.5%. The Dow lost 0.4%, while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 were fractionally lower.
According to preliminary data, volume fell on both major exchanges.
Homebuilders, media companies and Internet service providers were among the session's top winners. Specialty steel, appliance and home furnishing firms were some of the worst performers.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Remain Mixed In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Blue chips struggled while other indexes held nice gains in late trade Wednesday.
The Nasdaq was up 0.6%, on pace for its 11th straight gain. Back in August 1979, the tech-heavy index rallied for 19 straight sessions.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 0.2%.
The Dow shed 0.2% as losses in Coca-Cola (KO), IBM (IBM) and Caterpillar (CAT) continued to weigh.
Volume was tracking lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq.
Chinese online gamers remained strong. Changyou.com (CYOU) rallied 6%, but that was down from 10% at session peak. NetEase.com (NTES) climbed 5%, while Perfect World (PWRD) rose 3%.
Yahoo (YHOO) bounced back from a 4% loss, gaining 3%.

Reporting earnings after the close: Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Citrix Systems (CTXS), eBay (EBAY), F5 Networks (FFIV), Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), Mosaic (MOS), NVE Corp. (NVEC), Qualcomm (QCOM), SanDisk (SNDK) and Steel Dynamics (STLD).
2:15 p.m. Update: Rally Loses Steam In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes turned mixed as the Dow slipped back into negative territory.
The Nasdaq pared a 1% gain to 0.6%. Still, chip stocks showed strength again as the Philadelphia semiconductor index jumped 2.4% to a nine-month high.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and S&P 500 rose 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively.
The Dow slipped 0.1%, dragged down by losses in Coca-Cola (KO), IBM (IBM) and Caterpillar (CAT).
Turnover was again tracking lighter on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq.
Millicom International Cellular (MICC) added 4% to trade at a 10-month high. The telecom service firm cleared a cup base within a larger pattern Tuesday.
On the downside, Allegiant Travel (ALGT) gapped down and fell 6% in heavy trading. Late Tuesday, the air carrier said Q2 income soared 800% to $1.17 a share. But it missed views by a penny.
ICU Medical (ICUI) dropped 5%, slicing its 50-day moving average. That extended Tuesday's 8% decline.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Strengthen In Early Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Led by the Nasdaq, stocks perked up in early afternoon trading Wednesday.
The tech-laden index climbed 0.7% to a new nine-month high.
Other indexes turned green after seesawing all morning. The NYSE composite rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 0.3% and the Dow 0.2%.
Volume was tracking mixed with the NYSE lower and the Nasdaq slightly higher.

Starbucks (SBUX) gapped up 18% to a 52-week high. Late Tuesday, the coffee giant beat views with a 50% jump in Q2 earnings. That snapped five straight quarters of profit declines. Earlier Wednesday, Deutsche Bank raised shares to hold from sell and bumped its price target to 14 from 9.
On the downside, Fuqi International (FUQI) dropped 11% in heavy trading after announcing a public offering of 4.5 million shares. It was down as much as 19% at session low.

Aaron's (AAN) gapped below its 50-day moving average, tumbling 13% in monster trade. Before the open, the appliance and electronics rental firm reported Q2 earnings above views, but its sales missed estimates. The company also lowered its full-year revenue outlook. Raymond James and Cowen & Co. downgraded the stock, but Stifel Nicolaus upgraded shares.
12:15 p.m. Update: Market Turns Mixed At Midday
BY JONAH KERIStocks turned mixed at midday Wednesday as the major indexes continued to trade in a narrow range.
The Nasdaq gained 0.3%. The Dow industrials edged down 0.1%, the S&P 500 and NYSE composite less than 0.1%.
Volume remained mixed. It fell 18% on the NYSE and swelled 3% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.
A spate of Chinese dot-coms fared well Wednesday.
Changyou.com (CYOU) advanced 6% in more than triple its normal trade. The online gaming company's stock hit an all-time high.
Fellow online gaming firm Perfect World (PWRD) gained 4% in nearly triple its usual turnover.
Internet gaming and Web portal provider NetEase.com (NTES) also marched to a new high, adding 4% in nearly twice its average volume.
Chinese software developer VanceInfo Technologies (VIT) climbed 6% in brisk trade as it flirted with new highs.

Elsewhere, Human Genome Sciences (HGSI) added 2% in rapid turnover. The biotech firm's stock continued to gain ground after soaring 277% on Monday, when the company reported encouraging clinical results for its experimental lupus drug.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Trade In Narrow Range
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes were nearly unchanged in late-morning action Wednesday, as investors weighed a raft of earnings news.
The technology-laden Nasdaq gained 0.2%, the S&P 500 0.1%, the Dow industrials less than 0.1%. The NYSE composite dipped less than 0.1%, weighed by sagging energy and banking stocks.
Volume remained mixed. It fell 20% on the NYSE and swelled 8% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.
Universal Travel Group (UTA) jumped 6% in massive volume. The China-based travel services provider and recent IPO is 3% off its all-time high, set June 12.
Also on the China front, online gaming firm Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) ramped 4% in more than twice its normal trade. The stock is working on a shallow base after peaking in early June.

Vanda Pharmaceuticals (VNDA) also rose 4% in rapid turnover. The maker of compounds used to treat central nervous system disorders is in the eighth week of a base formed after surging off the stocks bottom in early May.
10:15 a.m. Update: Market Opens Higher
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks started Wednesday's session with modest gains, as the tech-laden Nasdaq fared best in early trading.
The Nasdaq gained 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.2%, the Dow 0.3% and the NYSE less than 0.1%.
Volume was mixed. It fell 13% on the NYSE and swelled 22% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.
Tech stocks led the way early on, buoyed by Apple's (AAPL) bullish earnings report late Tuesday. The iPod and iPhone maker gapped up at the opening bell, rising 4% in massive turnover.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) ramped up 3% in brisk volume. The Mexican fast food chain is set to announce quarterly results after today's close. The stock broke out of a two-month base this week.
Meanwhile, Spartan Motors (SPAR) soared 10% in heavy trade. The maker of car and truck parts is slated to report quarterly results on Thursday.

On the downside, ArcSight (ARST) slid 4% in brisk volume. The maker of enterprise security management software has wiped out its recent breakout, but the stock has found support above its 50-day moving average.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Fall In Pre-Market Trade
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes lost ground ahead of Wednesday's opening bell, pulling back after a weeklong rally pushed stocks to their highest point in several months.
Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow industrials futures all traded lower.
Corporate earnings news continued to dominate the headlines.
Aerospace giant Boeing (BA) reported second-quarter profit that topped views by 20 cents. The company credited higher defense sales and lower costs in its commercial aircraft.
Drug maker Pfizer (PFE) and beverage producer PepsiCo (PEP) both reported declines in year-over-year earnings, but both also beat Wall Street forecasts.
Appliance maker Whirlpool (WHR) also smashed expectations despite a 33% drop in year-over-year profit.
The news wasn't as bright in the financial sector.
Shares of Morgan Stanley (MS) slid 5% in pre-market action after it reported a Q2 loss of more than $1.2 billion, which was fattened by the firm's payback of TARP funds.
Fellow bank Wells Fargo (WFC) topped second-quarter earnings views. But shares tumbled 6% on the news that credit losses swelled in Q2 due to the weak economy and higher unemployment.
Those results came after Yahoo (YHOO) and Apple (AAPL) reported late Tuesday.
Yahoo's earnings picked up for the first time since early 2008, but sales turned lower. That sent the stock down 4%.

Apple fared better, beating earnings and revenue estimates thanks to healthy sales of laptops and iPhones. Shares gained 4%.5:15 p.m. Update:Â A mixed round of earnings reports sent stocks scrambling for direction Wednesday. 5:15 p.m. Update:Â Major indexes closed in split fashion Friday. Stocks opened higher, hit their highs late morning, then traded sideways for most of the session. But a round of late selling pushed most indexes lower.

The NYSE composite rose 0.2%, after having been up 1.1% at session peak. The Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq lost 0.2%. During the session, the tech-laden index pulled back after hitting its 200-day moving average.
Volume dropped off sharply ahead of the Memorial Day weekend.
For the week, major indexes finished higher. The NYSE climbed 2.2%, thanks in part to energy issues. Other indexes edged higher. The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 0.5%, the Dow 0.1%.
Leaders up or down in volume were few.
Aeropostale (ARO) climbed 4% in about double its average volume. The apparel retailer jumped after its stellar Q1 earnings and outlook Thursday.
NetEase.com (NTES) rose 3% in heavy trading. That was good for an all-time high. The Chinese Internet firm emerged from a recent pullback to its 10-week moving average.
Salesforce.com (CRM) gapped below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages in nearly four times average trade. The enterprise software company fell on a weak outlook and downgrade.

Quality Systems (QSII) edged down 2% in brisk trade, its fourth straight decline. The stock cleared a three-weeks-tight pattern Monday but then quickly fell 8% over the next few session. Potential support from its 50-day line lies below.
Elsewhere, the S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Index and the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index will be out Tuesday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks End Mixed In Lackluster Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes finished mixed in light, preholiday volume Friday. A late-session turnaround sent most indexes lower.
The Dow and Nasdaq lost 0.2% each. Both had been up 0.9% and 1% respectively. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1%.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite was the lone gainer, up 0.2%.
Turnover dropped sharply ahead of the three-day weekend. Decliners beat advancers 5-to-4 on the Nasdaq. Breadth was above even on the NYSE.
Oil, agriculture-related and computer stocks were among the day's top performers. Mortgage and leisure-related firms fell.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Stuck Sideways In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks were stuck in range-bound fashion as trading slowed to a crawl late Friday. On the bright side, equities were poised to close the week with gains.
The NYSE led with a 0.9% advance. The Dow rose 0.8%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.7%.
Volume was tracking 20% lower on the NYSE and 28% lower on the Nasdaq.
Recent IPOs pulled back.
OpenTable (OPEN) shed 8%. The online restaurant reservation firm came public Thursday, where it surged nearly 60%.
SolarWinds (SWI) lost 3%. The network software maker came public Wednesday, gaining 10% in its debut.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Find Resistance Near Morning Highs
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks rebounded after taking a breather, but they again pulled back after failing to take out their morning highs.
The NYSE composite and Dow were up 0.6% and 0.4%, respectively. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 rose 0.3% each.
Turnover was tracking 17% lower on the NYSE and 26% lower on the Nasdaq.

In merger and acquisition news, Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) agreed to buy Cougar Biotechnology (CGRB) for about $1 billion in cash in an effort to strengthen its line of cancer drugs. Cougar roared ahead 16%. J&J shares were fractionally higher.

Meanwhile, Sears Holdings (SHLD) gapped above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages, vaulting 14%. Late Thursday, the struggling retailer delivered a surprising profit of 38 cents a share ex items. Analysts expected a loss of 88 cents. Sales, however, fell 9%.

Fertilizer makers Agrium (AGU), Mosaic (MOS) and Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) each rallied 4% in heavy trading. Citigroup upgraded each to buy. The broker cited an improving outlook for grain prices.
On the downside, Tech Data (TECD) dropped 7% in active trading, giving back most of Thursday's gain. Citigroup cut the computer peripherals distributor to hold from buy on valuation.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Pull Back In Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes trimmed gains but remained higher in early afternoon trading Friday.
The NYSE composite was up 0.7%, down from about 1.1% at its session peak. The Dow and S&P 500 were up 0.5% and 0.3%, while the Nasdaq edged up 0.2%.
Volume was again tracking vastly lower across the board.
Peet's Coffee & Tea (PEET) rose 2% in brisk volume. It may be setting up a handle in a larger base. The coffee chain was featured in Friday's New America.
Neutral Tandem (TNDM) reversed earlier losses and climbed 2%. The provider of wireless telecom services turned higher after bouncing off its 50-day moving average.

On the downside, Zumiez (ZUMZ) gapped below its 200-day and 50-day moving averages, tumbling 15%. Late Thursday, the action sports clothing and accessories retailer reported a smaller-than-expected Q1 loss but gave a disappointing outlook for the second quarter. Earlier Friday, Robert W. Baird cut shares to neutral from outperform, while a couple of analysts lowered Zumiez's earnings estimates.

Salesforce.com (CRM) also gapped below its 200-day and 50-day lines, dropping 8%. After Thursday's close, the enterprise software maker trounced views with an 88% jump in Q1 earnings. But the firm lowered its full-year sales outlook. Citigroup on Friday downgraded shares to hold from buy.
12:15 p.m. Update: Market Retains Gains At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks traded higher at midday Friday, with volume drying up ahead of the long Memorial Day weekend.
The Nasdaq rose 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.6% and the Dow industrials 0.7%. The NYSE composite gained 0.9%.
Volume eased across the board. It sank 17% on the NYSE and 27% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Thursday.

Icici Bank5:15 p.m. Update:Â Major indexes closed in split fashion Friday. Stocks opened higher, hit their highs late morning, then traded sideways for most of the session. But a round of late selling pushed most indexes lower.The NYSE composite rose 0.2%, after having been up 1.1% at session peak. The Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq lost 0.2%. During the session, the tech-laden index pulled back after hitting its 200-day moving average.Volume dropped off sharply ahead of the Memorial Day weekend.For the week, major indexes finished higher. The NYSE climbed 2.2%, thanks in part to energy issues. Other indexes edged higher. The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 0.5%, the Dow 0.1%.Leaders up or down in volume were few.Aeropostale (ARO) climbed 4% in about double its average volume. The apparel retailer jumped after its stellar Q1 earnings and outlook Thursday.NetEase.com (NTES) rose 3% in heavy trading. That was good for an all-time high. The Chinese Internet firm emerged from a recent pullback to its 10-week moving average.Salesforce.com (CRM) gapped below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages in nearly four times average trade. The enterprise software company fell on a weak outlook and downgrade.Quality Systems (QSII) edged down 2% in brisk trade, its fourth straight decline. The stock cleared a three-weeks-tight pattern Monday but then quickly fell 8% over the next few session. Potential support from its 50-day line lies below.Elsewhere, the S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Index and the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index will be out Tuesday.4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks End Mixed In Lackluster TradeBY VINCENT MAOMajor indexes finished mixed in light, preholiday volume Friday. Stocks rallied into the close Friday, fueled by a strong November job report that seemed to clear the path for a Fed rate hike at the Dec. 15-16 meeting.

The major indexes recovered their Thursday losses and then some, as the Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average each rose 2.1% while the S&P 500 gained 2%. Volume was slightly lower on both main exchanges, according to preliminary data.
Winners topped losers by nearly 2-to-1 on both exchanges. The Dow was green across the board, with tech heavyweights Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) leading with gains of more than 3% each.
Specialty retail, airlines and builders were among the top gainers in the stock market today. The specialty retail group jumped 7%, primarily due to a 13% jump by Ulta Beauty (ULTA).

The beauty store and salon operator also led IBD 50 stocks as it gapped up and vaulted to a new high. Shares cleared a base after the beauty store operator reported quarterly results that topped views late Thursday.

Fellow IBD 50 stock Alaska Air (ALK) soared 5% in fast trade, marking a new high. The stock is still in buy range from the 82.88 buy point of a late-stage flat base initially cleared Wednesday. Hawaiian (HA) lifted 3%.

Among new issues, Fitbit (FIT) jumped into action with a 10% surge in twice the usual pace. It rallied 14% for the week as it continues to move off its Nov. 23 intraday low. Fitbit shipped 4.7 million units worldwide in Q3 to remain the top vendor of wearables, which includes smartwatches and fitness tracking devices, according to an IDC report released Thursday.
Energy stocks sagged as OPEC surprised at a meeting in Vienna by deciding to keep output at current near-record levels. West Texas intermediate crude prices fell more than 3% to $39.97 a barrel.
Railroads and shipping stocks also declined.

5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks closed mixed following a choppy session Tuesday. Most indexes hit new multimonth highs, but the Dow lagged.

The NYSE composite climbed 0.4%, boosted by fertilizer producers, airlines and oil drillers. Financials also lifted the index. Goldman Sachs (GS) gained 2%, despite the fact that analyst Meredith Whitney cut earnings estimates.
The S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the Nasdaq ticked up a fraction. Meanwhile, the Dow slipped 0.1% as losses in IBM (IBM) and Travelers (TRV) offset gains in Boeing (BA) and Kraft Foods (KFT).
Volume surged across the board.

Valassis Communications (VCI) rallied 9% in nearly twice its average volume. It cleared a 19.89 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern. The company provides marketing services such as newspaper inserts, door hangers and direct mail advertising.

5:15 p.m. Update: The market remained firmly in correction mode as indexes failed to rebound from last week's sharp losses.
Declining issues led advancers by better than 2-to-1 throughout the day. Nearly nine in 10 industry groups lost ground for the day.

Aerovironment (AVAV) plunged 30% in after-hours action after missing analyst EPS views and lowering its '09 guidance. The maker of unmanned drone aircraft had broken down below its 40-week level of support for the past two weeks.
Comtech Telecommunications (CMTL) slid 9% after narrowly beating earnings views but falling short of revenue forecasts.

No major economic releases are slated for Tuesday. The dwindling earnings calendar includes Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), General Steel Holdings (GSI) and JA Solar Holdings (JASO) scheduled to report before the market's open. American Public Education (APEI), DXP Enterprises (DXPE) and retailer J. Crew Group (JCG) are among those expected to report after the close.
4:15 p.m. Update: Another Seesaw Day Ends With Losses
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market closed lower, as the Nasdaq made its lowest close since Oct. 16, 2002.
The Nasdaq plunged 2%, the NYSE composite 1.4%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow 1.2.
Volume fell. As in most recent days, the indexes were up early but trended downward throughout the rest of the session.
Insurance stocks were among the worst. UBS downgraded Aflac (AFL) to sell from neutral as analysts questioned the company's exposure to bank investments.
Energy stocks rose as the price of crude topped $47 a barrel.
3:15 p.m. Update: Banks, Mining, Construction Groups Protect Gains
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes continued to struggle near session lows, hobbled by soft trading levels.

The NYSE composite and the Dow each shed 1%. The Nasdaq composite kept to its 1.4% low and the S&P 500 showed a 0.5% loss, aided by gains from MBIA  (MBI), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Bank of America (BAC).

Trading volume remained well below Friday's levels, and declining issues topped advancers by better than 2-to-1 on both exchanges. Among industry groups, super regional banks, mining equipment makers and heavy construction firms continued to post the strongest gains.
Google (GOOG), Dell (DELL), Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA) and Celgene (CELG) showed some of the Nasdaq 100's biggest declines.
Refinery builder Foster Wheeler (FWLT) posted the index's largest gain.
Merck (MRK), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and DuPont De Nemours (DD) headed the Dow's downside.

J2 Global Communications (JCOM) tanked 7%, losing its bid to regain support at its 10-week moving average. The mass-faxing and subscription-based communications company has been living below its 10-week moving average since early February.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Hit Session Lows In Light Volume
BY PATRICK CAIN
Stocks pushed down to session lows as losses piled up.
The Dow fell 1%, the S&P 0.7% and the NYSE composite 1.2%. The Nasdaq lost 1.4%.
Volume was lower across the board.
Google (GOOG) lost 3%. The Internet giant is in a losing streak of late. The stock is down 23% since Feb. 10. Volume has been high on the way down.
Credit card companies Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA) fell 1% each. American Express (AXP) gained 5% and is the top gaining Dow component over $10 a share.
Meridian Bioscience (VIVO), a maker of diagnostic kits and antibodies, slipped 5%. On Friday, William Blair initiated coverage of the firm with a "market perform" rating.

On the upside, Lincoln Education (LINC) gained 8%. The stock may be in its fifth week of a sloppy cup-shaped base. The chart action may also just be a 10-week pullback. The stock's RS line is at a new high.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Slip Lower In Soft Volume
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes backed slowly away from the morning's mild gains, as the energy sector's early gains eased and two-thirds of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD posted losses.
The Nasdaq composite wandered to a 0.7% loss. The NYSE composite slipped 0.5%, the Dow 0.4%. The S&P 500 was flat.
US Bancorp (USB) and Suntrust Banks (STI) each jumped more than 13%. Manitowoc (MTW) and Terex (TEX) gained 7% apiece, hauling the construction and mining equipment makers group higher.
Volume held steadily below Friday's levels.
Crude futures eased from their early highs, but remained more than $1.50 higher at more than $47 a barrel.

Lincoln Educational Services (LINC) jumped 7% in serious volume. The tech school operator reported Thursday its Q4 EPS and sales easily topped analysts' views and it guided '09 results above prior expectations.
S&P 400 issue Quanta Services (PWR) popped 7%. The builder of electrical energy and IT wiring infrastructure is six weeks into a possible base.

Icon (ICLR) tumbled 8%, compounding a four-week dive by the Ireland-based provider of clinical trials for pharmaceutical makers. The tumble killed the stock's effort to construct the right side of a base.
Infection-prevention products maker Steris  (STE) slid 5%, leaving the S&P 400 component at a six-month low.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Seek Direction Near Monday's Halftime
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes were mixed near Monday's halftime. Despite this morning's merger news, stocks have been mostly struggling for direction.
The S&P 500 rose 0.5% and Dow 0.1%. The Nasdaq lost 0.1%, while the NYSE composite eased a fraction.
Volume was again tracking lower across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.
American Italian Pasta (AIPC) dropped 5% in heavy trading. That marks the stock's third straight down day in brisk volume. It was the biggest percentage loser in the IBD 100.

On the upside, financials got a boost from billionaire Warren Buffett. On CNBC, Buffett said that Wells Fargo (WFC) and U.S. Bancorp (USB) should be "better than ever" in three years. Wells and U.S. Bancorp jumped 15% and 13%, respectively.
Allegiant Travel (ALGT) jumped 7% after bouncing off its 200-day moving average Friday. Last week, the air carrier reported increases in February traffic, bucking industry weakness.
Hansen Natural (HANS) added 2% to a nine-month high. Analysts see the beverage maker's earnings surging 95% this year.
11:15 Update: Indexes Struggle To Break Mixed Trading Stalemate
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTTMarkets pushed and pulled, edging higher in soft volume but still in mixed territory in late morning trading.
The S&P 500 held a 0.5% advance, while the Dow and Nasdaq composite each added. 0.2%.
The NYSE remained 0.1% in the red. Schering-Plough (SGP), U.S. Bancorp (USB) and General Electric (GE) posted some of the S&P 500's top gains. Exxon Mobil (XOM) bolstered the Dow with a 2% advance.
The cable and satellite television operators group and life, accident and health insurance providers posted some of the mornings heaviest losses.
Trading volume was lower on both counts, especially on the Nasdaq.

Oil prices surged more than $2 to near $48 a barrel, their highest level since January. Iraq's oil minister told foreign news agencies that current oil prices were not "profitable and fair" for oil producing countries and that OPEC was working to push prices higher. OPEC is widely expected to announce additional production cuts at its March 15 meeting.
Natural gas and gold fell. The dollar slipped vs. the euro, but gained on the yen after Japan reported its first current account deficit in 13 years.
Some agriculture-related issues moved higher. Fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS) and seed strain developer Monsanto (MON) both popped 2% in strong trading.

On the downside, Covance (CVD) dropped 4% in strong volume. The provider of clinical drug trials had attempted to build a right side to a four-month consolidation, but is now threatening to undercut its October lows.

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) gapped down to surrender 3%, despite a rally among most Europe-based drugmakers on news that Merck (MRK) planned to buy rival Schering-Plough for $41.1 billion. Glaxo is trading at its lowest level since 1996.

The Shanghai composite dumped 3.4% while Hong Kong's Hang Seng toppled 4.8%, hurt by a 24% drop by HSBC Holdings (HBC) ahead of its $17.7 billion rights offering scheduled later this week, an effort to shore up its balance sheet. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell back 1.2% to its lowest close since 1982.
Markets in Europe and the U.K. traded mixed, within a narrow range, as gains by energy and pharmaceutical issues offset banking sector losses.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Rebound From Lower Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks opened lower, but have turned narrowly mixed early Monday.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.8%, bouncing back from a six-year low. The S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Dow ticked up a fraction. The NYSE composite lost 0.2%, though it had been down as much as 1.5% within the opening minutes.
Volume was tracking lower across the board.

Rohm & Haas (ROH) rose 8% after a Delaware judge postponed a trial for a few hours so that the chemical maker and Dow Chemicals (DOW) could resume merger talks. Earlier this year, Dow delayed the closing of its buyout of Rohm & Haas.
Amazon.com (AMZN) rose 3% following an upgrade. Piper Jaffray upgraded the Internet retailer to buy from neutral on belief that the company is poised to take more market share.

McDonald's (MCD) edged up 1% after reporting a 1.4% rise in February same-store sales. Still, the fast-food giant warned that commodity costs and a strong dollar would pressure Q1 results and margins.
On the downside, Aflac (AFL) gapped down and tumbled 15% after UBS cut the insurer to sell from neutral on concerns it might be too heavily invested in banks.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Soft Start Despite Buyout News
BY VINCENT MAO
A big merger announcement failed to lift stock futures Monday, pointing to a lower open for equities.
Nasdaq futures dropped 4 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures shed 7 points and Dow futures lost 73 points.

Merck (MRK) will buy rival Schering-Plough (SGP) for about $41.1 billion in cash and stock in an effort to better compete in an environment of slowing sales and rising generic competition. Schering-Plough shares gained 15% in the pre-market, while Merck fell 7%.
Pfizer (PFE), which unveiled a $68 billion buyout of Wyeth (WYE) in January, slipped 2% in the pre-open.
Financials will once again be in the spotlight.
U.K.'s Lloyd's Banking Group (LYG) declined 10% in the pre-market on the news that the UK government will up its stake in the struggling back in exchange for insuring $365 billion of risky assets.
Capital One Financial (COF) joined a slew of banks in cutting dividends. It will slash its quarterly dividend to a nickel a share from 37.5 cents in order to save $500 million a year.
JPMorgan Chase (JPM), PNC Financial Services (PNC), US Bancorp (USB) and Wells Fargo  (WFC) all lowered their dividends recently.
Following Friday's dismal jobs report, more companies announced layoffs.
Newspaper publisher McClatchy (MNI) will eliminate 1,600 jobs, or 15% of its work force.

Eastman Chemical (EMN) said it would cut 200 to 300 jobs over the next four to six weeks and cut base pay for U.S. employees by 5%. The company, which looks to save $100 annually, also guided full-year earnings in a range of $2 to $3 a share vs. views of $2.31.

No economic data are due today. Key reports this week will be retail sales and initial jobless claims, both due Thursday.5:15 p.m. Update: The market remained firmly in correction mode as indexes failed to rebound from last week's sharp losses.Declining issues led advancers by better than 2-to-1 throughout the day.
