Despite this morning's merger news, stocks have been mostly struggling for direction.The S&P 500 rose 0.5% and Dow 0.1%. The Nasdaq lost 0.1%, while the NYSE composite eased a fraction.Volume was again tracking lower across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.American Italian Pasta (AIPC) dropped 5% in heavy trading. That marks the stock's third straight down day in brisk volume. It was the biggest percentage loser in the IBD 100.On the upside, financials got a boost from billionaire Warren Buffett. On CNBC, Buffett said that Wells Fargo (WFC) and U.S. Bancorp (USB) should be "better than ever" in three years. Wells and U.S. Bancorp jumped 15% and 13%, respectively.Allegiant Travel (ALGT) jumped 7% after bouncing off its 200-day moving average Friday. Last week, the air carrier reported increases in February traffic, bucking industry weakness.Hansen Natural (HANS) added 2% to a nine-month high. Analysts see the beverage maker's earnings surging 95% this year.11:15 Update: Indexes Struggle To Break Mixed Trading StalemateBY ALAN R. ELLIOTTThe S&P 500 held a 0.5% advance, while the Dow and Nasdaq composite each added. 0.2%.The NYSE remained 0.1% in the red. Schering-Plough (SGP), U.S. Bancorp (USB) and General Electric (GE) posted some of the S&P 500's top gains. Exxon Mobil (XOM) bolstered the Dow with a 2% advance.The cable and satellite television operators group and life, accident and health insurance providers posted some of the mornings heaviest losses.Trading volume was lower on both counts, especially on the Nasdaq.Oil prices surged more than $2 to near $48 a barrel, their highest level since January. Iraq's oil minister told foreign news agencies that current oil prices were not "profitable and fair" for oil producing countries and that OPEC was working to push prices higher. OPEC is widely expected to announce additional production cuts at its March 15 meeting.Natural gas and gold fell. The dollar slipped vs. the euro, but gained on the yen after Japan reported its first current account deficit in 13 years.Some agriculture-related issues moved higher. Fertilizer maker Mosaic (MOS) and seed strain developer Monsanto (MON) both popped 2% in strong trading.On the downside, Covance (CVD) dropped 4% in strong volume. The provider of clinical drug trials had attempted to build a right side to a four-month consolidation, but is now threatening to undercut its October lows.GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) gapped down to surrender 3%, despite a rally among most Europe-based drugmakers on news that Merck (MRK) planned to buy rival Schering-Plough for $41.1 billion. Glaxo is trading at its lowest level since 1996.The Shanghai composite dumped 3.4% while Hong Kong's Hang Seng toppled 4.8%, hurt by a 24% drop by HSBC Holdings (HBC) ahead of its $17.7 billion rights offering scheduled later this week, an effort to shore up its balance sheet. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell back 1.2% to its lowest close since 1982.Markets in Europe and the U.K. traded mixed, within a narrow range, as gains by energy and pharmaceutical issues offset banking sector losses.10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Rebound From Lower OpenBY VINCENT MAOStocks opened lower, but have turned narrowly mixed early Monday.The Nasdaq climbed 0.8%, bouncing back from a six-year low. The S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Dow ticked up a fraction. The NYSE composite lost 0.2%, though it had been down as much as 1.5% within the opening minutes.Volume was tracking lower across the board.Rohm & Haas (ROH) rose 8% after a Delaware judge postponed a trial for a few hours so that the chemical maker and Dow Chemicals (DOW) could resume merger talks. Earlier this year, Dow delayed the closing of its buyout of Rohm & Haas.Amazon.com (AMZN) rose 3% following an upgrade. Piper Jaffray upgraded the Internet retailer to buy from neutral on belief that the company is poised to take more market share.McDonald's (MCD) edged up 1% after reporting a 1.4% rise in February same-store sales. Still, the fast-food giant warned that commodity costs and a strong dollar would pressure Q1 results and margins.On the downside, Aflac (AFL) gapped down and tumbled 15% after UBS cut the insurer to sell from neutral on concerns it might be too heavily invested in banks.9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Soft Start Despite Buyout NewsBY VINCENT MAOA big merger announcement failed to lift stock futures Monday, pointing to a lower open for equities.Nasdaq futures dropped 4 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures shed 7 points and Dow futures lost 73 points.Merck (MRK) will buy rival Schering-Plough (SGP) for about $41.1 billion in cash and stock in an effort to better compete in an environment of slowing sales and rising generic competition. Schering-Plough shares gained 15% in the pre-market, while Merck fell 7%.Pfizer (PFE), which unveiled a $68 billion buyout of Wyeth (WYE) in January, slipped 2% in the pre-open.Financials will once again be in the spotlight.U.K.'s Lloyd's Banking Group (LYG) declined 10% in the pre-market on the news that the UK government will up its stake in the struggling back in exchange for insuring $365 billion of risky assets.Capital One Financial (COF) joined a slew of banks in cutting dividends. It will slash its quarterly dividend to a nickel a share from 37.5 cents in order to save $500 million a year.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), PNC Financial Services (PNC), US Bancorp (USB) and Wells Fargo  (WFC) all lowered their dividends recently.Following Friday's dismal jobs report, more companies announced layoffs.Newspaper publisher McClatchy (MNI) will eliminate 1,600 jobs, or 15% of its work force.Eastman Chemical (EMN) said it would cut 200 to 300 jobs over the next four to six weeks and cut base pay for U.S. employees by 5%. The company, which looks to save $100 annually, also guided full-year earnings in a range of $2 to $3 a share vs. views of $2.31.No economic data are due today. Key reports this week will be retail sales and initial jobless claims, both due Thursday.
5:15 p.m. Update:Â Volume picked up in afternoon trading, apparently marking a follow-through rally confirmation for the NYSE indexes.
Current information showed volume ended higher on both major exchanges, a necessary ingredient for a follow-through.
Medical sectors issues led the gains through most of the day, overpowering some weak economic news and a credit downgrade on General Electric (GE).
Financials kicked in and took control later in the day, after Bank of America (BAC) Chief Executive Kenneth Lewis said his bank wouldn't need additional bailout funding to get through the recession.
Oil prices pitched in to drive energy stocks higher, with the April crude contract spiking 11% to above $47 a barrel. April natural gas jumped more than 5%.

In after-hours trading, Aeropostale (ARO) dropped 5%. The speciality teen retailer reported Q4 earnings gained 31%, above analyst expectations. The company guided first-quarter earnings below expectations. Shares are climbing out of a deep consolidation.

Smith & Wesson  (SWHC) rose 13%, adding to a 15% spike in the regular session. The firearms maker reported fiscal Q3 earnings of five cents, above views. Shares are working their way up the right side of a cup-shaped base.

Friday's economic calendar includes the release of February export and import prices and January trade balance data from the Labor and Commerce departments before the market opens. The University of Michigan will deliver its preliminary consumer sentiment index numbers for March at 10 a.m. EDT.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Surge, But Volume Is Questionable
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market closed sharply higher Thursday, though volume wasn't impressive.
The Nasdaq, NYSE composite and S&P 500 soared 4%, while the Dow was up 3.4% at the closing bell.
Volume rose on the Nasdaq but fell on the NYSE, according to early readings. Higher volume on the NYSE would have marked a follow-through on those indexes' new rally attempt.

Financials led after Bank of America  (BAC) CEO Kenneth Lewis said the bank was profitable in January and February, echoing remarks from Citigroup (C) and JPMorgan (JPM) CEOs earlier this week. Lewis also said BofA should be able to get through the recession without new help from taxpayers.
Health care stocks also were strong after Gilead Sciences (GILD) agreed to acquire CV Therapeutics  (CVTX).
3:15 p.m. Update: Rally Holds As Nasdaq Volume Goes Green

5:15 p.m. Update:Â The major indexes ended comparatively flat for the day, but a dull finish masked a number of notable moves.

The Transportation-Shipping group gained 1.5% on a massive surge in volume, tripling the prior single-day trading record for stocks in the group. The basis for the move was a 14-day, 82% rise in the Baltic Dry Index, the gauge for pricing strength among dry bulk fleets. DryShips (DRYS), TBI International (TBSI), Genco Shipping and Trading (GNK) and Excel Maritime (EXM) were among the beneficiaries.

The Fertilizer Makers group added 1.1% in its sixth straight day of gains. More important, nearly 52 million shares traded hands, the group's biggest volume advance on record. Intrepid Potash (IPI) surged 7% and Terra Nitrogen (TNH) added 5%.
Hospitals, silver and gold miners, and the wholesale computer and cell phone groups took the day's hardest hits.

For Tuesday. the Commerce Department will deliver wholesale inventory numbers at 10 a.m. EST. On the earnings side, Intercontinental Exchange (ICE), Vishay (VSH), Cynosure (CYNO) and AECOM Technology (ACM) are slated to report prior to the opening bell. CB Richard Ellis Group (CBG), CF Industries (CF), HealthSpring (HS) and Mexican wireless heavyweight America Movil (AMX) plan to report after the close.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close Mixed
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The major indexes closed narrowly mixed Monday as the day came and went without an announcement on a bank rescue plan or a vote on a stimulus bill.
The NYSE composite and S&P 500 gained 0.1% while the Dow eased 0.1% and the Nasdaq was off a fraction.
Volume was lower as the market appeared to be waiting for the outcome of both initiatives.
3:15 p.m. Update: Dollar Down, And Oil Fades From Highs; Indexes Slip Lower
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes dug deeper into mild, soft-volume losses in late trading.
The Dow and Nasdaq composite each held 0.5% losses. The NYSE composite slipped 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged 0.2% lower.
Coca-Cola (KO), Home Depot (HD) and Caterpillar (CAT) anchored the downside on the Dow.
News Corp. (NWSA), Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Celgene (CELG) were among the Nasdaq 100's worst hit.
Volume faded lower on both exchanges. Declining issues led advancers by a narrow margin on the NYSE and by a 3-to-2 spread on the Nasdaq.
Crude futures backed off their early gains, holding nearly flat below $40 a barrel. The dollar continued to slump vs. the yen and the euro.

Industrial tool and equipment maker Kennametal (KMT) popped 7% in heavy trading after an upgrade to buy from Keybanc Capital Markets. Shares are six weeks into a possible base within a larger consolidation.

ResMed (RMD) pulled up from an early, gap-down loss to a 4% decline. The maker of treatments for sleep disorders received a downgrade, to neutral, from JPMorgan. Shares are building the right side to a five month, cup-shaped base.
2:15 p.m. Update: Midday Rally Ends As Indexes Go Into The Red.
BY PATRICK CAIN
Stocks went into negative ground as volume remained lower in afternoon trading.
The Dow was down 0.3%, the Nasdaq 0.2%. The S&P 500 and NYSE composite were flat after giving up modest gains.
Cephalon (CEPH), a maker of drugs to treat neurological disorders, erased early losses and was up 1% in strong volume. The stock found support near its 10-week moving average.

Thinly traded EZchip Semiconductor (EZCH) gapped up and gained 9%. The small cap is an Israeli developer of networking chips for high-speed networking switches and routers. The stock is in an odd three-weeks tight as the second week reversed down after being up as much as 15%.

On the downside, Life Partner Holdings (LPHI) fell 4%. The buyer of life insurance policies reversed lower and fell below the 10-week moving average last week. Volume continues to be huge on the way down.
Ctrip.com (CTRP) also fell, losing 3%. The China-based travel company reported earnings of 33 cents a share late Sunday. That topped expectations for 24 cents, and shares had gapped up early.
1:15 p.m. Update: Banks, Energy Lead As Markets Press Higher
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes rolled tentatively higher in light afternoon trading.
The NYSE composite and S&P 500 edged up 0.5% and 0.4%. The Nasdaq composite and the Dow both reversed from losses to add 0.2%.
Health care sectors took hits, with Biogen (BIIB), Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) and DaVita (DVA) all falling in brisk-to-heavy volume.
Huntington Bancshares (HBAN) and Hartford Financial Services Group (HIG) led the S&P 500's topside.
Volume ran softer on both exchanges, down 10% on the NYSE and 16% on the Nasdaq.
Baidu.com (BIDU) gapped up to add 12% in strong trading. The China-based search engine provider has been building a floor to a nine-month correction since November.
ITC Holdings (ITC) punched 5% higher in hot trading, bringing it close to a 46.60 buy point on a cup-with-handle base begun in November.
On the downside, Itron (ITRI) skidded 6% lower, returning the stock to its 50-day moving average. Shares are six weeks into a possible base.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Seesaw Near Session's Halftime
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks were having a hard time deciding which way to go following last week's stellar gains and ahead of more of details on the government's latest efforts to help the economy and the banking sector.
Thanks to energy issues, the NYSE composite was the only index in the green, up 0.2%. The Dow and Nasdaq slipped 0.2%, while the S&P 500 was mostly unchanged.
Turnover was again tracking lower across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.

Sohu.com (SOHU) gapped up and rallied 7% after beating views. Before the open, the Chinese Internet portal delivered Q4 earnings of $1.35 a share, up 214% and 19 cents over views. That marked the fifth straight period of triple-digit growth. It guided Q1 profit in range of $1.05 to $1.10 a share vs. views of $1.01.

Compass Minerals (CMP) gained 2% in fast trade ahead of its earnings report after the close. Analysts see the salt maker earning $2.20 a share, up 68%. Earlier this morning, the company raised its quarterly dividend by 6% or 2 cents a share to 35.5 cents.
Meanwhile, financials were mostly higher. Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and Bank of America (BAC) jumped 13% and 12%, respectively. Citigroup (C) rose 4%.

On the downside, DaVita (DVA) erased early gains and shed 4% to a two-month low. The provider of dialysis services reports earnings Wednesday. After growing in single digits the past three quarters, analysts expect a 14% rise in current quarterly profit.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Turn Mixed As Dollar Slips, Oil Gains
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes washed back and forth in ambivalent trading after the Obama administration opted to delay details of its new bank bailout plan until Tuesday.

Energy and some financial issues hoisted the NYSE composite away from earlier losses and into positive territory, up 0.4%. The Nasdaq composite and Dow both rose from lows but maintained 0.3% losses. The S&P 500 reversed earlier losses and climbed to the break-even mark.

The dollar tumbled against major currencies after news of a stimulus plan delay. Gold slipped more than $16 to near $898 an ounce. Nymex March crude futures rose more than $2 to above $42 a barrel. London's Brent crude benchmark topped $48 a barrel.

Dry-bulk shipping fleets sailed higher after the industry's rate barometer, the Baltic Dry Index, advanced for a 14th straight day. DryShips (DRYS) surged 11% on five times its average volume. Genco Shipping & Trading (GNK) jumped 10%. Eagle Bulk Shipping (EXM) tacked on a 7% gain. TBS International (TBSI) added 6%.
Fertilizers also ran higher. Intrepid Potash (IPI) logged a 6% gain in big volume. Mosaic (MOS) tacked on a 6% gain. Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) popped 3%.

EZ Chip Semiconductor Limited (EZCH) gapped up to add 10%. The thinly traded stock moved on more than 10 times its average trading volume. The enthusiasm did not spill over into the general semiconductor sector; the Philadelphia Semiconductor index dropped 1.4%.

On the downside, Life Partner Holdings (LPHI) sagged 6% in very heavy action. The secondary market purchaser of life insurance policies had been five weeks into a possible base. But the tumble tore open the pattern and left shares well below their 50-day moving average.
In China, the Shanghai composite added 2% to nail a four-month high. China Cosco Holdings, the world's largest dry-bulk shipping fleet operator, pegged its 10% limit on the rising Baltic Dry Index.

Hong Kong's Hang Seng index crept ahead 0.8% to add a fourth day of gains, the exchange's longest rally in two months. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 backed off 1.3%, weighed down by a rising yen and by concerns for a U.S. banking bailout.

U.K. and European markets were mixed in a narrow range. Key indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt hovered just above or below the break-even mark as commodities pulled lower as banks gained ground after a better-than-expected Q4 report from Barclays (BCS).
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Down On Soft Volume
BY VINCENT MAO
Major stock indexes opened lower Monday, then briefly turned mixed before getting shot down soon after.
The Dow fell 0.9%, the Nasdaq 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the NYSE composite 0.1%.
Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board.

ResMed (RMD) shed 6% following two downgrades. JPMorgan cut the maker of breathing machines to neutral from overweight, while Citigroup lowered shares to sell from hold. The downturn erased most of ResMed's gains from Friday's earnings-inspired pop.

Biogen Idec (BIIB) fell 3% after Barclays cut the biotech's shares to underweight from equal weight. Separately, Biogen and Elan (ELN) announced results from a two-year study where five times as many multiple sclerosis patients taking their co-marketed drug Tysabri were free of the disease vs. a placebo.
Rio Tinto (RTP) declined 6% after its chairman-elect resigned less than a month into the job.
On the upside, Hartford Financial Services (HIG) gapped above its 50-day moving average and surged 20% on a report that state regulators might ease its reserve requirement.

McDonald's (MCD) rose a fraction after saying is global same-store sales increased 7.1% year-over-year. Chief Executive Jim Skinner offered a bullish assessment of the results, saying in a statement that the fast-food chain "continues to appeal to customers as we offer high quality, affordable meal options and unparalleled convenience."
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Weaker Start
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures pointed to a lower open Monday, as investors await further details on the Obama administration's stimulus plan.
Nasdaq futures dropped 5 points vs vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures shed 4 points and Dow futures lost 46 points.
The Senate's version of the economic stimulus plan will be debated today, with a vote slated for Tuesday.

Also Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner will unveil details of the bank rescue plan Â a day later than originally planned. Geithner is expected to reveal how the government will use the second half of funds from the $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program.

In corporate news, Nissan (NSANY) announced plans to cut its global work force by 8.5%, or about 20,000 jobs. The automaker also expects its first annual loss in nine years. Shares fell 7% in the pre-market.
Last week group mate Toyota Motor (TM) widened its loss forecast.

Whirlpool (WHR) fell 8% on lackluster earnings and a weak outlook. Hurt by special charges and a strong dollar, the appliance maker's Q4 profit sank to 60 cents a share, down from $2.38 the prior year and 18 cents below views. Sales slumped 19% to $4.3 billion also below views. The company guided full-year earnings in a range of $3 to $4 a share vs. analysts' estimates of $4.12 a share.

Beazer Homes (BZH) narrowed its fiscal Q1 loss to $2.08 a share from $3.59 a year earlier, though that was still worse than Wall Street estimates of a $1.83 per-share shortfall. Sales tumbled 54% to $232.4 million, also below views. Still, the stock surged 17% in the pre-market.

Rohm & Haas (ROH) reported Q4 earnings of 69 cents a share, excluding items. That was down from 91 cents the prior year but 2 cents above views. Sales declined 13% to $2.03 billion, below views. Shares slipped 1%.

Dow Chemical (DOW) recently delayed its proposed buyout of Rohm & Haas.5:15 p.m. Update:Â The major indexes ended comparatively flat for the day, but a dull finish masked a number of notable moves.The Transportation-Shipping group gained 1.5% on a massive surge in volume, tripling the prior single-day trading record for stocks in the group. Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) popped 3%.EZ Chip Semiconductor Limited (EZCH) gapped up to add 10%. The thinly traded stock moved on more than 10 times its average trading volume. The enthusiasm did not spill over into the general semiconductor sector; the Philadelphia Semiconductor index dropped 1.4%.On the downside, Life Partner Holdings (LPHI) sagged 6% in very heavy action. The secondary market purchaser of life insurance policies had been five weeks into a possible base. But the tumble tore open the pattern and left shares well below their 50-day moving average.In China, the Shanghai composite added 2% to nail a four-month high. China Cosco Holdings, the world's largest dry-bulk shipping fleet operator, pegged its 10% limit on the rising Baltic Dry Index.Hong Kong's Hang Seng index crept ahead 0.8% to add a fourth day of gains, the exchange's longest rally in two months. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 backed off 1.3%, weighed down by a rising yen and by concerns for a U.S. banking bailout.U.K. and European markets were mixed in a narrow range. Key indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt hovered just above or below the break-even mark as commodities pulled lower as banks gained ground after a better-than-expected Q4 report from Barclays (BCS).10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Down On Soft Volume BY VINCENT MAOMajor stock indexes opened lower Monday, then briefly turned mixed before getting shot down soon after.The Dow fell 0.9%, the Nasdaq 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the NYSE composite 0.1%.Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board.ResMed (RMD) shed 6% following two downgrades. JPMorgan cut the maker of breathing machines to neutral from overweight, while Citigroup lowered shares to sell from hold. The downturn erased most of ResMed's gains from Friday's earnings-inspired pop.Biogen Idec (BIIB) fell 3% after Barclays cut the biotech's shares to underweight from equal weight. Separately, Biogen and Elan (ELN) announced results from a two-year study where five times as many multiple sclerosis patients taking their co-marketed drug Tysabri were free of the disease vs. a placebo.Rio Tinto (RTP) declined 6% after its chairman-elect resigned less than a month into the job.On the upside, Hartford Financial Services (HIG) gapped above its 50-day moving average and surged 20% on a report that state regulators might ease its reserve requirement.McDonald's (MCD) rose a fraction after saying is global same-store sales increased 7.1% year-over-year. Chief Executive Jim Skinner offered a bullish assessment of the results, saying in a statement that the fast-food chain "continues to appeal to customers as we offer high quality, affordable meal options and unparalleled convenience."9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Weaker StartBY VINCENT MAOStock futures pointed to a lower open Monday, as investors await further details on the Obama administration's stimulus plan.Nasdaq futures dropped 5 points vs vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures shed 4 points and Dow futures lost 46 points.The Senate's version of the economic stimulus plan will be debated today, with a vote slated for Tuesday.Also Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner will unveil details of the bank rescue plan Â a day later than originally planned. Geithner is expected to reveal how the government will use the second half of funds from the $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program.In corporate news, Nissan (NSANY) announced plans to cut its global work force by 8.5%, or about 20,000 jobs. The automaker also expects its first annual loss in nine years. Shares fell 7% in the pre-market.Last week group mate Toyota Motor (TM) widened its loss forecast.Whirlpool (WHR) fell 8% on lackluster earnings and a weak outlook. Hurt by special charges and a strong dollar, the appliance maker's Q4 profit sank to 60 cents a share, down from $2.38 the prior year and 18 cents below views. Sales slumped 19% to $4.3 billion also below views. The company guided full-year earnings in a range of $3 to $4 a share vs. analysts' estimates of $4.12 a share.Beazer Homes (BZH) narrowed its fiscal Q1 loss to $2.08 a share from $3.59 a year earlier, though that was still worse than Wall Street estimates of a $1.83 per-share shortfall. Sales tumbled 54% to $232.4 million, also below views. Still, the stock surged 17% in the pre-market.Rohm & Haas (ROH) reported Q4 earnings of 69 cents a share, excluding items. That was down from 91 cents the prior year but 2 cents above views. Sales declined 13% to $2.03 billion, below views. Shares slipped 1%.Dow Chemical (DOW) recently delayed its proposed buyout of Rohm & Haas.
5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks seesawed to a mixed finish Friday, but capped the week with slight gains.
The Nasdaq had a wild session, thanks to Dell's (DELL) earnings and Intel's (INTC) upbeat sales outlook. It closed with a 0.1% gain after having been up as much as 1.6% and down 0.5%.
Meanwhile, the Dow slipped 0.8%, snapping its eight-session win streak. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 lost 0.2% each.
Volume rose on both exchanges.
For the week, the NYSE composite climbed 0.5% and S&P 500 0.3%. The Dow and Nasdaq rose 0.4% each.
Cubic (CUB) reversed early gains and fell 3% in heavy trading. The military gear maker hasn't scored an up week in over a month.
SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) also lost 3% on brisk volume. The stock continued to pull back from Tuesday's all-time high.

On the upside, J. Crew Group (JCG) gapped up and rallied 8% on nearly four times average volume. Late Thursday, the trendy apparel retailer delivered Q2 results above views. Early Friday, the stock also won upgrades from Barclays, Citigroup and Needham.
4:15 p.m. Update: Techs Eke Out A Gain
BY VINCENT MAO
Techs outshined and scored a slight gain Friday, while the broader market slipped.
The Nasdaq edged up about 0.1%, but closed well off its session high. The Dow fell 0.4%, while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 lost 0.2% each.
Volume climbed sharply on the Nasdaq and dipped on the NYSE.
Medical-related, plastics and tobacco groups were among Friday's worst performers. Jewelry retailers, international oil producers, leisure product makers and chip issues bucked the trend.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Slowly Battle Off Session Lows
BY PATRICK CAIN
Stocks fought their way off session lows, but struggled to go positive. The Nasdaq even touched positive territory for a brief moment, then quickly slipped back down.
The Dow fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.3% and the Nasdaq rested just below break-even. The NYSE composite lost 0.4%.
Volume was higher across the board.

SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) fell 2%. Earlier this week it hit an all-time high. Today was the second day of high-volume selling. The pharmacy benefit manager scored triple-digit earnings growth last quarter. This period, analysts see 173% profit growth.

OSI Systems (OSIS) dropped 5%. The maker of medical monitoring systems reported Q4 results Thursday and sank 12%. Today's selling is an extension of that. So far, shares have found support at its 40-week moving average. Its earnings report showed EPS slowing 19%. Looking forward, Wall Street sees 150% profit growth in Q1.
Dell (DELL) was up only a fraction of its early morning gains. The computer company gained 3%.
Intel (INTC) gave tech stocks a boost with a bullish report.
Volume was huge for both Dell and Intel, which gained 4%.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Stand Ankle-Deep in Red Ink

5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks bobbed and weaved to a higher finish Wednesday. Major indexes opened higher on news that the Treasury might use TARP funds to help insurers. A merger deal in the housing sector also boosted sentiment. But stocks peaked during the lunch hour and gave up further ground following the release of the Fed minutes. A rally in the final hour helped stocks to their first gains in three days.
The Nasdaq climbed 1.9%, S&P 500 1.2%, NYSE composite 1.1% and Dow 0.6%.
Volume rose slightly on the NYSE, but slipped on the Nasdaq.

Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) reversed early losses and climbed nearly 6% in nearly double its average volume. That puts the Chinese online gamer 34% past a 33.70 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.

Jos. A. Bank Clothiers (JOSB) gapped up and surged 20% in huge volume. The men's apparel retailer extended gains from a recent breakout. It cleared a 29.33 buy point from a cup-with-handle base April 2.
Thinly traded NVE Corp. (NVEC) jumped 12% in nearly triple average trade. The maker of spintronic sensors cleared resistance near 35.
On the downside, Neutral Tandem (TNDM) dropped 6% in heavy trading. But the provider of interconnection services was down about 14% during the day.
Initial jobless claims, import and export prices, as well as data on trade balance will be out Thursday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Late Rebound Secure Day's Gains
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks bounced back after from a two-session pullback following a choppy session Wednesday. Major indexes traded mixed a few times during the session, but a late-day rally cemented gains.
The Nasdaq led with a 1.9% gain. The S&P 500 rose 1.2% and the NYSE composite 1.1%. The Dow lagged, rising 0.6%.
According to preliminary data, volume finished higher on both exchanges, but just slightly on the Nasdaq.
Despite a merger between Pulte Homes (PHM) and Centex (CTX), homebuilders put in a mixed performance. Retail issues charged higher ahead of Thursday's release of March same-store sales.
3:15 p.m. Update: Gains Dwindle In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks gave back the bulk of the day's gains late Wednesday after the release of the Fed minutes.
The Nasdaq was up 1.3%, the S&P 500 0.7%, the NYSE composite 0.6%, and the Dow 0.3%.
Volume was again tracking higher across the board. Advancers beat decliners by about 2-to-1 on both exchanges.
Gains dwindled after the release of the minutes from last month's Fed meeting. Seeing more trouble ahead, Fed officials committed to buying $1.2 trillion in bonds, thus boosting the money supply.

"Most participants viewed downside risks as predominating in the near term, mainly owing to potential adverse feedback effects as reduced employment and production weighed on consumer spending," read the minutes from the March 17-18 meeting.
Fertilizer producer Mosaic (MOS) reversed early losses and rallied 6%. The stock had been down about 6% after a wider-than-expected dive in fiscal Q3 profit.

On the downside, SVB Financial Group (SIVB) gapped below its 50-day moving average and dived 23% in huge trade. Last Tuesday, the bank projected a loss of 28 cents to 36 cents for the quarter vs. analysts' views for a profit of 21 cents. This morning, RBC Capital Markets cut shares to sector perform from outperform.
Group mates Comerica (CMA) and SunTrust Banks (STI) fell 10% and 9%, respectively.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retreat Ahead Of Fed Minutes
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pulled back from intraday highs ahead of the release of the minutes from the March 17 and 18 Federal Reserve meeting. The release is due around 2 p.m. EDT.
The Nasdaq continued to lead with a 1.7% gain. It had been up as much as 2.2%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 climbed 1.2% each and the Dow rose 0.8%.
Volume was tracking about 5% higher on the NYSE and 3% higher on the Nasdaq.
A number of retail issues scored nice gains.

Buckle (BKE) jumped 8% in brisk trade. Analysts expect the teen apparel retailer to post a 14% rise in March same-store sales. Results are due Thursday. Buckle may be adding a handle to its deep cup base.
Aaron Rents (RNT) rose 2% as it closed in on a 28.99 buy point from a cup base. The furniture rental firm reports earnings April 28. Analysts see profit rising 33% to 52 cents a share.

PriceSmart (PSMT) climbed 6% in fast trade after reporting fiscal Q2 earnings above views. This morning the operator of warehouse club stores topped views with a 10% rise in profit. The stock cleared a 19.50 buy point from a double-bottom base April 2. Most of PriceSmart's structure formed below the 200-day moving average, which is a flaw.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Push Ahead In Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
With the exception of the Dow, major stock indexes charged ahead in early afternoon trading Wednesday.
Boosted by gains from Bed, Bath and Beyond (BBBY), Google (GOOG) and Research In Motion (RIMM), the Nasdaq climbed 1.6%. The S&P 500 rose 1%, NYSE composite 0.9% and Dow 0.6%.
Turnover was tracking about 5% higher on both exchanges.

The Securities & Exchange Commission is considering five ways to restrict short sellers. One proposal is to bring back the uptick rule abolished in 2007. Regulators will enact a 60-day public comment period.
Jos. A. Bank Clothiers (JOSB) gapped up and surged 17% to a six-month high following last night's stellar 2008 results.

Family Dollar Stores (FDO) gapped up and gained 5% in a near two-year high in heavy trading. Late Tuesday, the discount retailer delivered fiscal Q3 earnings above views and guided Q3 results above views.

On the downside, Investment Technology Group (ITG) gapped down below its 200-day moving average, diving 22% and slicing its 50-day line. This morning, the agency broker and financial technology firm said its March trading volumes fell compared with year-ago levels.
12:15 Update: Major Indexes Rebuild Gains At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
A stop-and-start session improved by midday Wednesday, as stocks built on early gains.
The Nasdaq continued to lead, up 1.6%. The S&P 500 gained 1%, while the Dow industrials rose 0.7%. The small-cap S&P 600 advanced 0.7%, the NYSE composite 1%.
Volume was higher across the board. It rose 5% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.

Lincoln Educational Services (LINC) bounced off its 50-day moving average, rising 4% in brisk trade. The for-profit education provider owns an 82 Earnings Per Share Rating and a 98 Relative Price Strength Rating.
Fellow school stock Apollo Group (APOL) went the other way, sliding 2% in solid volume as it tunneled further beneath its 200-day moving average.
Elsewhere, Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) climbed 4% in above-average turnover, hitting its highest point in more than four years.
11:15 Update: Stocks Pull Back After Hot Start

5:15 p.m. Update:Â Stocks squeezed out more gains following a back-and-forth session Wednesday. Financials were once again winners following uplifting comments from JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon. Tech issues also joined in the fray.
The Nasdaq outshined, gaining 1%. Apple (AAPL) jumped 5% and regained its 50-day moving average. Amazon.com (AMZN) scored 4%, as did Research In Motion (RIMM).
The S&P 500 add 0.2%, while the Dow and NYSE composite edged up 0.1% each. Citigroup (C) added 6% following Tuesday's 38% gain. JPMorgan Chase rose 5% and Bank of America (BAC) climbed 3%.
Volume ended lower on both exchanges.

Among leading stocks, American Public Education (APEI) jumped 7% following its stellar Q4 results. But the stock backed off after hitting resistance at its 200-day moving average. And it finished just under its 50-day line.
VistaPrint (VPRT) added 4% in heavy trade, but closed just under its 200-day line. Analysts expect a 34% earnings rise in the provider of online printer services this year.

On the downside, Baxter International (BAX) tumbled 5% on more than twice its normal trade following an warning from the Food and Drug Administration. The FDA admonished the medical products maker over the safety of its Colleague Volumetric Infusion pumps.
Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) ended 2% lower after a wild session. The sports bar chain reversed from a near 7% gain.
Elsewhere, weekly jobless claims, retail sales and business inventories are on tap for Thursday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close Higher, Helped By JPMorgan News
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market closed with rare back-to-back gains Wednesday, even after indexes gave back much of a late surge in the final minutes.
The late gains came after JPMorgan (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon said on CNBC the bank was profitable the first two months of 2009.
The Dow and NYSE composite rose 0.1%, the S&P 500 0.2%.
The Nasdaq gained 1% as the tech sector rose after UBS upgraded Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) to buy from neutral.
Volume fell, according to early readings.
Leading stocks remained largely subdued.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Back To Mixed In Late Trading
BY JOANNE VON ALROTH
Indexes stumbled back into mixed territory as oil prices eased.
While the Nasdaq held a 0.2% gain and the S&P 500 maintained a 0.7% increase, the Dow slid 0.5% and the NYSE composite 0.4%.
Volume was lower on both exchanges.

April crude dove $3.38 to $42.33 a barrel after weekly data showed a 700,000-barrel jump in U.S. inventories. Analysts expected a 1 million-barrel decline. OPEC ministers plan to meet in Vienna Sunday to discuss the possibility of additional quota cuts.

AeroVironment (AVAV) regained some of its earlier losses as trade perked up, though the stock remained 4% below its opening price. The move echoed the unmanned aircraft maker's near-34% tumble on Tuesday.

Wholesale drug and medical supply distributor McKesson (MCK) gave up all of Tuesday's gains and plummeted 15% in huge trade on drugstore worries. Moody's analysts said Rite Aid (RAD) could be at risk of failure, while Deutsche Bank warned that all independent drugstores could be hard-hit by the economy.
On the upside, American Public Education (APEI) jumped 8% in heavy trade and regained its 50-day moving average. It posted earnings late Tuesday.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Turn Back To Positive After Stint In The Red

It posted earnings late Tuesday.2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Turn Back To Positive After Stint In The Red
5:15 p.m. Update: Pressure on the current rally increased as the major indexes appeared to chalk up a distribution day.

The NYSE and Nasdaq composites, the Dow and the S&P 500 all clocked losses between 0.1% and 0.9%. Preliminary data showed all indexes closing at volume levels well above Friday's below-average trading.

If the volume proves out in the final tally, the distribution days stacked against the current rally would rise to five for the Dow, four for the S&P 500, three for the Nasdaq and two for the NYSE composite.
The day's losses could have been much worse. Former leading sectors including energy, fertilizers and shipping all rose in strong volume, hedging much of the downside among major indexes.
The medical equipment makers group posted the session's deepest loss, with Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) and Natus Medical (BABY) taking some of the heaviest hits.
Tuesday, the Institute for Supply Management will release its December Services Index numbers.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Fall In Choppy Session
BY VINCENT MAO
Major stock indexes closed lower in a choppy session Monday, ending their recent winning ways.

The Dow fared the worst, losing 0.9% and falling below the 9000 level. JPMorgan ChaseÂ  (JPM) , Verizon CommunicationsÂ  (VZ) and AT&TÂ  (T) were the biggest drags on the blue-chip index, down 7%, 6% and 3%.
The S&P 500 fell 0.5%, the Nasdaq 0.3%. Big-cap techs AppleÂ  (AAPL) and Research In MotionÂ  (RIMM) bucked the trend, rising 4% and 3%. They also regained their respective 50-day moving averages.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite slipped a milder 0.1% thanks to a jump in energy issues.

Volume rose sharply across the board as traders returned from holiday breaks. Breadth finished mixed. Decliners beat advancers by 2-to-1 on the NYSE, while advancers edged out decliners by 15-to-13 on the Nasdaq.
Elsewhere, crude oil rallied to a one-month high on overseas tensions and President-elect Obama's economic stimulus plan. The December contract rose $2.47, or 5%, to $48.81 a barrel.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Slip But Hold Well Within The Session's Range
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Stocks slipped slightly with volume higher headed into the final hour of trading.
The Dow slipped 1.1% and the NYSE composite edged 0.3% lower, propped up by a 1.9% advance in its Energy Index. The Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500 each dipped 0.7%.

The number of advancing industry groups picked up, with more than 55% of the 197 groups tracked by IBD moving higher, compared with about 50% in earlier trading. Oil- and energy-related issues held the biggest piece of the gains, though the bulk of the top-gaining groups rose in light trading.
In oil-related stocks, Weatherford International (WFT) jumped 11%. Atwood Oceanics (ATW) strode ahead 7% in strong trading.

Shipping stocks continued to pound out gains in significant volume. Of the groups posting the day's top 20 advances so far, shippers showed the strongest volume by a wide margin, trading more than 700% above the group's daily average. DryShips (DRYS), TBS International (TBSI) and Excel Maritime (EXM) all rode higher in heavy trading. Homebuilders also cranked up.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Remain Lower; Quality Stocks Move
BY PATRICK CAIN
Stocks remained lower, but the NYSE continued to slowly climb in afternoon trade.
The Dow was down 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.1% and the Nasdaq 0.2%. The NYSE composite was up 0.2%. Volume was higher.
Some watched stocks are among the faster-traded firms. That's a healthy sign for the rally, as opposed to previous rallies where the biggest moves tended to be junk stocks.

Thinly traded China Sky Medical (CSKI) jumped 5%, nearing its all-time high of 17.10, which it hit shortly after the May 2008 initial public offering. The Chinese maker of over-the-counter nutritional supplements broke out from a deep double-bottom base in mid-December.

North American Tanker Shipping (NAT) is up 4% and rising toward the 36.10 buy point of its cup-with-handle base. So far the shipper has topped out at 36.05. Earnings growth exploded 854% last quarter, and analysts expect 250% growth this quarter.
This morning the shipping company announced that it will acquire a double-hull Suezmax tanker by March 15 for $56.7 million.
Stanley (SXE), a logistics provider to the government, rose 2% in above- average trade. The stock is in a cup base, but has decelerating earnings growth.

On the downside, Netease.com (NTES) fell 9%. There is no immediately available news for the high-volume dive. Before today's drop it was nearing its 23.60 double-bottom buy point. Now it could be in the early stages of forming a handle.
Fellow Chinese online gaming companies, such as Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA), seem unfazed. Shanda is down less than 1%.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes In Holding Pattern; Volume Eases From Highs
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Trading eased slightly and indexes stuck with mild losses in early afternoon action.
The Dow backed off to a 0.9% loss. Citigroup (C) and American Express (AXP) turned in the Dow's strongest gains. Verizon Communications (VZ) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) weighed heaviest on the downside.
The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq composite hovered at 0.4% and 0.5% declines. The NYSE composite remained just a fraction below the waterline.
Volume eased from its early highs, but still powered well ahead of Friday's below-average levels.

About half of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD moved higher in the session. Auto and truck tire makers, coal and solar energy stocks waged the strongest advances. Crude oil prices nudged out a $1 gain, just above $47 a barrel.

Netflix (NFLX) popped 4% on above-average volume. The online subscription movie rental services announced Monday a partnership with South Korea-based LG Electronics. LG plans to start producing high-definition TV sets designed to stream Netflix videos directly from the Internet, effectively embedding the Netflix service into the new televisions. Shares are 4% above a 29.85 buy point on a cup-with-handle base.

Compass Minerals (CMP), a purveyor of salt for road de-icing and food preparation, crystallized a 4% gain in strong trading. The move put shares 5% above a 60.63 buy point on a seven week cup-with-handle base.

On the downside, Gentiva Health Services (GTIV) slipped 4% in heavy trading. The home health care services provider broke out of a cup-with-handle base last week. But the base's handle was wedging higher, a warning sign. Shares are now 2% below the handle's 28.36 buy point.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Off Lows Near Session's Halftime
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pared the bulk of their losses, but remained red near the halfway point of Monday's session.

The Dow trimmed a 1.3% loss to 0.6%. Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT & T  (T) were among the biggest decliners in the blue-chip index, falling 7% and 4%, respectively. Bernstein Research downgraded and lowered price targets on both telecom giants.
Meanwhile, the Nasdaq fell 0.5%, S&P 500 0.3% and NYSE composite 0.1%.
Turnover was tracking sharply higher on both exchanges.

Endo Pharmaceuticals (ENDP) gapped down and shed 8% following a downgrade. Caris & Co. cut the drug maker to above average from buy on valuation. The stock was the biggest percentage loser in the IBD 100.
Old Dominion Freight Line (ODFL) erased early gains and slumped 6% in brisk volume. On Friday, the stock hit a wall of resistance at its 200-day moving average.

On the upside, Northwest Pipe (NWPX) reversed early losses, rallied 4% and regained its 200-day moving average. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B from an ugly E in late October.

Nordic American Tanker Shipping (NAT) rallied 4% to a four-month high. The crude oil transporter agreed to buy a vessel for $56.7 million. Nordic also said its Q4 dividend would be near 85 cents a share, up from 50 cents in the year-ago period.
Elsewhere, gold continued to lose luster amid strength in the dollar. The metal slumped $32.70 to $846.80 an ounce.
Crude rose 75 cents to $47.09 a barrel.
11:15 a.m. Update: Dollar, Energy and Tech Stocks Pull Indexes Off Lows In Rising Volume
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Energy and technology issues hauled markets from early losses into mixed trading as the dollar showed broad strength in morning trading.

The NYSE composite rebounded to the break-even mark from its earlier 1.2% slip. The S&P 500 showed a 0.1% loss and the Dow slipped 0.5%. The Nasdaq composite showed a 0.4% decline, pulled off its lows by strong volume gains from Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOG) and Research In Motion (RIMM).
Volume was rumbling far above Friday's below-average trading, up 40% on the NYSE and 30% higher on the Nasdaq.

Oil price rose about a dollar, holding squarely above $47 a barrel. The dollar staged broad gains vs. the euro and the yen. Commodities were widely mixed, and gold dove more than $25 to below $855 an ounce.
Oil- and energy-related groups were the top five gainers so far this morning and 11 of the top 15 upside groups.
Fertilizer makers gained nearly 2% in strong volume. Terra Nitrogen (TNH), Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) and Mosaic (MOS) made some of the strongest moves.

BP Prudhoe Bay Royalty Trust (BPT) gapped up and powered out a better-than 4% advance on nearly six times its average volume. The trust, a portfolio of older, lower production but long-lived oil production sites, jumped in strong volume through the past two weeks.

On the downside, IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) backed off 6% in strong trading. The company, which operates several regulated futures exchanges as well as global OTC energy and credit derivatives markets, reported record annual futures volume and record OTC commissions for 2008.

Overseas, Asian markets opened the week with solid gains. Leading indexes in Shanghai and Hong Kong jumped more than 3%. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo cracked open a 2.1% gain to bag a two-month high as the yen softened.
Markets were narrowly divided in Europe and the U.K., with London's FTSE 100 trading a fraction higher and bourses in Frankfurt and Paris showing mild losses.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Slump In Early Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks opened to the downside Monday and piled on more losses.
The Nasdaq dropped 1.6% and the Dow 1.3%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 each lost 1.2%. Despite the retreat, all major indexes remain above their respective 50-day moving averages.
Volume jumped sharply on both exchanges as traders returned to work.

Conmed (CNMD) gapped down and dived 25% to a near two-year low after slashing its sales outlook. Citing currency fluctuations and lower demand, the surgical device maker said Q4 sales will be about 9% lower than previously stated.

Biogen Idec (BIIB) fell 5% following a JPMorgan downgrade. The broker cut the biotech to neutral from overweight on the belief that its Tysabri multiple sclerosis drug will have a challenging year. JPMorgan also dropped its price target to 50 from 55. Potential support from the stock's 50-day moving average lies about a point below that price target.
Bank of America (BAC) lost 2% despite an upgrade by Fox-Pitt Kelton, which raised the stock to outperform from in line.
On the upside, Almost Family (AFAM) rallied 4% and regained its 50-day moving average. The home nursing care provider might be working on a new base.
Elsewhere, gold tumbled $25.8 to $853.70 an ounce. Oil reversed earlier losses, rising 66 cents to $47 a barrel.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Headed For Downbeat Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures pointed to a lower start ahead of the first full week of trading of 2009.
Nasdaq futures dropped 19 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures shed 11 points and Dow futures lost 94 points.

President-elect Barack Obama is slated to push for huge tax cuts and spending proposals aimed at stimulating the economy. His recovery plan is said to cost around $675 billion to $775 billion, but some economists put the package a closer to $1 trillion.

Apple (AAPL) Chief Executive Steve Jobs released a statement saying he has been losing weight due to a hormone imbalance. For the first time in a decade, he will not speak at the annual Macworld conference, which begins this week in San Francisco. Jobs will remain as Apple's CEO. Shares rose about 3% in the pre-open.
Amazon.com (AMZN) gained about 1% in the pre-market following an upgrade. JPMorgan Chase raised the Internet retailer to overweight from neutral. The broker expects Amazon to expand its market share.
In M&A news, Universal Pictures, a unit of General Electric (GE), reportedly sold its Rogue Pictures label to Relativity Media for about $150 million.
MasterCard (MA) said it bought Irish payment software firm Orbiscom for $100 million.
On the economic front, data on November construction spending will be out at 10 a.m. EST. Analysts expect a 1.2% decline.

December auto and truck sales will be released throughout the day. Double-digit declines are expected by most automakers. Ford  (F) and General Motors (GM) fell 3% and 2%, respectively, in the pre-market.
The key economic report this week is Friday's December jobs report.

Elsewhere, crude oil slipped 44 cents to $45.90 despite continued fighting in the Gaza Strip and news of a Nigerian pipeline attack.5:15 p.m. Update: Pressure on the current rally increased as the major indexes appeared to chalk up a distribution day.The NYSE and Nasdaq composites, the Dow and the S&P 500 all clocked losses between 0.1% and 0.9%. The Mosaic Company (MOS  -  Free Report) is set to release first-quarter 2018 results after the market closes on May 7.Mosaic recorded net loss of $431 million or $1.23 per share in the fourth quarter of 2017, against net income of $12 million or 3 cents a year ago. Adjusted earnings were 34 cents per share for the quarter that topped the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 27 cents.The companyâs revenues rose roughly 10.5% year over year to $2,091.9 million in the quarter, beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1,886 million.Mosaic beat earnings estimates in three of the trailing four quarters while missed in one, with an average beat of 8.75%.Mosaic has outperformed the industry over the past six months. The companyâs shares have gained around 20% over this period compared with roughly 1.9% upside recorded by the industry.Â Â Let's see how things are shaping up prior to this announcement.Factors to ConsiderMosaic, in its fourth-quarter call, said that it expects phosphates sales volumes in the band of 1.9 million to 2.2 million tons for the first quarter of 2018. The segment gross margin is expected to be in the band of $55 to $65 per ton.Potash sales volumes have been forecast in the range of 1.7-2 million tons for the first quarter and the gross margin is anticipated to be in the band of $50 to $60.For 2018, the company expects adjusted earnings to be in the range of $1-$1.5 per share. Selling, general & administrative expenses are forecasted to be between $325 million and $350 million for the year. Capital expenditure is anticipated to be in the range of $900-$1,100 million in 2018.The Zacks Consensus Estimate for revenues for Mosaic for the to-be-reported quarter stands at $1,877 million, reflecting an increase of 18.9% from the year-ago quarter.The Zacks Consensus Estimate for net sales for the Phosphate segment is pegged at $893 million for the first quarter, reflecting an estimated 6.4% rise from the year ago quarter. Potash segmentâs net sales are expected to rise 2.7% year over year in the first quarter as the Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $425 million. Net sales for Mosaicâs International Distribution segment for the first quarter is projected to witness an increase of 28.5% from the prior year quarter as the Zacks Consensus Estimate for the first quarter is pegged at $626 million.Mosaic is exposed to still weak agricultural market fundamentals. However, it should gain from rising global demand for fertilizers. The company expects higher demand for both phosphate and potash to continue this year. It envisions 2018 to be another record year for global shipments of both products. Mosaic also gained from higher realized prices for phosphate and potash in the fourth quarter, which is expected to continue in the March quarter.The Vale Fertilizantes acquisition is also expected to deliver significant synergies. The acquisition has allowed the company to capitalize on the rapidly growing Brazilian agricultural market. Chemicals giant, LyondellBasell Industries N.V. (LYB  -  Free Report) has agreed to buy A. Schulman, Inc. (SHLM  -  Free Report) in a deal worth $2.25 billion, a move that will create a premier global provider of advanced polymer solutions with extensive geographic reach, leading technologies and a diverse product portfolio. A. Schulman is a leading supplier of high-performance plastic compounds, composites and powders.Under the deal terms, LyondellBasell will purchase 100% of the common stock of A. Schulman for $42 per share in cash and one contingent value right per share and will also assume outstanding debt and specific other obligations. The company will use cash on hand to fund the buyout.The planned acquisition has been unanimously approved by the boards of the companies and is subject to regulatory clearances and approval by shareholders of A. Schulman and other customary closing conditions. The acquisition is expected to consummate in second-half 2018.Shearman & Sterling LLP is serving as LyondellBasell's legal counsel on the deal while J.P. Morgan and Dyal Co. are serving as financial advisors.The buyout doubles the size of LyondellBasell's existing compounding business. It also creates a platform for future growth with reach into additional high-growth markets such as packaging and consumer products, electronics and appliances, building and construction, and agriculture. The acquisition will enable the company to offer a comprehensive range of innovative solutions to its customers.LyondellBasell expects to capture $150 million in run-rate cost synergies within two years. The buyout is also expected to be accretive to earnings within the first full year following its closure.LyondellBasell has outperformed the industry it belongs to over the past six months. The companyâs shares have rallied around 27.5% over this period, compared with roughly 14.1% gain recorded by the industry.Â LyondellBasellâs profits surged more than two-fold year over year to $1.9 billion or $4.80 per share in the fourth quarter of 2017. The bottom line was boosted by a non-cash benefit from the U.S. tax reform of $2.07 per share.Adjusted earnings of $2.73 per share for the quarter outstripped the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $2.52. Revenues went up roughly 18% year over year to $9,135 million in the quarter, beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $8,785 million. The company witnessed higher sales across its segments in the quarter.LyondellBasell noted that strong global demand and delays in capacity additions across the industry have led to improved outlook for 2018. The company intends to realize the benefits of strong operating rates across its global portfolio of assets and continue the upward trajectory in profitability for the Houston refinery. The company expects strong contributions from its refinery in 2018 driven by the efforts to improve its reliability and performance.LyondellBasell is a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) stock.LyondellBasell Industries NV Price and ConsensusÂ  LyondellBasell Industries NV price-consensus-chart | LyondellBasell Industries NV QuoteOther Stocks to ConsiderOther companies worth considering in the basic materials space include Methanex Corporation (MEOH  -  Free Report) and The Mosaic Company (MOS  -  Free Report), both sporting a Zacks Rank #1. The fertilizer industry is not out of the woods yet and remains buffeted by certain headwinds that continue to weigh on stocks in the space this year. Sustained pressure on crop commodity prices is scuppering a meaningful recovery.The overall weak fertilizer industry fundamentals have kept investors away this year. Does that mean you should pluck the entire industry out of your portfolio?If you look beyond the negatives, there are a few bright spots such as improving pricing and demand dynamics for potash, a major crop nutrient, and signs of stability in the farm economy.Â Â Â  Â The Zacks Fertilizers industry has underperformed the broader market year to date. While the industry has gained roughly 8.2%, the S&P 500 has returned around 11.9%.Â Â Â  Â Letâs do a quick health check of the fertilizer industry by delving deeper into certain key factors.Crop Commodity Pricing Still a DragThe prevailing softness in agricultural commodity pricing remains a concern for fertilizer and agricultural chemicals companies as it is hindering fertilizer usage by farmers given the adverse effect of lower crop pricing on growersâ income.Prices of major crops (such as corn and soybeans) remain at their multi-year lows as markets remain awash with grains. An expected bumper corn and soybean harvest is likely to put a cap on crop prices in 2017.Â The U.S. Department of Agricultureâs (USDA) harvest outlook indicates another bumper year of production. The USDA, in its September report, raised its corn and soybean harvest forecasts for the 2017/18 crop year. It now sees corn production to be 14.184 billion bushels, up 32 million from its August forecast.The USDA also predicts record soybean production of 4.431 billion bushels compared with its August view of 4.381 billion bushels. This is expected to aggravate the grain glut and restrict crop prices.Has the Farm Economy Hit Bottom?U.S. farm income is expected to tick up this year after three straight years of decline due to low commodity prices. Per the USDAâs August 2017 forecast, net U.S. farm income is expected to go up 3.1% to $63.4 billion in 2017. This compares to the USDAâs February 2017 forecast of an 8.7% decline to $62.3 billion. The upturn in profits will likely be driven by higher cash receipts from the sale of crop inventories.However, despite the projected rise, net farm income would still be lower in 2017 than all the other years since 2010 and a far cry from the record $123.8 billion achieved in 2013.Nevertheless, the USDAâs profit forecast for this year gives signs of stability in the farm economy and suggests that the sector may have finally hit the bottom. Higher anticipated farm income is expected to positively influence farmersâ nutrient-purchasing decisions.Potash Prices on Recovery ModeThe potash market has stabilized this year from the 2016 lows. Potash prices have recovered after feeling gravityâs pull last year due to subdued demand for the nutrient. Most producers of the nutrient, including Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan Inc. , Agrium Inc.  and The Mosaic Company (MOS  -  Free Report) witnessed a spike in prices in the second quarter that drove their potash margins.Potash Corp., a major producer of the nutrient, saw healthy demand for potash in the second quarter and expects consistent customer engagement through the balance of 2017, supported by healthy consumption trends.With Canpotex contracts for the second half in place, the company sees strong consumption in China driven by higher crop acreage and nutrient affordability. The demand environment also remains healthy in Brazil, another important market.Moreover, the government of Indiaâs move to cut the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate on fertilizers from 12% to 5% is a welcome news for famers in that country. It also augurs well for potash demand in India, one of the worldâs top buyers of the nutrient. As such, higher demand from major consumers should drive up potash prices in the second half.Picture Not So Good for Nitrogen & PhosphateHigher supply has contributed to a softer nitrogen pricing environment. Abundant nitrogen supply driven by new production capacity is expected to weigh on global prices in 2017. Additional nitrogen capacity including a significant increase in North America is expected to come online globally in the back half of the year.Global capacity expansion continues to exert pressure on urea and other nitrogen fertilizer prices. Elevated supply in the global nitrogen market is hurting prices, causing farmers to delay buying activities. As such, nitrogen margins of fertilizer producers remain thwarted by a weak pricing environment.Excess capacity (outpacing demand) also continues to hurt prices of phosphate as witnessed in the first two quarters of 2017. Phosphate markets are expected to remain oversupplied in the second half (with incremental capacity from Saudi Arabia and Morocco, as noted by Agrium and Mosaic in their second-quarter earnings calls), thereby putting pressure on prices. Weak prices are expected to continue to affect phosphates margins in third-quarter 2017.2 Fertilizer Stocks Worth Betting OnDespite some positives, the fertilizer market is yet to rebound and there is continuous negative sentiment among agriculture investors that can create uncertainty in the near term.Nevertheless, the constant need of farmers to nourish their crops, replenish nutrients in the soil following a harvest and boost yields to feed a growing world support the bullish case for fertilizers.Below we highlight two fertilizer stocks, armed with a solid Zacks Rank, that are worth considering for investment in the prevailing operating environment.Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile S.A. (SQM  -  Free Report)Santiago, Chile-based Sociedad Quimica is a solid choice armed with a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). You can see the complete list of todayâs Zacks #1 Rank stocks here.The company has an expected earnings growth of 52.2% for 2017. It also has a long-term expected earnings per share growth rate of 32.5%. The stock has also gained a whopping 100.5% year to date, significantly outperforming the Zacks Fertilizers industryâs gain of 8.2% over the same period.Annual estimates for Sociedad Quimica have also moved north over the past 60 days, reflecting analystsâ confidence in the stock. Over this period, the Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2017 and 2018 for the companyâs earnings has increased by around 11.8% and 24%, respectively.Intrepid Potash, Inc. (IPI  -  Free Report)Headquartered in Denver, CO, Intrepid Potash is another attractive pick with a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). The company has an expected earnings growth of 73.8% for 2017. It also delivered positive earnings surprise of 50% in the last reported quarter. Moreover, the stock has also gained a solid 96.2% year to date, significantly outperforming the Zacks Fertilizers industryâs gain of 8.2%.Â Will You Make a Fortune on the Shift to Electric Cars?Here's another stock idea to consider. Much like petroleum 150 years ago, lithium power may soon shake the world, creating millionaires and reshaping geo-politics. Soon electric vehicles (EVs) may be cheaper than gas guzzlers. Mosaic (MOS  -  Free Report) did not disappoint when it reported its fiscal second quarter 2011 results on Jan 4. The agriculture sector has been hot as crop prices have been at multi-year, or in some cases multi-decades, highs in the last few months.
The fertilizer company surprised on the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 12.1%. Earnings per share were $1.02 compared to the Zacks Consensus of 91 cents.
Revenue rose 59% to $2.7 billion from $1.7 billion in the year ago quarter.
Gross margin jumped to 29% from 18% a year ago due to significantly higher phosphate selling prices and potash sales volumes.It's All About the Phosphates
The company had a solid quarter in its phosphate division as both prices and volumes were higher than expected. Sales rose 54% to $2 billion from $1.3 billion last year.

It saw record sales volumes of 3.7 million tonnes, higher than the company's prior range and much higher average selling prices of $461 per tonne compared to just $287 per tonne a year ago. With that kind of price increase, it's not surprising that sales are surging.Potash Less Robust

The price increases were not as pronounced on the potash side of the business. This was a disappointment to several of the analysts. Sales, however, rose 69% to $699 million from $414.3 million last year.
Its average selling price was just $331 per tonne compared to $370 a year ago. Total sales volume, however, did rise to 1.8 million tonnes from 1 million tonnes last year.
Still, potash prices in North America were up 35% from the summer industry wide so price increases are happening, just not as quickly as some hoped.Global Market Outlook Raised

Demand for phosphates and potash continue to be strong but greater supply is limited in the near term. Mosaic raised its full year shipments for phosphates to a range of 59 to 61 million tonnes from its prior guidance of 57 to 59 million tonnes. The prior global record had been 57 million tonnes.
It also sees a more robust market for potash and raised that range as well. It now expects 53 to 56 million tonnes, up from its prior guidance of 52 to 55 million tonnes.What About the Estimates?

The analysts are still evaluating the quarter so estimate revisions have yet to really come in. However, 1 has moved higher in the last 7 days for fiscal 2011, pushing the Zacks Consensus up to $3.83 from $3.82 per share.
But there are currently 19 estimates for 2011 so we'll have to see what the other revisions do.Still Solid Fundamentals
Shares got a boost from the earnings report but they were already near 52-week highs. It is trading with a forward P/E of 19.6 now which isn't cheap.

Mosaic is still a Zacks #3 Rank (hold) stock.Tracey Ryniec is the Value Stock Strategist for Zacks.com. She is also the Editor in charge of the market-beating Zacks Value Trader service. You can follow her at twitter.com/traceyryniec.

The five best performing stocks on the Zacks #1 Rank List last week were: DryShips, Inc. , TBS International Ltd. (TBSI), Excel Maritime Carriers Ltd. (EXM), The Mosaic Company (MOS  -  Free Report)  and Terra Industries Inc. (TRA).DryShips, Inc.  is once again a top-performing Zacks #1 Rank company, as its sector continues to perform extraordinarily well in the market and on this list. Given the strong momentum in its industry, earnings estimates have been trending higher for several months. Expectations for this year are up approximately 26% in the past two months and 8% in the past 30 days.

DryShips will announce its third-quarter performance soon, and analysts are expecting results that underscore the strong conditions in its space and its impressive numbers in the past several periods. For the second quarter, earnings per share reached $1.59, excluding items, which topped the consensus by more than 16%. Voyage revenue advanced to $112.5 million from $54.5 million. Analysts have boosted earnings estimates for the third quarter by 30% and 11.4% in the past two months and 30 days, respectively.

TBS International Ltd. (TBSI) is an ocean transportation services company that offers worldwide shipping solutions through liner, parcel and bulk services and vessel chartering. That puts TBSI in one of the hottest sectors of the market right now, benefiting from strong demand for commodities such as iron ore and coal. Over the past three months, earnings estimates for this year are up about 15%, including a rise of 2.3% in the past two months. Expectations for its yet-to-be-released third quarter are also up in those timeframes.

Shares of TBS International advanced more than 22% last week. This was the first time that the company made the top performers list since August when it reported second-quarter results. For the quarter, adjusted earnings per share of 56 cents significantly advanced year-over-year, and also edged past the consensus by almost 2%. Total revenues jumped 31% to $77.2 million from $59 million. More recently, TBS International took delivery of the M.V. Yakima Princess, putting its fleet at 34 multipurpose handymax and handysize vessels. The company expects the delivery of three more bulk carriers in the next three months.  Excel Maritime Carriers Ltd. (EXM) was a top-performing Zacks #1 Rank company for September, and made its first appearance on the list for this month in the week ended Oct 12. Shares gained 19.6% during the week for the drybulk carrier company. As with many companies in this industry, earnings estimates are on the rise for Excel Maritime. Expectations for the year are up approximately 21% in the past two months, including a rise of 4.9% in the past 30 trading days.

For its second quarter, Excel Maritime Carriers announced earnings per share of 71 cents, excluding items, eclipsing the consensus by almost 25%. Total revenues advanced to $37.3 million from $26.7 million. The company said it is benefiting from the strength in shipping markets and consistent implementation of its balanced fleet deployment strategy. Earnings expectations for the third quarter are also trending higher.

The Mosaic Company (MOS  -  Free Report) announced solid fiscal first-quarter results last week, helping the agricultural chemicals company make the top-performing Zacks #1 Rank list. The company has been able to capitalize on strong agricultural fundamentals, including higher selling prices for phosphates and potash. Earnings per share in the quarter soared year-over-year, and also bettered the consensus by approximately 6.7%. Sales jumped by 55% to $2 billion. With prices for phosphates remaining strong and prices for potash increasing, Mosaic expects strong earnings and cash flow for the rest of fiscal 2008.
Shares of the company advanced about 17.7% last week. Earnings estimates for this fiscal year are up 16.5% in the past month, including an increase of about 8.7% in just the past seven trading days.

Terra Industries Inc. (TRA), a leading international producer of nitrogen products, is part of an industry that has a lot of momentum at the moment. There is good demand in the agricultural and industrial markets right now, especially in emerging economies. Shares of the company gained 16.3% for the week ended Oct 12. Over the past month, earnings estimates for this year are up 19%.

Terra Industries will report its third-quarter results on Oct 25. Solid demand led to a strong second-quarter report. Earnings per share of 66 cents advanced year-over-year from five cents, while revenues increased more than 30% to $693.8 million from $523.5 million. Nitrogen products revenues were up approximately 32%. The company said its outlook for the rest of the year and beyond remains positive, thanks in part to good demand for fall fertilizer fill and seasonally firm nitrogen prices.

The credit crunch has yet to have a meaningful impact on overall expectations for growth. Ahead of the "official" start of third-quarter earnings season, the Zacks Revisions Ratio, which measures the proportion of full-year earnings estimates being revised upwards relative to those being revised downwards over the preceding four weeks, is right about average at 0.82.

To put this number in perspective, I've compiled pre-earnings season trends in earnings estimate revisions for the past two years. These numbers represent the cumulative number of earnings forecasts that have been revised during the preceding four weeks for companies within the Zacks Rank universe1.

As you can see, brokerage analysts have not been more cautious (or less cautious) then they have at similar points over the past two years. A big reason is that in the face of a sinking greenback, record highs for crude and tightened lending standards, the economy and corporate profits are continuing to grow. As I stated last week, the median company within the within the S&P 1500 (S&P 500, S&P MidCap 400 and S&P SmallCap 600) is projected to have generated an 8.5% increase in profits during the third-quarter.

These numbers do conflict with some of the recent economic data that has been released. August durable goods orders declined 4.9%, the first decline since May. The Conference Board's consumer confidence index sank to a two-year low this month. The National Federation of Retailers predicted that this year's holiday shopping season will be the worse it has been in five years. Even Target (TGT  -  Free Report), whose sales had been holding up, recently slashed its September sales forecast. And I'm not even mentioning the housing numbers which just stunk.

So how does one reconcile this difference between the trend in earnings estimate revisions and the recent economic data? Durable goods orders are volatile and a single month's change really does not tell much. The trend over the next few months will be more important, especially if there is a notable, sustained drop because it will suggest that the credit crunch is widening. At this point, I don't believe that such a scenario will develop, but I do acknowledge that it is within the realm of possibilities. Consumer confidence surveys are interesting, but they do not necessarily reflect actual spending habits. A person can say he is more worried about the economy, but continue to visit Starbucks (SBUX  -  Free Report) everyday. Retail sales were not strong over the summer, something that has already been factored into earnings forecasts. It is possible that profit projections for many retailers will have to be cut further.

On the other hand, there is evidence that Chicken Little is wrong about the outlook for stocks. There are many countries experiencing stronger growth than the U.S. and this adds to demand for exports. (The weak dollar makes U.S. exports more price competitive, an added plus.) Corporate balance sheets are strong overall. Demand for machinery, parts and technology (e.g. laptop computers), despite today's durable goods report, has been good. There are many companies that are enjoying pricing power. Even in retail, there are several companies that are doing just fine (e.g. Tiffany (TIF  -  Free Report) and Zumiez ). Plus, the U.S. economy is still growing, even if the pace of growth has slowed recently. Simply put, at the aggregate level, conditions for profit growth continue to exist.

Last week, brokerage analysts raised their full-year forecasts on five of the six stocks within Fertilizers. Those stocks were Agrium (AGU), CF Industries (CF  -  Free Report), Mosaic (MOS  -  Free Report), Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan (POT) and Terra Industries (TRA). All five are Zacks #1 Rank ("strong buy") stocks.

The upgrades reflected optimism that these companies will continue to enjoy pricing power for the foreseeable future. Demand for potash and fertilizer have been strong and are expected to remain so. It's also worth noting that the upward revisions to estimates occurred as grain prices and other agriculture-related commodities are setting either record or 52-week highs.

The reaction to the fiscal third-quarter earnings reports from four of the major investment banking firms has been somewhat predictable given the numbers. Profit forecasts for both fiscal 2007 and fiscal 2008 were cut on Bear Stearns (BSC) and Morgan Stanley (MS  -  Free Report). Both firms missed the consensus estimate by sizeable margins because of the turmoil in the credit markets. Lehman Brothers (LEH) missed by a penny as it too was hit by the problems in the fixed-income markets. Brokerage analysts are split on the outlook, however, with two raising fiscal 2007 profit forecasts and three cutting fiscal 2007 forecasts. Notably, no analysts raised their forecasts for fiscal 2008, whereas four cut their forecasts. Forecasts for fiscal 2008 are down ten cents from a week ago to $7.66 per share.

Brokerage analysts raised their fiscal 2007 and 2008 forecasts on Goldman Sachs (GS  -  Free Report) after the firm topped expectations by nearly 40% with profits of $6.13 per share. GS was able to employ trading strategies to take advantage of the turmoil, though not all of its hedge funds followed the same practice. Forecasts for fiscal 2007 are at a new high with brokerage analysts now expecting profits of $23.67 per share versus $21.83 a week ago. Prior to the recent surprise, the consensus forecast had been falling. For fiscal 2008, the consensus estimate calls for profits of $22.45 per share versus $21.82 a week ago. Two months ago, the consensus estimate had stood at $22.80, however.

The big question going forward is how much merger and acquisition activity is going to occur over the next few quarters. The answer at this point is unknown. Higher raw material costs provide an incentive for companies to seek synergies through mergers as well as to grab additional market share. Investors are demanding better terms for companies that are not exhibiting financial strength, however, which is a headwind. In addition, the psychological impact of the credit crunch could make it harder for private equity firms to get favorable financing terms. This said, financing remains available for companies (and individuals) in strong financial shape.
